lines.text: And that's a good point of clarification. But he was arrested and indicted under Merrick Garland. No, under Trump. Who had all of the information.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Under Trump. Epstein was arrested, indicted, and committed suicide under Trump. In 2019, Trump was president. Merrick Garland was not the attorney general.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: OK, I stand corrected. So 19, that came in the first Trump administration, correct?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, and Bill Barr was the attorney general. Bill Barr was the guy who ordered the investigation into the suspected suicide.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Right. But then for four years, did you hear Hakeem Jeffries say, I want to know all the things that happened?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: No, but I heard, no, hold on. But I heard, maybe we're onto something here. Because I, no, I heard Donald Trump say that. And now Donald Trump, that he's in power, is the guy saying, we don't want to know anything.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You're going to have to find that soundbite. Because what Trump was saying was, we want transparency. We want to throw out all of this stuff. Which is exactly what Hakeem Jeffries was saying.  But Jeffries didn't say it for four years.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Right, and now Trump is saying, let's move on, and Jeffries is saying we want transparency.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Now, Trump is in the... Now, Hakeem suddenly has an epiphany that he wants to know all about it, when his party controlled the White House and the Justice Department, but he didn't seem to want to know about it then. Doesn't that strike you a little bit disingenuous?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, I feel like all politicians are disingenuous. That's why I think you and I are good at what we do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I don't dismiss it that easily.  OK. Let's get back to Trump. Let's get back to Trump. This is important. I want to get to you, Trump, on immigration. But go finish right now on Epstein. All right. I'll do the immigration, too. There's no rush tonight. We'll get it to everything. Donald Trump's hurting himself now. And I just wonder if there's anybody in his administration that is telling him that. Because most of the people don't want to get involved with this at all.  So I don't know if he's getting — look, Mr. President, this is starting to hurt you. It's hurting you with your base. The press is looking for stuff to get you on. And it's diverting away from very important stories like Putin-Russia, like China, all right, like immigration. And it's becoming a tabloid wave that we have to stop. I wonder if there's anybody saying that to him. There should be.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, that's the point, right, of surrounding yourself with people who are willing to tell you the truth. And I think what you're saying is, is that unlike Trump 1.0 and Trump 2.0, there's not those people, because they're seen as disloyal.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You talked to the guy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I haven't spoken to him about this. You're the reporter. All I know is that Pam Bonnie's not calling the shots. I can tell you that with certainty.  I want to ask you... No, you want to go on to immigration?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I do, because I think this is what's interesting about this, is there's a revolt that you point out inside of MAGA. You and I both see it. It's a split.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's a split. It's not a total revolt.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's a split. Trump tried to put it down last Tuesday. It didn't work in the cabinet meeting when he dressed down the reporter. Then there was the big eruption on Friday. We played all the sound bites. Then we got on to the amnesty thing.  And now, all of a sudden, there's this discussion of some kind of farm worker parole program on and on. I get the feeling that in Trump 2.0, Trump is not afraid of the split. He doesn't really care at this point. He doesn't... Possible.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's annoying him, no doubt about that. But he doesn't have to run again. But he's a man who likes approval.  He likes the MAGA approval. When he showed up at Giants Stadium for the soccer game, he got booed. He didn't like that. And I don't know who was booing, whether it were liberal people or MAGA people that want more information about him. Nobody could possibly know. But Donald Trump wants people to like him. And this one is very, very hard for me to process because it's so easily corrected. OK. Bondi gets out.  says, picture with Merrick Garland, who would show up. This is what we know. We can't tell you names. We don't want these people destroyed. That's fair. People will buy that. And that's it. You put it to bed. Why not?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: No, I agree. I agree with you. The amnesty thing is a whole different thing. You and I actually agree on that. We both wrote about it on the same day. Bill, good to see you as always. Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Bill O'Reilly argues that Trump should order Pam Bondi to hold a press conference and answer general questions about the Epstein investigations. He believes that the Justice Department should release information to restore public trust, but emphasises the need to protect individuals from unwarranted reputational damage by not releasing specific names without context. O'Reilly criticises both Democratic and Republican politicians for being disingenuous in their calls for transparency and points out that the Biden administration had similar information on Epstein but did not take action. He suggests that Trump is hurting himself politically by not addressing the issue proactively and that a simple statement from Bondi and Garland could put the matter to rest.
summary.SPEAKER_03: The host questions O'Reilly's statements and points out inconsistencies in his previous arguments. He highlights that Trump promised to release everything about the Epstein files during his campaign but is now reluctant to do so. The host argues that the perception of the Trump administration hiding something is damaging and that Trump needs to address this issue to appease his base. He also brings up the political aspects of the situation, noting that Democrats are using the Epstein saga to criticise Trump. The host suggests that there is a revolt within the MAGA movement and that Trump seems less concerned about maintaining unity in his base compared to his previous political endeavours.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the political implications of the Epstein saga involving Donald Trump. The speakers debate whether Trump and his administration should release information held by the Justice Department related to Epstein. They argue that transparency is needed to address public concerns and perceptions of cover-ups, but also acknowledge the risks of releasing names without proper context, which could lead to reputational damage. The discussion highlights the hypocrisy of some politicians in calling for transparency only when it suits their party interests.

video_title: Epstein 'couldn't have killed himself,' says inmate held in same cell | Banfield

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Okay, I'm joined now by someone, and this is interesting, with intimate knowledge of the very jail cell Epstein died in, Michael Francis. He was a capo for the Colombo crime family in the 1980s. He served time in the exact cell where Epstein was later held. Michael, welcome back to the program.  Tell us about that cell, and what do you make of these revelations that there is a minute missing from the surveillance video, Michael?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, listen, you know, I spent seven months on that tier and in those cells. And the first thing I have to say, there's no way you are able to commit suicide. There's just no way. There's no way to hang yourself. There's nothing from the ceiling. There's nothing from the bed. You'd have to be a midget.  and work really hard to try to hang yourself. And I don't think you can accomplish it at that point. You know, as far as the cameras being off, I haven't experienced that. I did eight years in prison. And I haven't experienced cameras being broken in the perfect storm of correctional officers not walking those cells. They walk in, and they look in on you all the time. As a matter of fact, you know, sometimes it's embarrassing to go to the toilet, because they're walking past you and looking in the cell constantly.  I've said this from day one, I do not believe it was suicide. I can't talk about what happened to him, but I don't believe it was a suicide because you just couldn't physically do it. It would be almost impossible to do it. So that's number one. It must be interesting, Michael.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: When you look at the video, though, it must be interesting because you know the area. I mean, we all look at this and it just looks like a prison, but this must look very familiar to you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Absolutely. Very familiar. You know, and the fact that a minute is missing, you know, look, everything around this guy, I just did a very deep dive into him, which I'll be releasing on my platform in the next several days. You know, look, there's no way that this person operated alone. You know, look,  They have the videos. Alan Dershowitz recently said that he saw the client list, but because there's people that he know, he can't—because he's an attorney, he can't, you know, reveal what he saw. But he said he saw the client list. He's demanding that it be released. You know, to think that there's no flight logs, that there's no client list, that the thousands of recordings that they had—because I found out for sure that he had cameras on every bedroom.  every bedroom, recording everything, and all of a sudden, all of it is gone? I mean, none of this makes sense. And, look, the only reason it's important, it's not that anybody's trying to say, come on, this guy was a creep. And there was young women involved in this, young girls that were trafficked and abused. I have four daughters, and I have granddaughters. And I just don't like it. And anybody that's involved in this should be held accountable. I recently interviewed Paul Hutchinson.  who was a major figure in the Sound of Freedom. He was one of the ones that went to rescue, I think, 51 or 52 of these young girls and young boys that were being exploited and trafficked. I mean, this has got to stop. And if these people are not held accountable, it's just going to continue. And, unfortunately, it seems like it's people with power and money. It seems that, from what my investigation,  you know, that this Les Wexner was the first one that Epstein was able to bribe. And, you know, there's a lot of stuff here that needs to come out, and it's really shameful if it doesn't. That's my opinion. But as far as the jail cell, no way there was a solution.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We only have... Yeah, I want to go back to the jail cell, because you have... I mean, you lived in that jail cell. And just real quick, again, tell me, would you have the privacy in that jail cell to take your own life?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Not only would you not have the privacy, I don't understand how you would be able to do it. You have to hang yourself from something. There's nothing on the ceiling that you can hang a bedsheet on. The bed is not that high. I mean, you have to try to lay down on the floor in some way, because Jeffrey Epstein was a fairly big guy.  You'd have to be a midget to even try to hang yourself. So it's not a question of not only are there cameras on, are there CEOs walking the tier constantly, especially from what I understand, Jeffrey Epstein was on Suicide Watch for a while. They want you very, very closely. Trust me on that. So I just can't buy it. I cannot buy it. I'm sorry. And I have no horse in this race other than my experience and the fact that I just couldn't see it happening. Yeah.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, well, we appreciate you coming on tonight, Michael. We appreciate your perspective, especially as someone who's been in that exact cell.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you so much, sir. You're welcome.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The host introduces Michael Francis and asks him about his insights into Epstein’s cell and the recent revelations about the missing surveillance video. The host also probes Francis’s views on the possibility of suicide and the broader implications of the case.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Michael Francis claims that suicide is physically impossible in the cell he and Epstein occupied due to the lack of suitable ligature points and constant surveillance. He expresses scepticism about the official narrative, highlighting the missing footage, the alleged destruction of Epstein’s evidence, and suggests that Epstein did not operate alone. Francis implies that powerful and wealthy individuals are involved and need to be held accountable.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the death of Jeffrey Epstein in jail. Michael Francis, a former inmate who served time in the same cell, asserts that suicide is impossible due to the cell's design and constant monitoring. He also questions the missing surveillance footage and the surrounding circumstances, suggesting foul play and involvement of powerful individuals.

video_title: Zohran Mamdani's rise is 'really scary' for New York and America: Lucy Biggers | On Balance

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Lucy Biggers, social media editor at The Free Press, former Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez supporter, is with us now. Lucy, appreciate it. I say over and over again to my Republican friends, who are gleeful that they can define Democrats as socialists now, that the media was foolish to dismiss Donald Trump in 2016, and we would be foolish again to dismiss this socialist movement inside the Democratic Party in 2025. Do you agree?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I definitely agree. And thank you so much for having me on. Over at the Free Press, we've been reporting on this for months. One of our reporters, Olivia Reingold, was really on this beat. And the way she was covering his campaign and the way Mamdani was attracting crowds just walking through the city. And she said months ago, like, there's something here. And I think we see Cuomo trying to do whatever he's doing, resuscitating some sad campaign. And Mamdani's got the energy and the hype, and he should be taken seriously.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I think this guy Omar Fatah should be taken seriously as well. I have a friend in Minneapolis, very involved in politics, said the same thing, that it was written off as a fluke or as a, you know, sort of this wacko guy, and now all of a sudden he might win. If you think about how Trump identified this anger within working class, and it began with rural whites in 2015, but rural voters, traditional value voters in 2015.  The class that I see being identified by Democrats is this credentialed, entitled class who has four degrees in comparative literature, buys $9 coffees, and then complains they can't afford rent. And they, too, are angry. Is that who Mamdani is speaking to?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, that was the class and group of people I used to identify with back in 2018 when AOC got elected. I made a huge viral video about her campaign that really blew up. I was a big supporter of AOC, the Green New Deal, Free College, Bernie Sanders. And yeah, I think it's the college educated elite. We could see from the exit polls, she did the best among people making  I'm saying off the top of my head, but I want to say it was like $100,000 a year and mostly white people. He didn't win the working class communities. And I get it. There's this desire for change. But unfortunately, we've seen with every city or country that tries socialism, it's the road to hell is paved with good intentions. It never ends well. And so it's really scary. I think it's really scary to see people like Mamdani taking off because it's not going to end well for cities like New York.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, it didn't end well for Caracas, Venezuela, Havana, Cuba, just to name a few. This from Barack Obama. I think it's going to require a little bit less navel-gazing and less whining and being in fetal positions, and it's going to require Democrats to just toughen up. I don't know what that means. Do you?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I don't know what it means. The Democrats are so lost. I think you see Cuomo right now. It's like, what are you standing for, other than the fact that you hate Trump? And I think that's where you have to give, like, the Mamdanis of the world credit, because they actually are standing for something. They're standing for really stupid ideas, but they have a policy. And I think people are really hungry for that populism on the left, and it's taking this form of this socialism. I don't know what the Democratic elite of the last decade  stand for. They really just hate Trump. But their elites, they don't want socialism. But they can't then give Trump any credit when he does anything right. So they're very lost. And then they're also sort of caught up. And they don't want to say the wrong thing to be canceled, so they say nothing. So they're very lost. And I think this is why Mamdani, I think, could win. And this is going to be what's going to be the future of the Democratic Party, which hopefully will never get big enough to create a national stage.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We've got to learn more about this Fatah guy in Minnesota. But there is a chance that Barack Obama is going to become the George W. Bush of the Republican Party, which is wild when you think about that. Lucy, this was great, as always.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We'll talk soon.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Lucy Biggers agrees that socialist candidates like Jabari Mamdani in New York should be taken seriously. She highlights the energy and hype surrounding his campaign. Biggers, a former AOC supporter, notes that Mamdani is appealing to the college-educated elite, but she warns that socialism has never ended well for any city or country that has tried it. She expresses fear for the future of New York if Mamdani wins.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host emphasises the importance of not dismissing the socialist movement within the Democratic Party, drawing parallels with the media's misjudgement of Donald Trump in 2016. He suggests that Omar Fatah in Minnesota is also a candidate to watch. The host critiques the Democratic Party for lacking a clear stand and being perceived as out of touch with the working class. He argues that the party is caught up in identity politics and cancellation culture, and this is creating an opening for populist socialist candidates. The host also makes a provocative statement about Barack Obama potentially becoming the George W. Bush of the Republican Party.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the rise of socialist candidates within the Democratic Party, specifically focusing on New York and Minnesota. The speakers acknowledge the growing momentum of these candidates but express concerns about the potential consequences of socialism.

video_title: Menendez ruling huge victory in freedom bid: Brothers' attorney | Banfield

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So the odds of Lyle and Eric Menendez getting out of prison go up and down faster than the stock market, it seems like. But now, and I know you've heard this before, those odds, they finally actually seem to be in the brothers' favor. We just heard from the L.A. District Attorney. Now I want to bring in Alexandra Kazarian. She is a senior trial attorney for Garagos & Garagos, which has been fighting for Lyle and Eric's freedom.  for years now. It's good to see you again, Alexandra. I heard you were laser-focused while the district attorney was speaking. It seemed like he was kind of trying to downplay this latest decision by the judge, but it does seem like a pretty big win for you guys.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Oh, it's a huge win. And you know, Mr. Hockman talks about ultimate justice and ultimate justice in this case would be a manslaughter plea. If Mr. Hockman's office wanted to cut right to ultimate justice in this case, it would be, you know, agreeing that these boys should have initially been able to present a manslaughter conviction to the jury, which wasn't allowed. And that's the crux of the prima facie case here in the habeas.  What the determination that Judge Ryan needs to make is, is there evidence that either wasn't available at the time that should have gone to the jury that would have changed their verdict? And what Mr. Hockman has wrong is that Leslie Abramson always, as part of her defense in this case, always argued that it was imperfect self-defense.  that yes, the brothers killed their parents because they thought they were going to be killed, but an imperfect self-defense allows the jury to understand that they might have been wrong. Even though they were wrong in believing that they were going to be killed, they still believed it.  And if they believed it and were wrong, it's not a complete self-defense, but it does lower the conviction from a murder to a manslaughter. And in their second trial, they were not allowed, the jury was not allowed to consider the manslaughter, they were not allowed to consider the imperfect self-defense.  So, the way that the sexual abuse plays into that is that because of the abuse by their parents, because of the father's sexual abuse and because of their mother sanctioning this abuse, creating this hallway rule where adults and family members were not allowed to go down the hallway if one of the children was in the room with Jose, this terrible, terrible thing that both of these parents did, because of that abuse,  Psychologically, these children were in fear of these parents and believed, even if it may have been incorrect on that day, that these parents were going to kill them and that the only way out was to kill them themselves. That is an imperfect self-defense. It wasn't allowed to go to the jury. Because of this new evidence, Judge Ryan has decided that it should be considered as to whether this murder conviction should stand.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So if he throws out the convictions, Alexandra, will you still have a parole hearing? How does this all play out?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Each one is separate, so it really depends. That's a really, really hard question to answer, because with the timing of it, we don't know exactly when this hearing is going to happen, if it's going to happen before the parole hearing. So that's just something that I don't have an answer to, and I really wish I could. And I know everybody wishes I could answer that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Are you surprised? I mean, you know, these guys have served 29 years in prison. It's 29, right? 29 years total.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think they've been sentenced for 29 years.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We've seen the documentaries. They've been in custody, I think, close to 35. Are you surprised that the district attorney is still, is so passionate about this, it seems? I mean, he has really made it, it feels personal to him that he doesn't want them to get out.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It does. I understand wanting the integrity of a conviction to stay in place, but if it's not the right conviction, I don't know why you would argue against evidence of extreme sexual abuse. I mean, in this case, Jose Menendez is somebody who skirted justice his entire life, who people knew. The adults in the situation surrounding these poor brothers, they knew.  And they didn't do anything. As a matter of fact, every single adult that found out about the abuse abandoned them. So these two boys were failed by everybody. So the fact that he wasn't brought to justice is the failure of the system here. And I think it's time that these two brothers did receive ultimate justice, which is the ability to live their lives.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

summary.SPEAKER_01: The host discusses the fluctuating odds of the Menendez brothers' release and introduces Alexandra Kazarian. He questions the DA's passion for the case, noting the brothers' long incarceration and the public's interest.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Alexandra Kazarian emphasises that the recent judge's decision is a significant win as it allows for the consideration of new evidence regarding sexual abuse, which could support an imperfect self-defence claim and potentially reduce their conviction to manslaughter. She highlights the psychological impact of the abuse on the brothers and criticises the DA for downplaying the evidence.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the recent legal developments in the case of Lyle and Eric Menendez, suggesting a potential win for their defence team which could lead to a reduced conviction.

video_title: No surprise judge ruled to resentence Menendez brothers: Los Angeles DA | Banfield

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right, so it's been more than two years since the Menendez brothers filed a habeas corpus petition challenging their murder convictions for killing their parents. But the answer they just got from an L.A. judge was definitely worth the wait for them. The judge agreed the evidence the brothers presented that their father sexually abused them and others may well have gotten them acquitted.  or convicted of lesser charges had it actually been admitted at trial. Remember, that wasn't allowed to come in at trial. So now the state has 30 days to show why the murder convictions should stand. This is the second major legal win in a row for Team Menendez. Remember back in May, a different judge cut their sentences from life without parole to 50 years to life, making it possible now, but not guaranteed that they could walk out of prison this year.  For the L.A. District Attorney, the habeas bombshell, it's just another headache for him over the weekend. Another high-profile murder case came to a sudden and unexpected end. You might remember this one. Sam Haskell Jr., son of famous Hollywood agent, died by suicide in an L.A. jail. He'd been accused of killing his wife and her parents, dismembering their bodies and dumping their remains in trash bins.  Haskell died two days before a preliminary hearing to determine whether he should stand trial. And by the way, the last time he appeared in court, he actually happened to be in a suicide vest. I'm joined now by Nathan Hockman, Los Angeles County District Attorney. Welcome back to the program, sir. Are you surprised by the judge's ruling with the Menendez brothers?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No, I'm not. This judge is basically going through the steps. And the steps for the habeas petition, and this habeas petition was filed in May of 2023, is that you first ask for an informal response from the prosecution. So we provided an informal response back in February of 2025, at which point we wrote an 80-page-plus brief explaining why the new evidence, this is  evidence that supposedly didn't exist before the trial, couldn't be obtained before the trial, is new, it's admissible, and it's significant enough to warrant a brand new trial. We explain in this 80 plus page submission why it wasn't new, why it wasn't admissible, why it wasn't material, why it wasn't significant, and therefore it shouldn't justify a new trial.  The next step, though, is if the judge makes a finding that says there is at least a minimal amount of possibility, they call that prima facie. There's a prima facie case that this evidence makes. We're actually going to ask for the formal response from the prosecution, which is what he's asked for.  So he's made absolutely no findings that the defendants in this case have met their burden of proof to show that this evidence is new, admissible, significant, and warranting a new trial.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: He just asked us to make a formal response to their petition, which we intend to do within 30 days.

summary.unstructured_summary:
{'high_level_summary': 'The conversation discusses two high-profile murder cases in LA
: the Menendez brothers and Sam Haskell Jr. The Menendez brothers have received a significant legal win as a judge agreed that previously excluded evidence of sexual abuse could have impacted their trial outcome. The state now has 30 days to respond. On the other hand, Sam Haskell Jr. died by suicide in jail before his preliminary hearing.', 'SPEAKER_00': 'The news anchor summarises the recent legal developments in the Menendez brothers case, highlighting the judge\'s ruling that allows the admission of previously excluded evidence and the subsequent 30-day period for the state to respond. They also briefly mention the unrelated case of Sam Haskell Jr. who died by suicide in jail.', 'SPEAKER_02': 'The LA District Attorney clarifies that the judge\'s ruling does not signify a finding in favour of the Menendez brothers. He explains the procedural steps in a habeas petition and asserts that the prosecution has already argued why the new evidence is not new, admissible, or significant enough to warrant a new trial. The DA states they will provide a formal response within 30 days.'}

video_title: Verdict 'not necessarily unexpected' in Justin Mohn murder case : Lawyer | Banfield

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So the Sixth Amendment gives everybody who is charged with a crime the right to a competent defense, but that doesn't mean that everybody actually has a defense. Case in point, the Pennsylvania man who killed his own father in January of last year and posted a video of himself holding his dad's severed head on YouTube.  Justin Moen was convicted last week after taking the stand at a bench trial, that means there's no jury, and admitting everything under oath. The same judge who found him guilty sentenced him on the same day to life in prison with no parole. It was actually two life sentences, barring some kind of Menendez-style  legal miracle, kind of like what we were just talking about. Justin Moen will never breathe free air again. And through it all, Attorney Steven Jones was at Moen's side, and he joins us live now in his first national TV interview since the verdict and sentencing. Thank you for being with us, Steven. I mean, it certainly seemed like a very interesting situation for an attorney to be in, based on everything that I read about the case. There were no cameras in the courtroom, but what was his reaction when the verdict came down?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Hi, Brian. His reaction was pretty stoic, as it has been kind of through the entire case. So I don't know that it was necessarily unexpected. He certainly wanted to go a different way. But when the verdict came down, I think he was accepting of what his fate was.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So Justin's, and we covered this on Friday, his mother, sister, brother, they all had these victim impact statements. They wanted him to go away for life, his own family. Did that surprise him? I mean, or did that upset him?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: No, actually not at all. I don't think it was unexpected. I mean, based on what it was that he did, what he admitted to doing, and his reasons for doing it, which were found to not be justified. But ultimately, I think he expected the response that he got from his family. And as he sat there, and he took the verdict, and he listened to what it was that they had to say, he was offered the chance to express some sort of remorse. And he was not interested in that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Does he have any kind of contact with him at all anymore? No, he's not permitted to. He's not permitted to, okay. We were surprised when he took the stand in his own defense. You know, somewhat rare during a murder trial. What were your, in a way it kind of felt like he was going rogue. What were your thoughts on that? I mean, is that something that you guys talked about? Did you advise him to do it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, I don't know that he went rogue. Justin was afforded the defense that he wanted. Sometimes the defense that you assert, and in fact, pretty much all the time when you assert a defense, it's the defense that you want. And oftentimes you may not listen to the advice that you're given, but that's the defense that he gave.  was the one that he wanted. I was appointed to represent Justin. I advised Justin on the possible defenses that were available to him, obviously, as I would any client. And the defense that he chose was exactly the one that he wanted, and that's what he went with. So when he got on the stand, I don't think anybody who was familiar with the case heard anything  that hadn't already been said by him, whether it was to the detectives in the case, the numerous people that he wrote letters to, letters that he wrote to the court, or things that he said out loud to the news media.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Why no insanity plea? Because the judge brought it up several times. Is that something that you discussed with him at all?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I absolutely would discuss every defense that was available. And the defense that was asserted by Justin was the defense that he chose. Brian, he was given the opportunity. They assessed his competency. He was found to be competent. And when you're found to be competent,  there's only so much that can be done to try to assert a defense that's outside of what that person actually wants. And the defense that he wanted, and if you had listened to any of what it was he was trying to present, was that he was effectuating a citizen's arrest, and that, unfortunately, he says, unfortunately, his father resisted that arrest. And he believed, at least the defense that he wanted to assert, was that he could use deadly force against that resistance.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And the judge listened to the facts and disagreed with that.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Attorney Steven Jones provides insights into his client Justin Moen's behaviour and defence. He explains that Moen was stoic throughout the case, expected the guilty verdict and harsh sentencing, including from his family. Jones reveals that Moen chose to take the stand in his defence, asserting a citizen's arrest defence, despite Jones's advice. He also notes that they discussed all available defences, including insanity, but Moen rejected it. Jones emphasises that Moen was given the defence he wanted, even if it meant ignoring legal advice.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The interviewer, Brian, questions Jones about Moen's reaction to the verdict and sentencing, his family's victim impact statements, and Moen's decision to take the stand. He expresses surprise at Moen's lack of remorse and his choice of defence. Brian also inquires about the absence of an insanity plea and why Moen chose to assert a citizen's arrest defence, which the judge ultimately rejected.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the high-profile murder case of Justin Moen, where he was convicted of killing his father and sentenced to two life sentences. His attorney, Steven Jones, explains Moen's stoic reaction to the verdict, his lack of remorse, and the reasons behind his chosen defence strategy.

video_title: President Trump backs Ukraine with weapons, threatens Russia with tariffs

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And let's bring into the conversation now National Security Analyst and expert and retired Marine Intelligence Officer Hal Kemper. Hal joins me. Hal, you have guided our viewers each and every day almost throughout this entire conflict. Yet another iteration here. What pieces of military equipment now are going to Ukraine? What's the U.S. sending here, Hal?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, Andrew, of course the big one is the one they talk about. That's kind of the bumper sticker one, which is the Patriot missiles, something desperately needed. Uh, as we've seen, uh, Ukraine, particularly key, but other cities, Western Ukraine as well, have just been inundated with drones and these missiles to include these hypersonic missiles, Russia's firing. They have been firing missiles at a rate never seen before in the three years of the war. And it almost seems like Putin has been pursuing this mad moment, if you will,  of sending as many of these things as possible. And they're not all aimed at military targets, primarily hitting civilian targets, things like that. Other things that are on the order going out are what they call defensive weapons. Now, there's a lot of interpretation on what that can mean, but artillery rounds  certainly are well in there and you know I would mention we've sent about 3 million artillery rounds over to Ukraine during the course of war so that's something they desperately need. Certain types of HIMARS may be on the list, I think they are. There are some, there's a version  of a new missile that we have that can be fired through the HIMARS system. We haven't even sent that to our closest allies in NATO yet, but that's something Ukraine has asked for. It has about a 500 kilometer range. If that thing gets released, that's a significant shift in US policy. But basically all the things that you would expect, and mostly ammunition type stuff. I haven't heard of major end items, except for I did hear there might be a battery  which is a complete system for launching Patriot missiles that may go intact over to Ukraine very soon. So that is a significant asset that would be shifted over there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So Hal, I have to ask because the president says the Europeans are paying for all of this, that they're putting the bill completely. How so?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, it's kind of an interesting arrangement. Um, uh, European NATO allies, and it looks like it's a country to country thing more than NATO. I'm not sure if NATO is going to set up a separate set, a central fund to do this, but Germany is definitely in Finland, uh, Norway, Denmark. I've heard of a few other countries that are in, that are paying, that will be paying for buying those weapons from the U S now the question, uh, comes to my mind is what will we charge?  It might be we charge a very discount rate for this purpose as well. That's very possible. There is a lot of latitude on what we can charge for weapons, and certainly if it's something we have in the inventory, what we can charge. But this is actually kind of going back to something we've heard from President Trump and those around him for quite some time, is that the European countries need to start pulling their weight and providing more support for NATO.  What this does is it addresses a defense industrial base shortfall within Europe. I'm not saying the U.S. is healthy in this regard. We have a lot of work to do to rebuild our defense industrial base, but Europe is much further behind us. So they're not in a position where they can suddenly start producing weapons at the rate to support Ukraine with what Ukraine needs. So now it's okay. They can't produce them in Europe, but they can pay for them in Europe and get them from the U.S.  And it keeps that pipeline going.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: OK, so I just want to follow up on this. Obviously, a lot of this drawdowns from the entire duration of the war have been congressionally authorized and approved here. So we're essentially still paying for a kind of right or no. Do I have that right? I'm trying to make sense of it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: As far as I know, we're still paying for some weapons. And I think I'm not entirely sure. I was trying to kind of suss that out today to figure out if that was the case.  it looks like some of the Patriot missiles that were going in may have been from the congressionally authorized stuff. That's been drawing down. There's not a lot of that fun left, but there still was some of that fun left. So some of those weapons, particularly the Patriot missiles, are from that. Now, the thing they just announced, this is new.  This will be on top of whatever that is. And I will say the Europeans have been stepping up really fast. In fact, I saw an estimate some weeks back that said they'd actually filled the gap in terms of contribution towards buying weapons for Ukraine that the U.S. used to fill.  And so that was pretty big. But this actually addresses that other problem, which is how do you get the weapons? And again, it goes back to the ability of these NATO European countries to produce weapons that Ukraine needs. And particularly the fact is, you know, a Patriot missile, there's only one place you get a Patriot missile. That's from the U.S. All right. That's our missile. So they have to get that. If they want to put missiles and missile and Patriot batteries, they've got to get the missiles from the U.S.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Now let's talk about the kind of other threat here that was posed today, and that's the tariff threat. I want to just read from the Associated Press. Trump said he would implement severe tariffs unless a peace deal is reached within 50 days. Do tariffs scare Putin? We've been talking about this issue here in the newsroom amongst ourselves, and I was posing the question, do we even do enough business with Russia for tariffs to have any material impact?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's not, well, the tariffs are not on us per se. It's not our tariffs. The issue is secondary tariffs on countries that do business with Russia. That's China and India. That's really, they're the countries that buy a lot of oil and gas still.  very dependent on oil gas, well, somewhat dependent on oil gas from Russia. They've been getting it at a discount. It's been helping their economies because they're able to buy this cheap Russian oil. Of course, it's dangerous for the whole world because the Russians ship it in these, what they call shadow tankers, these dilapidated old tankers that are not particularly seaworthy. And they're running around the world with their automated identification systems turned off because they don't want anybody to know that they're  extremely dangerous for maritime commerce. Basically, what this would do is potentially shut that whole thing down, and that would cause a massive crunch in revenue going to Russia. Russia is, to use the late Senator John McCain's expression, is basically a big gas station. They are a petrostate.  And they are running out of places they can sell their oil. And this makes them run out of pretty much every place that they can sell their oil. So that's part of it. The other thing is, I would mention a former prime minister of Russia, Mikhail Khrushchev today, actually came out and talked about the Russian economy. And he said the Russian economy could kind of basically stall out by the end of the year. So these two things juxtaposed against each other. And he says, hey, Putin knows this.  These two things juxtaposed put a lot of pressure on Putin.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The expert explains that the U.S. is sending Patriot missiles, artillery rounds, and possibly a new HIMARS missile with a 500km range. He notes that European NATO allies are now paying for the weapons from the U.S., addressing Europe's defence industrial base shortfall. The expert also discusses the potential impact of Trump's proposed severe tariffs on Russia, emphasising that they would target secondary tariffs on countries like China and India, significantly reducing Russia's oil revenue.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host asks questions about the U.S. military aid to Ukraine, focussing on the Patriot missiles and other defensive weapons. He also inquires about the funding source, clarifying if the Europeans are paying for all of it, and how the congressional authorisations for drawdowns work.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the latest U.S. military aid package to Ukraine, the financing mechanism behind it, and the potential impact of new tariff threats on Russia.

video_title: Former President Joe Biden defends his use of an autopen at the end of his term, NYT reports

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And welcome back here to Live Now from Fox. I'm Andrew Kraft. Let's go back there to the White House. Like I said before the break, I want to dive into this interview former President Joe Biden gave to The New York Times. Over the weekend, Biden saying he had orally granted all the pardons and commutations issued at the end of his term  calling President Trump and other Republicans quote-unquote liars for claiming his aides had used an auto pen to do so without his authorization. Fox News correspondent Madeline Rivera has more details.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Former President Biden breaking his silence over his use of an auto pen device to issue pardons at the end of his time in office. President Trump and Republicans have jumped on it as a major scandal, saying it raises serious questions about who was in charge at the Biden White House.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I guarantee he knew nothing about what he was signing.  I guarantee it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: President Biden firing back at his critics over the weekend in an interview with the New York Times, saying he used an auto pen to sign the clemency warrants because there were so many of them, but that he, quote, made every decision. In response to Republicans questioning his mental sharpness, Biden said they're liars. They know it.  The former president says pardons of his staff and members of his family were meant to protect them from politically motivated prosecutions by the Trump administration. Some of his former staffers have been coming to his defense. Of course it makes no sense that he would physically sign 4,000 documents. What's important here is that he says, I made the decisions. What he's saying is the auto pen just executed those actions.  Last week, the former president's doctor testified on Capitol Hill in a deposition to the House Oversight Committee, but his answers didn't shed much light after he pleaded the fifth to nearly every question.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I think that this adds more fuel to the fire, that there was a cover-up.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: This week, former First Lady Jill Biden's senior advisor, Anthony Bernal, is expected to appear before the House Oversight Committee for a closed deposition. In Washington, Madeline Rivera, Fox News.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Madeline, thanks so much. All right, let's talk about this story with our friends there at 24 Sight, Tom LoBianco, and at the Washington Examiner, Kalyn Deese. You guys, thanks for being with us here. Hope you had a good weekend. I guess, Tom, I'll start with you. For our viewers, what's an auto pen? What is that? Is that just a DC thing or something else?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's one of the great wonders of the Trump era of American politics is how deep in the weeds we get with American history. I was actually just reading up on this and a very nice piece from NPR. Apparently it's used for, if you think about signing thousands of documents, it's a, it is a,  automatic machine which writes in ink and it's used by, it has been used by presidents before, it's been used by, you know, university presidents, administrators and whatnot. Typically it's going back years and years and years, decades past. LBJ says Carter and Nixon have used it before. And I should note as a good Marylander, it is a Maryland, it's made by a Maryland company.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: of  commutations and pardons over the course of that four years. The most of any president and our viewers can fact check me there, but I looked that up here, but this was an interview in the New York times. Kalen Biden said that he had his staff use an auto pen for the warrants because he had granted clemency to so many people. The auto pen was used in all on 25 pardon and commutation warrants from last December to this January.  Some of the individual warrants included large batches of names because they all fell into the same broad policy category, like reducing the sentences of nonviolent drug offenders who met the standards Biden had established here. So how is this all going down? What is the reaction? This is in lieu of Biden taking a pen and signing these things with his own hand, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Right. And I think that if you ask most people, especially Republicans on the Hill, they would probably ask you the question, why would Biden even go out and tell the New York Times, give him a 10 minute interview to talk to him about all of this. But I would say that it really shows a lot of confidence over there from the Biden camp that they think that they had a well  a thorough created formula to use the auto pen to the point where they're trying to posture as not necessarily as nervous as some Republicans might think they would be, especially in the weeks that we've been going through this investigation. Now, I do think that where they are opening themselves up for a little bit of trouble is the fact that we've basically been given a window into this very convoluted system in which aides would be basically passing information  from one aid to another to the point where there's basically, you know, this multifaceted, you know, group of people that are, you know, finally getting this to the to the to the final stages for, you know, signing the the auto pen. So I think that they're leaving themselves open, at least in part from the political side, where  As Republicans like James Comer are going through these interviews in the coming days, especially with Anthony Bernal, they're going to be able to ask them questions, especially related to the way that, say, Chief of Staff Zients was basically signing off on the use of the auto pen and how there were basically lower aides that were creating blurbs sort of as the justification for using the auto pen. It creates a system in which now the Republican investigators are going to be asking them direct questions.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: questions about this.  According to the New York Times, these clemency warrants that were reviewed by the Times show that the Biden White House had a process to establish Biden had orally made decisions in meetings before the staff secretary, her name, Stephanie Feldman, who managed use of the auto pen, would have clemency records put through the signing device here. So, Tom, do you think I have that right politically speaking that Biden wanted to explain, wanted to clarify, wanted to get out ahead of this story?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Feels that way. I mean, as we've noted before, certainly uncharacteristic of how he was during the campaign, his re-election bid, when he was in the White House, he certainly didn't call reporters on cell phones. So, yeah, I mean, I don't know it directly myself, but I suspect there's, you know,  a realization that they probably need to talk about this. I mean, you know, as as time stories go to, you know, props to the New York Times for getting that. It's incredibly detailed. You know, Cailin noted this a second ago. I mean, my God, this is arcane.  This is the type of thing I'd look to put into a book, you know, to pad out a few pages. All right. So, but, you know, it's important. All right. It's these are, you know, yes, the nonviolent offenders. But if you look at the universe of pardons and, you know, what Republicans have gone after Biden and continue to go after Biden for, it's the bigger names. It's Hunter Biden. It's Anthony Fauci.  So, obviously incredibly important, perhaps meriting this, you know, where we are right now, down in the weeds with, you know, notes and whatever, oral blurbs from the secretary to the council, to the president, you know, whatever.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: A live picture there at the White House. And so I have to ask this, because I was struck by the fact that, you know, Biden is taking the time to call the New York Times, to your point, Tom, something that I was seeing on X over the weekend. He never did. During the four years that he was in the White House, he never had a one-on-one interview  with the New York Times. I was struck by that here. But, and Kaelin, to you, and maybe this is a charitable explanation, but this is logistically speaking the use of an auto pen to save a president time, right? Is that too charitable of an explanation?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No, I think precisely that's the point of an auto pins use. And that's why the system in which they created for using the auto pin really doesn't make sense as far as getting things done. I mean, it's almost as if, you know, you know, you could say this was a system that you could ask LLM or chat GPT to sort of, you know, Hey, I'm going to give you a list of names and make sure it fits in with this criteria. It's like,  I mean, I guess you could argue that the way that it was working with the aides, they were trying to make sure that all of these names that were pardoned, some of them very violent offenders, fit in with this criteria. But it makes a lot of people puzzled whenever they see that something that's supposed to be for the use of ease.  being made so convoluted. And I'll say this as a point to sort of move it forward a little bit. It's very odd that we're getting this information from the New York Times about all of these emails and discourse that was happening. Whenever the House Oversight Committee has been investigating all of these former Biden aides, we haven't, at least as far as what they've intimated from their discussions, we haven't seen anything  as far as these conversations go. And the New York Times says that there's thousands more. So I find it very interesting that the house investigators didn't cut to the chase on this part yet. And I think that it'll be very likely moving forward that those investigators will try to get access to some of those NARA archive emails in order to sort of press this issue even more so. I can't help but think that they're going to focus their attention next  on looking at some more of these emails that the New York Times didn't even talk about.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah. You know, Tom, let's do big picture here. We're nearing the one year mark since Biden withdrew from the 2024 election. That was July the 21st, 2024 here. That's in a matter of several days. You know, is it valid to ask the question now in the wake of all of these kind of tell all books  about what Biden's mental acuity was at the time in the last two years of his one-year term, about whether or not he was up to the job, about whether or not he actually could have if he were to have stayed in the race and won the election, served four more years as president here. Those questions are connected to the conversation we're having right now. That's the entire reason we're talking about the auto pen, right, Tom?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And you know, one of the co-authors on that piece is Tyler Pager, who is a co-author of the newest 2024 recap out great book by Tyler and Josh Dalsey and Isaac Arnstorf.  which just published, and again, to the point of how Biden and the Biden White House operated, part of the reason that we're hearing about this is because they weren't engaging at all. I mean, they weren't engaging before on these books, really left it to, again, just a repeated problem for the Democrats, left it open to Trump and the Republicans to craft the narrative.  But yeah, it's I mean, that is really the centerpiece of so many of these recaps of what happened last year. And, you know, if you if you boil it down here, depending on where you sit on the political spectrum, if you know if you are a Democrat and you think  Our friend Chris Alyssa has pointed this out very well. There's kind of mutual outrage from the partisans here. If you're a Democrat, one of the reasons you get so angry about this is the idea that his infirmity and the cover up of that infirmity is what ultimately put Trump in the White House, that debate performance, which we were covering at the time. That is what led to it. And if you're a Republican,  in a Trump MAGA base, you know, that the anger comes from this, you know, that there, you know, there was a cover up, there might be something more sinister at play. But it really,  Not a lot of Biden fans out there right now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So, Kaelin, I want to follow up on that question I asked Tom. Because we've been talking about, and Tom gave us examples, other presidents have used auto pens. But the reason we're talking about Biden's use of the auto pen is because it's directly connected and linked to the questions about his mental acuity, his alleged physical and mental senility while in office here. That's where Republicans are taking this, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, Republicans think that there must have been something deeper to the fact that he was using an auto pen, especially as it ramped up, as we're now getting more clear confirmation of in his final months in office. And something that's very interesting is that Biden's use of the auto pen stems far back into the early days of his presidency, whenever he was signing proclamations at first. It really wasn't until, I believe, the first year of his presidency, I believe on a trip to Israel where he used the auto pen  kind of as it is usually intended for, which is to sign legislation while you're away from the office. But as it turns out, we began to see later into Biden's presidency, there were days whenever he was even at the White House,  where he was having the auto pen being signed. That's according to information that's been obtained and released from the Oversight Project, formerly part of the Heritage Foundation, but they uncovered on at least seven different occasions. There were times whenever Biden was working at the Oval Office, but he still had things signed with auto pen. Therein lies where Republicans start to get suspicious because they think to themselves, kind of like we were just mentioning before, if it's supposed to be something that is convenient and for ease,  Well, one can make also an argument that it's just as easy to use your own hand to sign a signature on something, especially if you're at work that day. So I think that that's where people start, especially Republicans, start to look at the issue and wonder to themselves, was there something else happening here? Were there more aides that were doing this, perhaps unbeknownst to the president? And I think that that's where, especially Republicans like, say in Comer's camp,  want to see the Justice Department look into this as well. And I'll say this, you know, last week, whenever we saw Biden's doctor plead the fifth, there was a bit of a discussion about whether I remember Mike Lee, Senator Mike Lee from Utah was asking, why don't we just give Biden's doctor immunity if he's going to plead the fifth?  Well, I think that there is an equal interest in seeing that no immunization is given to anyone who's interviewed in this process because the Justice Department probe is that serious and they don't want to foreclose any opportunities to perhaps bring them to a grand jury if that ever gets to that point.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: OK, you know, Tom, just lastly here on this question, because a lot of people, especially Democrats,  over the weekend were essentially saying, you know, why would former President Biden step on this major, major internecine war going on in MAGA over Jeffrey Epstein? Why would he do that? Why would he kind of step on that news cycle and generate his own here about the auto pen? But is it valid to ask, you know, to Kaylin's point, you know, to bring some of these staffers,  especially Stephanie Feldman, who was responsible for the deployment, the use of the auto pen to just explain, either in closed or open door settings, whether or not she or other staffers were doing this without the president's authorization. Biden says they weren't, but we deserve to know that question. What if they were? Right, Tom?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I mean, yeah, I mean, it's a big story if you have rogue staff out there operating. I mean, that, you know, we have that right now, too. I mean, we have Hegseth, you know, talking out of school. And then we have Trump announcing today that we're sending missiles to Ukraine. Right, we just did a segment on that. You know, again, that's the reason it's a big deal when you have  people talking out of school like they shouldn't and making decisions if that happened. I mean, yeah, if a junior staffer was the one that pardoned Anthony Fauci, I guarantee you that would be a huge story if that happened. I don't know. We don't know.  It's a big if. It's a huge if. It's, I mean, you know, tack it on to the Epstein thing. You know, we could be talking about this six years from now, right? We could be looking at the pruder film of auto pens.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Kaelin, lastly here, where does this go now? What will you be following on the auto pen question?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Oh, well, you know, I think that in Kalen, I'm sorry, I want to step on you there. I'll make this real quick. What the house Republicans do with it. And I'll be, I'll be reading the examiner certainly to see how this goes. Um, you know, you know, again, it's up to see. And then also, as he noted what the justice department does with it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah, I think definitely all eyes should be trained on where, especially the interviews with specifically Jeff Zients go. I know that there's going to be also some interviews in the future with Andrew Bates, who is very key to the White House, Ian Sams, people like that. I mean, the House Republicans seem to believe that these interviews are gonna be way more important  perhaps even more so now that this information is out there from the New York Times and they have some fuel to go with whenever they want to ask these questions. And I think that, like I said earlier, these NARA emails, records, are going to be important going forward as well.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right. Kaitlin Deese, Tom LoBianco, always good to see you guys. Talk soon. Have a good night. Thanks. Okay. In the meantime here, I just want to round out the hour with yet another major story we were especially

She highlights the Republican accusations of a cover-up and the upcoming House Oversight Committee depositions, noting that the White House has a process for orally approving clemency decisions before using the auto-pen.

He also steers the conversation towards the upcoming interviews with Biden aides and the potential consequences for the Biden administration.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The analyst explains the White House’s process for using the auto-pen and notes that Republicans are using this issue to question Biden’s leadership and mental sharpness. She also discusses the political strategy behind Biden’s interview with The New York Times and the potential for further investigations by House Republicans, emphasising the importance of upcoming interviews and NARA emails.
summary.SPEAKER_03: The analyst provides context on the historical use of auto-pens by presidents and suggests that Biden’s decision to clarify his use indicates confidence in their process. He also discusses the political motivations behind the Republican scrutiny and notes the broader implications for perceptions of Biden’s mental acuity and leadership.
summary.SPEAKER_04: This speaker is a Republican critic who suggests that Biden did not know what he was signing and implies a cover-up within the Biden White House.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses former President Biden’s use of an auto-pen to sign 25 pardon and commutation warrants. Biden defended his use, stating he made all decisions orally, but Republicans criticised this as raising questions about his mental sharpness and suggesting a cover-up. The discussion also touches on the political implications and the upcoming House Oversight Committee interviews with Biden aides.

video_title: Top Story with Tom Llamas - July 14 | NBC News NOW

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Tonight, flames tearing through an assisted living facility, killing at least nine residents. People hanging out of their windows, screaming for help. The intense rescues as fast spreading flames trap seniors. Smoke filling the facility. We hear from those who thought they wouldn't make it out alive.  Also tonight, a private plane with a family on board crashing into a Florida neighborhood, narrowly avoiding homes. Neighbors rushing in to help those trapped in the wreckage. Out West, dangerous wildfires exploding near the Grand Canyon in nearby Utah. Video capturing a firenado. Plus, the renewed storm threat for flood ravaged Texas. And at this hour, a new risk for flash floods along the East Coast.  President Trump's new ultimatum to Russia. Trump threatening new secondary tariffs and plans to rearm Ukraine. lines.text: Next thing that we knew was the police coming five in the morning just saying, you know, you little girl is not going to come home anymore.
