video_title: Jon Ossoff Torches Trump Admin. For Canceling Grant 'Because The Project Had The Word Justice In It'

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Do you all know Thomasville, Georgia? Thomas County, just a few miles from the Florida line, small, rural. Thomasville's never gotten much love from Washington. There's short healthcare options, the infrastructure's old. So a couple years back, we allocated federal funds to help them build a new health clinic and upgrade their sewers. The health clinics and sewers didn't used to be controversial.  But then out of nowhere, the Trump administration canceled the grant for Thomas Fitts. Y'all know why? First, because the project had the word justice in it. And justice is now a forbidden word in Washington.  And second, because a tiny amount of the grant was for electric lawnmowers to maintain the new facilities. And electric vehicles, which were supposed to be Georgia's economic future, are now considered woke. So no more health clinic, no more sewer upgrades for Thomasville. See, they're all trapped in this right-wing internet ideology.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker highlights the allocation of federal funds to Thomasville, Georgia for a health clinic and sewer upgrades. The grant was cancelled due to the inclusion of the word "justice" and the allocation of funds for electric lawnmowers, which were deemed "woke" by the Trump administration.
summary.high_level_summary: The speaker discusses the politicisation of federal funding in a small town and how ideological biases led to the cancellation of a crucial grant.

video_title: 'Aren't You Proud About What The Coast Guard Just Did?': Kristi Noem Praises TX Flooding Response

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I'm also very proud of the fact that I have the supervisory authority over the U.S. Coast Guard. Aren't you proud about what the U.S. Coast Guard just did in Texas to help those individuals?  Texas just went through an incredible tragedy with the flooding event that happened and is still looking for their loved ones and for children and have been absolutely devastated. And the individuals who showed up there from the Coast Guard, from Border Patrol, those individuals from the BORTAC teams, from FEMA that showed up immediately and supported that state in its response to its individuals, I'm so proud of them because for the very first time, we acted in a way that disaster response should.  You know, the way statute lays out is that every emergency that happens in this country should be locally executed. That means the people that are closest to that emergency need to be the ones making the decisions to respond to people. It should be state-managed, which means the state makes the decisions on how they're going to universally handle this disaster. And the federal government, our role should be to support. We should be there to support. We shouldn't be making the decisions  We should be sending the support that is necessary to get that state through that situation and that's exactly how we implemented it in Texas and are continuing to do so to support Texas as it gets through this. And at the exact same time New Mexico was flooding, North Carolina had  some flooding events going on, and we continue to stand on watch to make sure that we're there to support people across this country. Regardless if you're Republican, Democrat, independent, if you love freedom and if you love this country, we are going to be there for you to help support you and get you through the most challenging days of your lives. Now, I'm here tonight, and I'm not going to talk much longer. I guess it says I have 19 minutes. I'm not going to talk that long.  But what I do want to talk to you about is that you guys are the future. People will tell you throughout life that there are things that will determine what you're going to be. They will tell you that the family that you're raised in, or the city that you're in, or the community is, is going to impact your future. I would disagree with that. People will tell you many times that your education will determine who you're going to be and what you will be. It'll open up doors for you and create new opportunities. I would say that I disagree with that.  Our Department of Homeland Security interacts with all of those areas. It interacts with even the jobs that you're going to have. The one thing I want to remind all of you here today, and one of the important reasons why I think that you should recognize that you are here, is because what still makes the world move, what still will determine your success in life, is relationships, is the people that you meet, the people that you spend time with, the people that you talk to,  I would encourage you to continue to stay involved, to go out there and to come to conferences like this, meet people, go shake hands. You never know when the next person that you meet may be your next mentor that will give you the greatest advice that turned your life around, that changed everything for you.  The next person you meet may be the person that gives you a reference for your next internship, or your first job position that you get, or maybe the scholarship that you need to get the degree that you want. Maybe you will meet somebody when you show up for an opportunity when that door is open that will be your next business partner. Don't leave this conference without recognizing that the most valuable thing that you gained here was the relationships that you built, the people that you talked to, and the people that you were with.  I've got a team around me and staff with me that every single day help me do the job that I do. And I'm so proud of them.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The speaker highlights the successful federal disaster response strategy in recent flooding events across the US, emphasising the support role of the federal government while allowing local and state authorities to take the lead. They underscore the unity and non-partisan nature of this assistance.
summary.high_level_summary: The speech covers disaster response in the US and the importance of relationships. The speaker praises the federal government's support role in recent flooding events in Texas, New Mexico, and North Carolina, emphasising local and state execution with federal backing. The speech then shifts focus to the value of personal connections and relationships in determining success, overshadowing factors like family, education, and location.

video_title: 'I'm Not Happy': Donald Trump Slams Russian Attacks On Ukraine, Threatens Tariffs

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: The only one we haven't been able to get to yet is Russia. And I'm not happy. And I will tell you that Ukraine wants to do something. Again, it's a war that should have never started. If I were president, it never would have happened. I used to speak to President Putin about it a lot. It was the apple of his eye.  But once I saw what was going on, I said, you know, they're going to — they're going to have a war here. I was outside. Election was rigged. And I was outside looking in, and I said, you know, that thing is going to be a war. Couldn't believe it. Because what Biden said was the exact opposite of what should have been said. And it started. And it's a real mess. We're losing — I guess they're losing 5,000 or 6,000.  people a day. It's actually now more. I used to — I was saying 5,000 a day. It's actually more now. Mostly soldiers, but a lot of people in cities and towns that are getting blown up, too. It's a horrible war. And it should be stopped. And so, if it's not done, if we don't have an agreement in 50 days, that's what we're doing — secondary tariffs. And they're biting. And I hope we don't get to the point where we do. But I've been hearing so much talk — it's all talk —  So I'll talk, and then missiles go into Kiev and kill 60 people. It's got to stop. It's got to stop. But the purpose of this is to say that this is a very big deal we've made. This is billions of dollars' worth of military equipment is going to be purchased from the United States, going to NATO, et cetera. And that's going to be quickly distributed to  the battlefield, Ukraine will take it up. And, you know, say what you want about Ukraine. When the war started, they had no chance. And they still would have had no chance if the equipment they used — they had the best equipment. Because we do make the best planes and missiles, and we make the best military equipment in the world, by far.  And we have new things coming out that are beyond belief. And I'm very excited about the Golden Dome. It's going to give us very strong protection. We're already started that. But they had courage, because somebody has to use that equipment. And they fought with tremendous courage, and they continue to fight with tremendous courage. But they don't have — they're losing on equipment. And Russia has really taken a very positive — very, very  strong, I mean, what they've done the last couple of weeks.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Without military needs, that's what they're doing. 700 drones a day, missiles, bombing cities. This is not because of military goals. It is just creating panic, keeping people out of their sleeps, hitting towns. It's really terrible. And it is meaning a lot of people lose their lives, but also the infrastructure, whole cities being  They're wiping out the electric.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's going to take years to rebuild it. That's going to be the next problem. But that's going to take a long time. Many of the cities are knocked down to the ground. Many of the people have left. But many have stayed. I don't know if they actually stay. Most have stayed, actually. It's incredible that they stay, knowing that a missile could be hitting your apartment house, and your apartment house that you're sitting in could collapse on top of you.  And they do very heavy construction. They don't use rebar. They do very thick concrete construction. Those are heavy buildings. Big buildings and heavy buildings. And they collapse like they're made out of paper. It's unbelievable to see this happening with people — so many people being killed. So we think we're going to make progress, and we hope we're going to make progress. In the meantime, we're going to get you good service on what you need.  And we really became friendly with NATO this last meeting. You know, we went from 2 percent to 5 percent, which everyone said was not even a possibility. They weren't paying 2 percent. Many of them were paying much less than 2 percent.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: But even those, since you became President, all committed to the 2 percent before the summit. And now, collectively, they committed to the 5 percent.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: That's right. They did. They've been very good. And I think I made a lot of friends over there. We had a couple of days of very intensive talks.  And they're great people. They're leaders of countries. Leaders of countries. Many of them, great countries. Some of them, smaller countries. But for the most part, I'd say very solid, strong countries and very successful. Some of them are among the most successful countries in the world.  That's the story. We hope that's going to have an impact on Vladimir Putin, and we hope it's going to have an impact on Ukraine also. We want to make sure that Ukraine does what they have to do. All of a sudden, they have — they may feel emboldened, or maybe they don't want — you know, this is a very  Difficult situation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Ukraine wants a peace deal. I think so. And they will stay committed to that, there's no doubt. They want it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But the Russians have to become- They have to continue to want it, though.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, I agree. We will- you and I will make sure of that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All of a sudden, they're getting all these- You and I will make sure of that. We'll- we'll make sure. I feel confident that they will do what has to be done. Plus, we have certain parameters that both sides know. And we already know what- what should be done. So I think that's going to be- it's going to be very strong. We want everlasting peace.

summary.SPEAKER_00: SPEAKER_00 focuses on the humanitarian impact of the Russia-Ukraine war, describing Russian attacks as indiscriminate and targeting civilians and infrastructure. They emphasise the widespread panic, destruction, and loss of life caused by these attacks. SPEAKER_00 underscores Ukraine's desire for a peace deal and their commitment to achieving it. They agree with SPEAKER_01 on the need for a peaceful resolution to the conflict.
summary.SPEAKER_01: SPEAKER_01 is critical of the Russia-Ukraine war, stating it should have never started. They express frustration with the ongoing violence and loss of life, emphasising the need for Russia to stop the war. SPEAKER_01 highlights the significant military aid being provided to Ukraine by the U.S. and NATO, noting the superiority of American military equipment. They propose imposing secondary tariffs on Russia if the war continues within 50 days. SPEAKER_01 also acknowledges the courage of the Ukrainian people and their military efforts. Additionally, they mention the progress made in NATO commitments, with members increasing their defence spending to 5% of GDP.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the Russia-Ukraine war, U.S. military aid to Ukraine, and NATO relations. SPEAKER_01 emphasises the need for Russia to stop the war, highlights the humanitarian crisis, and announces billions of dollars worth of military equipment to be purchased from the U.S. by NATO for Ukraine. They also mention the potential imposition of secondary tariffs on Russia if the war doesn't end within 50 days. SPEAKER_00 underscores the indiscriminate nature of Russian attacks, targeting civilians and infrastructure, causing widespread panic and devastation. They emphasise Ukraine's desire for a peace deal and their commitment to it. Both speakers agree on the importance of finding a peaceful resolution and express confidence in achieving it.

video_title: Mark Rutte And Donald Trump Announce New Munitions To Be Shipped To NATO

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Germany, where they're going to send early-on missiles. And they'll be replaced, and NATO is going to take care of it. It's going to be coordinated by NATO, and they're going to work very much with Matt Whitaker, who's right here. He's a great ambassador. And Matt is going to be coordinating. You better do a good job, Matt. I will. But Matt is going to coordinate. He's a very talented guy. He's going to coordinate everything.  So, in a nutshell, we're going to make top-of-the-line weapons, and they'll be sent to NATO. NATO may choose to have certain of them sent to other countries where we can get a little additional speed, where the country will  release something, and it'll be mostly in the form of a replacement. And I'd like to have Mark. And again, just a highly respected, pretty young guy. Pretty young guy for having had the career that he's had. He had an amazing career before going to NATO. So we spent a lot of time together over the last couple of months. And if you could say a few words. Absolutely.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: No, no, Mr. President, dear Donald, this is really big.  This is really big. You called me on Thursday that you had taken a decision. And the decision is that you want Ukraine what it needs to have to maintain, to be able to defend itself against Russia, but you do want Europeans to pay for it, which is totally logical. And this is building on the tremendous success of the NATO summit, the 5 percent.  but also the decision to keep Ukraine strong and the decision to increase our defence industrial production. So based on that, this is – that was Europe stepping up. This is, again, Europeans stepping up. So I've been in contact with many countries. I can tell you that at this moment Germany massively, but also Finland and Denmark and Sweden and Norway, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Canada, they all want to be part of this. And this is only the first wave. There will be more.  So what we will do is work through the NATO systems to make sure that we know what Ukrainians need so that we can make packages. Of course, in a way, we discussed it this morning, as Pete Hecht said, at the Pentagon, in a way that, of course, the U.S. will be on its stockpiles necessary to defend this country. That's absolutely clear. But it will mean that Ukraine can get its hands on, really,  massive numbers of military equipment, both for air defense, but also missiles, ammunition, et cetera, et cetera. So if I was Vladimir Putin today and hear you speaking about what you are planning to do in 50 days and this announcement, I would reconsider whether I should not take negotiations about Ukraine more seriously than I was doing at the moment, if I was Vladimir Putin. But when I'm Ukraine, I think this is really great news for them. So I really want to thank you for that. And it means the European is paying for it.  And again, I mentioned all these countries, we will deal with that. And exactly as you said, it might also mean that countries will move equipment fast into Ukraine and then the U.S. later backfilling it because speed is of the essence here. So really, thank you. This is important.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The U.S. will manufacture top-of-the-line weapons and send them to NATO. NATO will coordinate the distribution of these weapons to Ukraine and other countries. Matt Whitaker will be instrumental in this coordination. The U.S. aims to ensure speed and efficiency in the process.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Europe will pay for the military aid to Ukraine, building on the success of the NATO summit. Several European countries, including Germany, Finland, Denmark, Sweden, Norway, the UK, the Netherlands, and Canada, have expressed willingness to participate. The aid will include air defence, missiles, and ammunition. The speaker emphasises the significance of this announcement for Ukraine and urges Putin to reconsider negotiations.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses NATO's coordinated effort to provide military aid to Ukraine, with the U.S. manufacturing weapons and NATO members, particularly Europe, funding and supplying the equipment.

video_title: Watters: Dems liked cages when they built them

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Donald Trump was in the VIP box this weekend for the biggest soccer final in the world. The championship match was in New Jersey yesterday, and 47 brought Melania for a day date. The Brits upset the French 3-0. And the president wasn't going to miss out on the celebration, so he showed up to the trophy lift like he owned the team.  Trump liked the trophy so much that he took it home with him. They said, could you hold this trophy for a little while? We put it in the Oval Office. And then I said, when are you going to pick up the trophy?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: He says, we're never going to pick it up. You can have it forever in the Oval Office. We're making a new one. And they actually made a new one. So that was quite exciting.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: It's 24 karat gold. And you know, Trump loves his gold. Plus, it looks better in the oval anyway.  Trump lifted the gold on the anniversary of dodging death. Same day, same hour. Since then, he's been a man on a mission. When history looks back on this time in our country, when history looks back on you, how would you like to be remembered? A good person, but a person that saved our country. I really believed our country was going down for the fall. I don't know if it ever could have come back. It was very close to the edge.  The country was teetering because Biden let the whole third world pour in for four years. Trump stopped the flooding and now he's sending them home. And the one thing that brought America to its knees is the one thing Democrats are still fighting for.  Instead of enjoying the gold, Democrats are fanning the flames and letting their assassination fetish get the best of them. A couple of ICE agents got doxxed in Portland this weekend, and radicals showed up outside their doors and told them to go die.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

lines.text: This is why they wear masks. Wingnuts tried raining on Homan's parade too, but Tom didn't let him go without a spanking. Wait, Dwight, three or five years. Pardon me? Are you an MS-13 member? Hey, hey, that's okay. That's okay. Bring it! Bring it! You got morons like this all over the country.  This guy, this guy wouldn't know what it's like to serve his nation.

lines.text: This guy ain't got the balls to be an ICE officer. He hasn't got the balls to be a border patrol agent. This guy lives in his mother's basement. Get out of here, you loser.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Homan has to live separately from his wife because of the threats he gets from guys like this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: This is what they brought us yesterday.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: That is what they met us with yesterday. That is what they shot at us with yesterday.

Instead, the media is trying to unmask the victims. Name a police agency that has a 700% increase in assaults. Name one. I haven't looked at that data, yeah.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You won't find one. The attacks on ISIS on President Obama, 700% increase. And we're not even talking about the doxing of agents, their spouses and their children.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So they're wearing masks to help give them some sort of protection.  But the same people are complaining about ICE wearing masks. Have they ever said anything about BLM protesters wearing masks? Democrats are protecting the privacy of BLM, Kifa, Antifa, and MS-13, but not ICE. This weekend, Trump actually opened the big, beautiful doors to alligator Alcatraz and let Congress come in for a quick little look-see. lines.text: They are essentially packed into cages, wall-to-wall humans, 32 detainees per cage. The only thing inside those cages are their bunk beds, and there are three tiny toilets. They essentially drink.  They get their drinking water and they brush their teeth where they poop in the same unit.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Everybody brushes their teeth where they poop, Debbie. It's called a bathroom. She's probably talking about these sink toilet units that every prison in America has. The migrant criminals are getting treated the same way as American criminals. And Debbie's angry that they're not being treated better.  And how does Debbie think we should be detaining criminal aliens if we don't use cages? And are these even really cages? It's like any fence you see anywhere. She doesn't like the super max in El Salvador. She doesn't want to keep them in jails and sanctuary cities. And alligator Alcatraz isn't nice enough. It seems like defense attorney Debbie wants MS-13 to stay in Times Square hotels for eternity.  This is just a temporary facility that these guys stay at for a few weeks before they get shipped home.  It is a center to process illegal aliens and then to provide a pad to deport them from the runway that's right there. We did not create the four seasons. That's not the intent of this. All the standards are a lot higher than what was even required. But that's, you know, really beside the point. If they're not serving margaritas at Alligator Alcatraz and every unit doesn't have marble vanities and Toto toilets, Democrats call it a dungeon.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: The reality is, when they come for one of us, they're eventually going to come for all of us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: And we've seen the construction of Alcatraz, alligator Alcatraz. We're seeing people being abducted and sent to dungeons in foreign countries.  Omar and Debbie never lamented the living conditions of government housing projects, or living conditions in Appalachia, or my dorm room, which was very small. They only complain about Alligator, Alcatraz, and Guantanamo Bay. They make sure the foreign terrorists are comfortable and they have everything they need. The Democrats complained so much during the war on terror, you remember? We were letting Al-Qaeda play soccer and video games.  These are some of the dudes at Alligator Alcatraz that Debbie and Omar don't want to fence around. One MS-13 gangbanger is nicknamed Satan. He's wanted for being in a murder ring. We have Biden migrants with convictions for sexual assault, robbery, arson. One guy in Alligator Alcatraz was arrested for slicing an elderly woman's throat. lines.text: What do you say to these lawmakers who argue this is not humane treatment of individuals, of humans?

lines.text: Democrats have called them cages, though.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I wish they would have said that back during the Biden administration and back when Democrats were in the White House and they were piling people on top of each other on cement floors.

Democrats, they don't want them in cages. They just want them out there working in the fields. Over 300 illegals, some of them minors, got iced at a pot farm in California. lines.text: They are literally driving down the street, jumping out of unmarked cars, tinted windows, no license plates, and literally snatching people from bus stops, going into car washes. It's difficult to get your car washed in LA now because many of the car washes have closed down.

lines.text: Who's going to wax Karen's Corolla if Jose gets iced? We don't know. We didn't really believe car washes were vacant, so we called five L.A. car washes today, and they all picked up and told us to come right in. lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But we also are going to have a re-institution of the Angeleno card, something that Mayor Garcetti started during COVID that will actually provide cash assistance to people. Because, you know, you have people who don't want to leave their homes, who are not going to work, and they are in need of cash. It's a couple hundred dollars, I don't know the exact amount, and this should be available in about a week.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Bass wants to mail reparations to migrants.  L.A. is still in debt from the riots and losing all that homeless money, billions. And whole neighborhoods are still burnt down. Are the illegals getting checks faster than Americans who've lost their homes? Seems like it. It's been six months, and they haven't even started rebuilding Malibu. The no-name California senator who lunged at Noem says he can't leave his house either, because if he goes to Home Depot, Homan's sending him to Alcatraz.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: What if I was outside a Home Depot, because I like to do some work around the house, not dressed in a suit. Would I be a target of ICE enforcement under Tom Holman? Probably. And it's just wrong. It's not just due process rights that have become the concern, but racial profiling.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Is Karen going to send Senators stimmy checks if they're afraid to leave their homes too?  Mark Cuban says Democrats could at least help Homan a little.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: They should be putting Tom Homan on blast, saying, OK, the FBI has their top 10 most wanted list, right? List the top 1,000 criminals that are here that need to be deported. We'll all help you. But the Democrats would never say something to the effect, we'll help you.  They only have to do something that's the antithesis of what Trump says and does. lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Democrats still haven't figured it out. Most of the country wants alligator Alcatraz and mass deportations. The Times, ABC, CBS, all their polls say a majority of Americans back it.  But if Democrats are going to keep trying to move them into five-star resorts, this country is going to put them in the dungeon, an electoral dungeon. Additionally, SPEAKER_04 makes comments about various political figures, including Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Ilhan Omar, and Karen Bass, often in a derogatory manner. video_title: FALLOUT following Trump's defense of Bondi amid Epstein files

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Correspondent David Spahn is at the Justice Department tonight.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: President Trump, over the weekend, trying to rein in negative headlines by telling millions on social media to support Attorney General Pam Bondi. He posted, what's going on with my boys, and in some cases, gals? They're all going after Attorney General Pam Bondi, who is doing a fantastic job. We're on one team, MAGA, and I don't like what's happening. Trump invited Bondi to sit near him at the FIFA soccer game on Sunday in New Jersey, a sign of public support.  Fox has told Deputy FBI Director Dan Bongino came to work on Monday after not showing up on Friday. Fox News confirmed a yelling match between Bongino and Bondi in front of top White House aides last Wednesday. President Trump says he spoke with Bongino yesterday.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Very good guy, and he sounded terrific, actually. No, I think he's in good shape.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: The Justice Department released the Epstein memo last week that insisted not only was Epstein's death a suicide, but there is no client list. Trump's supporters, many online influencers in the MAGA community, have directly blamed A.G. Bondi for over-promising and under-delivering.  Some even calling for her to resign or be fired. Bongina was said to be furious with the backlash from the memo, despite multiple sources saying he approved it. FBI Director Kash Patel looking to keep the peace, posting, the conspiracy theories just aren't true, never have been. It's an honor to serve the President of the United States, and I'll continue to do so for as long as he calls on me.  As for Attorney General Bondi, she is continuing to move forward. On Friday, Brett, she fired 20 employees at the Justice Department with ties to former special counsel Jack Smith, who was involved in the prosecution of then former President Donald Trump during those two federal investigations.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Right. David Spahn at the Justice Department. David, thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Reports internal conflict at the Justice Department. President Trump supports Bondi amid backlash from MAGA supporters over the Epstein memo. Trump spoke with Bongino, who was reportedly upset with the backlash against Bondi but approved the memo. FBI Director Patel denied conspiracy theories. Bondi fired 20 employees with ties to former special counsel Jack Smith.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Reports on the developments at the Justice Department. He confirms Bongino's return to work after an absence and mentions the yelling match between Bongino and Bondi. He also notes Bondi's decision to fire 20 employees.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses internal strife within the Trump administration and the Justice Department surrounding Attorney General Pam Bondi, Deputy FBI Director Dan Bongino, and the release of the Epstein memo.

video_title: Leavitt SLAMS Dems: 'Completely lost their minds’

Is the administration going to celebrate it in some way?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, with President Trump, we work hard every day, and we are going to continue to work hard to deliver on all of the campaign promises that he made to the American public. But it surely has been an extraordinary six-month start to the four years that President Trump has been blessed with  back in the Oval Office. And let's go back to one year ago yesterday, where God saved the life of President Trump so he could save this country and return to this city where so much change is needed. And look at what he has done with the border. You just laid it out, Sean, the most secure border in our nation's history. A president who has the backs of our law enforcement officers every day  Those law enforcement officers who are watching your show right now, who put their uniform on to protect our fellow Americans, to make our communities safer, this president supports you, and he loves you. Look at our economy. It is booming again, thanks to the pro-growth, less regulatory policies of this administration. And we just signed, President Trump just signed the most significant piece of tax legislation in American history, the largest tax cut.  For working and middle class families, that means more money directly into the pockets of every single American watching your show tonight. You look at what he's done to root out DEI and waste, fraud and abuse in our federal government to keep men out of women's sports. Victory upon victory. We had another one.  with the Supreme Court today handing another big victory to not just the Trump administration, but more importantly, parents and students and families across the country. The Supreme Court saying that, yes, Secretary of Education Lyndon McMahon can move forward with the president's promise to dismantle the Department of Education, return education back to parents, back to states, so we can have the best, brightest, most highly educated students in the world.  win after win every day. We will continue to work hard. And I just want to say to your audience, there is not a more hardworking president than Donald J. Trump. I witness it with my own two eyes every day. That man is working around the clock. He hardly ever sleeps. He's constantly thinking about not just the problems in our country here, but around this world and how to solve them. And look at what he's done on the world stage with bringing peace to the Middle East,  withdrawing Russia and Ukraine to actually talk directly for the first time in this war in years. We see what's happening with the hostages coming out of Gaza, and he's going to keep pushing until every last hostage is out. This is a president who is a peacemaker-in-chief, and it cannot be overstated how successful the first six months of this administration have been, thanks to the leadership of President Trump.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Caroline, let me read a headline from the Washington Examiner. Trump's tariffs deregulation give June its first budget surplus in 20 years. Wow. That's not gotten a lot of attention.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: No, it hasn't. And all of the naysayers, all of the so-called economic experts who doubted this president and his economic formula are now eating their words. In fact, there was a story on the cover of the Wall Street Journal today saying that those fears of recession that everyone was ranting and raving about have now cooled because the economy and everyone from Wall Street to Main Street understands this is a president who is a businessman and he knows what he's doing.  pro-growth, higher wages, less inflation, less taxes, and more money back in people's pockets. And look at the investments that have poured into our country. We have companies all over the world who are coming to build factories and create jobs with American hands and American labor right here in the United States of America. This is the best country on the planet to do business in. And that's something President Trump  promised the American worker. I was with him on the campaign. I know you covered it, Sean. When he traversed this country and promised the American worker, he was going to stand up for them. And his economic agenda has surely done that. And all of the so-called experts, they have been proven wrong. The president knows what he's doing. He wants to bring growth back to this country.  He wants to end the Bidenflation crisis, and he already has in just six months. There's more work to do. He will continue to do it. But he has a proven economic formula that works. Just look at the success of his first term as president.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Let me ask you about the 700 percent increase of attacks on ICE agents. Add to that the doxing of ICE agents and their families. And then you have the L.A. mayor, Karen Bass, announcing a new cash giveaway plan for Biden illegals. How is it possible that you're going to give away free money to illegals? And in New York state, they're talking about hiring attorneys for illegals. And then you have sanctuary state and city policies. How is any of this not against the law? How is it not aiding and abetting lawbreaking?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: The Democrats have completely lost their minds, and they have forgotten the number one reason they lost the election in an overwhelming fashion on November 5th. video_title: How rent control laws 'hurt' housing

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It is official, former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo releasing a video on X minutes ago saying he is back in the race for New York City mayor. He will run as an independent candidate after getting crushed in the Democratic primary by Democratic Socialist Zoran Mamdani. Mamdani, who won the primary with a decisive 12-point victory, champions a citywide rent freeze on rent-stabilized units.  a call that has rattled landlords, real estate interests and even some economists ahead of November's mayoral election. Jeff Green is a self-made billionaire real estate entrepreneur with holdings in New York, Palm Beach and all around the country. He first experienced rent control while attending Harvard Business School when he purchased a home in Somerville, Massachusetts. Because if I recall right, Jeff, you couldn't afford the dorms. So you bought a kind of a rundown building. You thought, oh, maybe I'll just  by the building and it was really cheap and then you found that you were dealing with rent stabilization, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, no, it wasn't that I couldn't afford the dorm but I didn't get into the good apartment complex so I bought a three-decker to live in and at the time the city of Somerville  we've had rent control. And it was actually voted out while we were there, which is a very brave move for the alderman. Remember, when I was at Harvard Business School, I took a course at the Kennedy School, and I wrote a paper on rent control in 1978. And I had looked at all kinds of research that had shown that rent control laws absolutely do nothing but hurt housing and housing prices and rents. And it's almost 50 years later, we're still talking about doing this, coming up with using this, which we know is ineffective.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Tell me and tell our viewers why rent freezes don't work. Because let's just say I am one of the many people, because the voters spoke in this primary, who can't afford to live in New York, or they're really, really stressed by the high rent payments, who say, well, wait a minute. Rent freeze sounds good. I should be able to have a decent job and pay my rent. Explain why it works in the reverse.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I mean, look, you were talking about making mortgage payments with Ancor in your last segment. I'm sure you'd love to have your mortgage frozen the rest of your life. I mean, I'd like to have my mortgage payment frozen, my insurance payment frozen. Everyone would rather have all their expenses frozen.  But the reality is that right now we have a New York City and a lot of cities in the country have housing shortages. So how do you solve a housing shortage is by creating more housing. You're not going to create more housing by making it so unappealing to developers to build housing. And that's what's exactly what's happened in New York. I have three projects in New York. We have one in Hudson Square, which is kind of just between Tribeca and West Village.  We have a waiting list there. Every time we get a notice for someone to move out, there's another tenant paying higher rent lined up for that apartment. What is that saying to me? It's saying there's a huge housing shortage in New York City. We need, so, look, I'm all in favor. We're a wealthy country. If somebody has a hardship, they're elderly, they're disabled, and they can't afford housing, as a country, we should offer that subsidies. And that's why we have Section 8 programs for people who legitimately, hopefully legitimately,  have hardships. But to just freeze rents across the board all you're doing is completely discouraging any investor or developer from investing in markets that are desperate to get new housing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Who would you consider financially backing? You are not a New York resident, obviously, but you have properties here. Cuomo just announced via a thing on X, a video on X, that he's in. There's Mayor Eric Adams, who is also running as an independent because he didn't win the Democratic primary. And it's almost like the Hunger Games at this point.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, look, I mean, they're both better choices. I mean, I get what Mondami is doing. I mean, he's trying to appeal to people by giving away something free. I'm going to freeze your rent if you vote for me. And the most voters, you know, would rather have frozen rents. Who wouldn't want their rent frozen? I understand. But policymakers should not be doing these cheap programs, which is really take advantage of  of the desperation and how scared people are about their rents. Because what you're really doing is you're going to cause their kids aren't going to ever be able to afford to live in New York. Because who's going to build a new building when these cities just keep freezing rents and keep taking away the income of those who are invested in this city?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: What is the number one thing that you wish you could see from New York City and the government here that would inspire more building?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, it's very simple. How do you get more building? Zoning is one thing. You know, if you increase, if you give people zoning incentives to get, you know, more housing, if you are on a lot, you know, maybe higher, higher, higher areas, ratios, higher density. Look, in the state of Florida, we have a workforce program now where the state actually has gone in and overridden every city zoning law.  and said that if you build 40% of more workforce housing in any city in Florida, you can build the highest height allowed within a mile of the building, unless it's next to a residential neighborhood, the highest height. And the double, one and a half times the highest floor area ratio.  And so what they're saying is, we want workforce housing. We want affordable housing in Florida. So we're going to make it so appealing to real estate developers and investors that we're going to give them a chance to make some money. The other side of that is, there's no property tax at all on that 40% of workforce housing. So they've made it so appealing, you're going to see even more housing built in Florida. New York has to start thinking the same way. Otherwise,  Everyone in New York is going to move to Florida, which is great for someone like me, who's a big investor there, but pretty tough in New York.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Jeff, it's good to see you. And you have real world experience with all of these situations. So we really appreciate it. Thank you for coming on.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer introduces the topic of Andrew Cuomo entering the New York City mayoral race as an independent. They ask Jeff Green about his views on rent freezes, highlighting the appeal of rent freezes to voters struggling with high rent payments but also the potential concerns raised by landlords and economists. The interviewer also probes Green about his financial backing for the mayoral candidates and his suggestions for inspiring more building in New York City.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Jeff Green opposes rent freezes, citing his research and personal experience with rent control in Somerville, Massachusetts. He argues that rent freezes create housing shortages by discouraging developers from investing in new housing projects. Green believes that to address the housing shortage, cities should create more housing supply through incentives like zoning changes and tax breaks. He suggests that providing subsidies for individuals with hardships is a more targeted approach to addressing affordability issues than freezing rents across the board.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the potential impact of a citywide rent freeze in New York City proposed by the Democratic Socialist candidate Zoran Mamdani. The interviewer speaks with Jeff Green, a billionaire real estate entrepreneur, who argues against rent freezes based on his personal experiences and economic research.

video_title: America cannot become healthy again without the cooperation of US industry, says RFK Jr.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: I spoke a few little bit ago with Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and Secretary of Health and Human Services Robert Kennedy Jr. on how to make America healthy again. Please take a listen.  All right, it's a big news day, but not only international and foreign policy in Ukraine and Russia, but also on the health side, very important. And joining me now, Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Thanks to both of you. I appreciate it very, very much.  Mr. Kennedy, Secretary Kennedy, you'll be doing everybody a great favor. We will owe you a real debt of gratitude if you can get these petroleum-based dyes or other dyes out of the kids' diets, out of the schoolchildren's diets, and actually out of the adult diets, too. Can you do it, sir?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, and you know, Larry, when we came in six months ago and we said we're going to get rid of the nine petroleum-based synthetic dyes that are in our food that cause ADHD, that are associated with cancers and all kinds of a grim inventory of other health injuries, people laughed and they said we'd never be able to do it. But what happened today, which is the dairy industry has now made a commitment  to get rid of all dyes by the end of 2026. And some of them are already taking action. Some of them have already gotten rid of the dyes. We now have, with this contribution, with this commitment, we now have about 40 percent of the food industry that's already made that commitment. And 35 percent of the food industry was already, had already gotten rid of the dyes.  We're very proud of this public-private partnership. I'm very grateful for our partnership with Brooke and with our partnership with the industry. We cannot make America healthy again.  without the cooperation of the American farmers and American industry. And they are stepping up to the plate. And we're very grateful to them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And, you know, Mr. Kennedy, I was listening to Marty McCary last night, your FDA commissioner, obviously, talk about why it is that these kids now, kids growing up, are in such lousy health.  And it has so much to do with what they're being fed. And this dye business, petroleum-based dye, even in ice cream, I got to tell you, I didn't know it was in ice cream until I read up on what you all were saying. I mean, it's really quite remarkable, but there's got to be an urgency to it, a real urgency to it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: There's urgency and, you know, FDA also is stepping up to the plate. We've already approved Fast-Track and approved in the last two months three new vegetable-based dyes. Today, we approved a new vegetable-based dye, Blue Dye.  You know, we're going to make sure that these companies and this industry has the supply chains so that they're able to get the products that they need to continue to meet the needs of their consumers, but in a way that keeps our children healthy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: And Madam Secretary, Brookie Rollins, my dear friend, it's up to you, I guess, to implement this with respect to what food stamps and school lunches and other things.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, that's right. And listen, this partnership we talk about a lot is unprecedented, never before in American history. Do you have an HHS secretary who is just simpatico? We talk almost daily, working together to make America healthy again. Bobby Kennedy understands more than anyone that you can't do that without American agriculture and the American farmer. Our announcement today outside on USDA steps, but to your point, Larry, USDA spends $400 million every single day on our nutrition programs, SNAP,  I mean, this is a market mover in terms of what weíre feeding America. So being able to ensure that our farmers, especially some of our smaller farmers, have the market in which to sell their locally homegrown produce, but also working with the big  dairy producers, the ice cream makers, all of the above, to get the healthiest, best choices out into America. But especially as you're talking about, Larry, you know, three out of our four kids couldn't pass the military readiness test today. Something has to change. And Secretary Kennedy is leading the way, and we here at USDA are here to support him in every way we can.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So just to make it clear, I mean,  Can you get waivers and or change legislation, or was anything in the one big beautiful bill that would stop this? You know, food stamps, SNAP, school lunches, et cetera, et cetera. You know, you're the Lord High Executioner. He's the information guy on this. You're the Lord High Executioner. Can you execute this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I have to say I have never been called the Lord High Executioner before, Larry, but I love you so much. Listen, to your point, yes, USDA, and we have been working with some of our best governors across the country, Arkansas, Indiana,  Iowa, Idaho, Tennessee, et cetera, et cetera, to get the waivers put into place so that taxpayer dollars through SNAP are no longer buying sugary drinks and junk food, which is what a lot of the populations that rely on these food stamps, that was the number one purchase within the food stamp program was sugary drinks, $13 billion of about $110 billion program. That is unsustainable.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Secretary Kennedy, just on a related matter, but somewhat distant.  The former president of Harvard University, Larry Summers, who was Treasury Secretary under Bill Clinton—I'm sure you know Summers—Secretary under Bill Clinton, when they moved, they had great reforms on welfare. They moved from welfare to workfare. He's out there saying in The New York Times and elsewhere that the Medicaid reforms, the eligibility reforms for able-bodied, will cause 100,000 people to die.  I mean, I think that's an outrageous, outrageous claim, Secretary Kennedy. What's your take on that? Can you fight back on that?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: First of all, there's no cuts on Medicaid. There is a, there's a diminishment of the growth rate of Medicaid, which is bankrupting our country. And by the way,  The national debt is also a determinant, a social determinant of health. If we're leaving our kids with these giant debts, they can't afford health care. They can't afford good food. In 1996, when Larry Summers was working for President Clinton,  they put in the TRAMP program, they put in a work requirement, and it was regarded as one of the most successful poverty diminishment programs in the entire Clinton administration. Oh, you know, in recent years, Obamacare included, Medicaid was designed, Larry, for people who were poor, for children, for mothers,  And it was expanded during the Obamacare to include able-bodied Americans, and the growth rate went way up. The hospital services and doctor services are no longer available for the target population.  This is not a good outcome, and we're bankrupting the states. It's the biggest expense for all of our states. They're all going bankrupt. We've got to do something to fix it. And luckily, we have a president who's willing to do that. We're not going to cut Medicaid, and there's nobody who's going to die from this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think Summers has a very bad case of amnesia, and I'm glad you pointed out the fiscal side of it. Madam Secretary, last one to you. Have you figured out a solution to the immigrant workers, the illegal immigrant workers in the travel industry, the hotel industry, meatpacking, farm? What's going to happen here, Brookie?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Well, the President has been unequivocal in, A, his support of no amnesty, mass deportation. If you've broken the law, you've broken the law, while at the same time saying we have to do everything we can to protect our farmers and our farm workers. Secretary Lori Chavez de Rimmer, one of our colleagues from the Cabinet who is really, really great, has opened up an Office of Immigration Policy over at Labor. She is really looking to solve this very, very quickly.  Ultimately, we have to move to a 100 percent American workforce. Now, a lot of this, Larry, I think you can appreciate, can be solved through automation. We are looking at that very closely and working with a lot of our great farmers around the country, but also ensuring we have got so many job openings in America. It actually may even go back to what Secretary Kennedy was talking about, the able-bodied men and women in America who are not working today. Now, will they be filling all of the farm openings? No, probably not.  But this idea of dignity of work, Larry, you and I talked about a lot in the first Trump term. It's time to return to that theme and that great righteous vision of every man and woman in America having a job and having the ability to provide for their families. So there are a lot of solutions on the table, and we're moving forward.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right. Secretary Kennedy, we appreciate it very much, sir. Secretary Rollins, we appreciate it very, very much. We'll talk some more on all this. Thank you for coming on.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you, Larry.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Secretary Brooke Rollins underscores the importance of public-private partnerships in achieving health goals. She highlights the USDA's role in implementing changes through nutrition programs like SNAP and school lunches. Secretary Rollins discusses working with farmers and states to obtain waivers and ensure healthier food options are available. She also addresses the issue of illegal immigrant workers in agriculture, emphasising the need for a 100% American workforce while exploring solutions like automation and leveraging able-bodied American workers.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. emphasises the harmful effects of petroleum-based dyes in food, particularly on children's health. He highlights the industry's commitment to removing these dyes by 2026 and the FDA's approval of vegetable-based dyes as alternatives. Secretary Kennedy also defends Medicaid reforms, stating they aim to control growth rates without cuts, and emphasises the fiscal responsibility of such measures.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The host (possibly Larry Elder) expresses support for the administration's efforts to remove artificial dyes from food and emphasises the urgency of the issue. He also discusses the broader implications of food quality on public health, particularly among children. The host questions the implementation of these changes in programs like SNAP and school lunches. He also touches on Medicaid reforms, criticising claims that they will lead to significant health harm, and brings up the topic of illegal immigrant workers in various industries, seeking solutions that protect farmers while upholding the law.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the administration's efforts to improve public health through dietary changes and regulatory reforms. They focus on removing petroleum-based dyes from food, promoting vegetable-based alternatives, and utilising public-private partnerships to achieve these goals. The conversation also touches on broader health-related issues like Medicaid reforms, immigration policies affecting the agricultural industry, and the importance of a dignified workforce.

video_title: The Hill: 7/14/2025

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: All right. Hello. Good evening. Thanks for being with us tonight. I'm Blake Berman. This is The Hill on NewsNation. He's not an assassin, but he's a tough guy. That from President Trump today, as he has now put Vladimir Putin on the clock.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Disappointed in President Putin because I thought we would have had a deal two months ago, but it doesn't seem to get there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So based on that, we're going to be doing secondary tariffs if we don't have a deal in 50 days. It's very simple. Coming up here on The Hill tonight, we will show you how the president is now helping to arm Ukraine. Plus...  Pardon me? President Biden doubles down on his use of the auto pen from the Oval Office. How his own son was different and what President Trump is saying now. Also tonight, it is, it's the bipartisan issue potentially in this town. Certainly not much more above it. Confronting China. We'll show you how the US is taking on its adversary and doing so underground. And down in Florida, lawmakers take a tour of alligator Alcatraz.  the detention center there. How at least one governor tonight is saying that his state could be next. But first tonight here from the Hill, a decision that's being celebrated abroad by many on the left and stirring a little bit of frustration in the president's own base. The commander-in-chief announcing from the Oval Office today, next to the head of NATO, that the U.S. is sending quote, top of the line  weapons to ukraine now trump emphasizing that nato not the united states will be the one to pick up the tab it is a far cry from the verbal throwdown with the ukrainian leader vladimir zelensky just four months ago in that very same room and comes as the president suggests that putin is leading him on and just three weeks after his trip overseas to nato we begin tonight here on the hill with our kelly meyer live at the white house with the very latest that kelly  Yeah, hey there, Blake. And I was just thinking back to when I was in the Oval Office just a few months ago, back in May, when I asked the President, you know, Putin keeps attacking Ukraine, but you're saying that you trust him. And at that time he said, well, this is a war. And now he seems to be shifting his tone on this and really saying he's not happy.  with Russia.  giving Putin 50 days to make a peace deal, otherwise face severe sanctions. Today, he threatened 100% secondary tariffs on Russia, which would impact those countries that trade with Russia. It is much less than the 500% tariffs that a bipartisan group of senators are pushing for on Capitol Hill. President Trump says, though, with Putin, it's all talk. Take a listen.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I go home, I tell the first lady, and I spoke to Vladimir today. We had a wonderful conversation. She said, oh, really?  Another city was just here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Now, a White House official tells me not to read too much into the first lady weighing in, that she's not pushing him to put the pressure on Putin. And another Ukrainian official I spoke to today says he's worried about that 50-day deadline, that it leaves room for Putin to really do whatever he wants. We heard drone strikes were continuing today. Blake? Kelly Meyer, live tonight on the North Lawn. Kelly, thank you. So during that meeting today with the NATO chief, President Trump emphasizing throughout that the United States will not be covering the cost.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We made a deal today where we are going to be sending them weapons and they're going to be paying for them. The United States will not be having any payment made.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We're not buying it, but we will manufacture it and they're going to be paying for it.  Now, here are some of the weapons that could be heading toward Ukraine that the U.S. would manufacture. The Patriot missile interceptors, precision-guided rockets, Hellfire missiles, howitzers as well. Now, the war with Russia and Ukraine has been going on for more than three years, 1,230 days.  The U.S. has spent about $67 million, roughly, as of April in assistance to Ukraine. Some of the military aid that we have sent includes three Patriot air defense batteries and munitions, more than 200 howitzers with more than 3 million artillery rounds, and more than 10,000 Javelin anti-armor systems.  With me now, the Democratic Congressman from Massachusetts, Seth Moulton, member of the House Armed Services Committee, former Marine as well, as I always like to note. Congressman, thanks for being with us tonight here on the Hill. You're a Democrat.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good to see you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You as well. You're a Democrat. Are you going to tell me tonight that you think the President got this one right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: yes and it doesn't matter whether you're a democrat or republican when it comes to opposing war criminal vladimir putin and his criminal war it's just taken this long for donald trump to figure out that he's actually a bad guy and he's been playing him like a fiddle so you think he's been played by two  Of course he is. I mean, since when have we had a United States president on either side of the aisle stand up and repeat Kremlin talking points about the war? This is Donald Trump who said that Zelensky started the war, not Putin who invaded, that this was Ukraine's fault, that Putin is not a war criminal. I mean, he has just been lying to the world and to the American public, including his MAGA base, about what's going on there. It's nice to see him finally following in Biden's footsteps.  and actually supporting the Ukrainian freedom fighters who are defending their democracy.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I'm going to get to the base and Sean Spicer here in a second, but you mentioned the President, former President Joe Biden. It's not like he was able to end this. Not like he was able to. He wasn't, right? Joe Biden wasn't. Donald Trump certainly hasn't been able to. So how do you think that the Commander-in-Chief is able to hopefully get this thing settled?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, look, it's a hard question, and you're absolutely right that the Biden administration wasn't able to end this war. Sitting on the Armed Services Committee, one of the discussions that we always had, especially behind the scenes in classified settings with the Biden administration, was, okay, we understand that we support your policy, and this is Republicans saying this too, we want to help Ukraine, but what is the plan to win?  How are we actually going to win this war? And let's be honest, the Biden administration did not help Ukraine win. They helped Ukraine survive. But when I asked that question of Trump administration officials, I mean, it was deers in the headlight, because they're clearly not getting any direction from the president, or at least they haven't been up until this point, to ensure that Ukraine wins. And why does that matter? Because it sends a message to the rest of the world  that if you're a dictator like Putin or like Xi Jinping in China, you don't get to just start wars because you like to. That's an important message for America and our democratic partners around the world to send to murderous regimes everywhere. And it's good to hear that's finally, it seems to be at least, what Trump is saying as well now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You do think that the president wants Ukraine to win, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: We certainly haven't thought that when he's repeating Kremlin talking points, when he's blaming Ukraine for the war, when he's disparaging Zelensky. So do you think that's an open-ended question though, I guess is what I'm getting at. No, I don't think people think that.  I think it's still an open-ended question because just because Donald Trump is saying the right thing in the last 24 hours, it doesn't make the last six months go away. But listen, I'm happy with where Trump is today. He seems to make decisions based on politics, not on principle. Even when you just heard him talking about this, he wasn't talking about the principles of democracies overcoming murderous dictators.  he was just talking about who pays the bill, like as if this is some deal not involving lives of innocent people. But let's stick with Trump when he's saying the right things, and hopefully he'll continue.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I'll leave it there. Congressman Seth Moulton with us tonight here on the Hill. Thank you, sir. I know we'll talk again soon. Appreciate it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good to see you. You too.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Joining me now, Sean Spicer, NewsNation contributor, former Trump White House press secretary, host of the Sean Spicer Show podcast. Sean, nice to have you in. Happy Monday. Good to see you. There's the open question there. First off, let me start here. What do you take issue with what you heard there from the congressman?  Well, there's a lot to take issue with. Look, I will give Seth Moulton a smidge of credit for finally acknowledging that Donald Trump's doing the right thing in the interests of this country. I think he's always been seeking that. However, where Congressman Moulton continues to be wrong, and it's no surprise considering his track record, is that this isn't following in the steps of Joe Biden. Joe Biden begrudgingly gave Ukraine defensive weapons.  There was never an attempt to actually win. The only reason that Russia invaded Ukraine was because of Joe Biden's feckless leadership. When Joe Biden took us out of Afghanistan so horribly, Putin saw that as a green light. But more importantly, what Donald Trump did today, Blake, and this is where I think I'm so proud of how he does things versus how the past has happened. It was just like Iran. Everyone said you had to go in full on, boots on the ground, or you had to stay out. Donald Trump showed us a third way. Today, what did he show us?  showed us that we can get Ukraine the supplies that they want, but we as Americans don't need to be footing the bill every time. But there's a question, Sean, but there's also a question of how he's handled this, right? And I want to get your reaction because I thought this was pretty revealing. Here was what the president said today about Vladimir Putin and whether or not he's an assassin, and then there was more, and I'll get your reaction.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I don't want to say he's an assassin, but he's a tough guy. It's been proven over the years. He's fooled a lot of people. He fooled Bush. He fooled a lot of people. He fooled Clinton, Bush, Obama, Biden. He didn't fool me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But what I do say is that at a certain point, you know, ultimately talk doesn't talk.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's got to be action. And it leads to the question, Sean, if the president was actually fooled by trying to go the route of talking and negotiating first.  OK, so two things. Number one, I want to go back to my previous point, and then I'll get to it. I don't think that we can overstate how significant today was. This idea that America has always had to foot the bill for everybody else's issues, right? Europe needs to step up for its own national defenses. The same thing that he did in NATO he did today, which is show us a new way, a way that America can actually help its allies, but at the same time, not have to foot the bill for everybody's backyard issue. That's what he showed us today. To your point,  Look, all that one needs to do is read Trump's books, The Art of the Deal, The Art of the Comeback. Look at how he has dealt and negotiated his entire life. He talks very openly about this. You can't get a deal if you kick somebody in the face. You can't get a deal if you malign them. He has tried to talk to Putin to say, hey, look,  I want to end the war. He's the only one who for 40 years actually had peace, right? He understands that you can't have the same thing happen over and over again as Joe Biden did and expect a different outcome. So he tried to do what he could with Putin to have a conversation. He made it clear today. Talk is done. I'm going to take action. But I give him credit for trying to find a new and better way to achieve peace and not have the American taxpayer continue to foot the bill every single time Europe has a problem.  You give him credit, and I hear you. There's also questions, Sean, as you know, with the base and what the president is doing or is not doing. I'll give you a couple highlights here. Marjorie Taylor Greene, quote, we do not want to give or sell weapons to Ukraine or be involved in any foreign wars or continue the never-ending flow of foreign aid, end quote. And then this also comes as parts of the right are not happy  with how jeffrey epstein and and that case has been handled here was laura trump earlier today and i'll get your reaction i believe that there will probably be more coming on this and i believe anything that they are people to release that doesn't you know damage any witnesses or anyone underage or anything like that uh... i really don't probably try to get out sooner rather than later to everybody out there is all worked up about it there's no still a great plot to try and keep this information away that i'm aware of  What damage has been done with the base, Sean? Well, it's to be seen. But I think the problem that they face is that they handed out, the Attorney General handed out a series of binders earlier that purported to show that there was, and then said, coming soon, there's going to be more. And so they set a level of expectations that people rightly thought would be met, and they didn't.  So I get it, and I think Laura Trump is articulating probably where they are right now, which is to figure out how do we explain this. We set the bar. The Attorney General said that there was more information. And I think people on the right, who has expected transparency, were led to believe that there'd be more to the situation. I think Laura's right. They're probably trying to figure out what can we release to show what's there. But look, at the end of the day, as somebody who has known Donald Trump for 10 years, been there at the beginning,  What he is doing on the MAHA front, on tax cuts, on the big beautiful bill, on foreign policy, he is enacting not just one or two signature things, but entirely pushing the movement forward and getting things done in each of the respective areas. I give him a lot of credit. I think we hold him to a high standard because we've expected so much of Donald Trump. But we've got to remember that this is a guy who's not giving us excuses, but results.  I do think it's fair to point out that the first six months and what's happened, you can say has been successful for the president, Sean. And in the last week, there have been a lot of questions from those who support him louder than anyone else who are wondering.  what's going on here in this moment.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And he has to address it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But again, can I have one quick point?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Sure, real quick, and then I got to run.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: One last thing. Again, I think on the Epstein thing, I get it. But respectfully, I think that he found a brand new way. U.S. contractors are going to make a product. They'll profit from them. And NATO will pay the bill. That, to me, is literally the definition of America first. He showed it in Iran. He showed it again today. This is a president who's showing us that there is a better way to conduct foreign and domestic policy and deliver results for the American people. And I'm very proud of what he's done.  I'll leave it there with you. Sean Spicer with us tonight. Thanks, Sean. Talk to you again soon. You bet. Of course. All right. Still to come tonight here on The Hill. Alligator Alcatraz. Are there going to be more of those popping up all across the country? What one governor's office is telling NewsNation tonight. Plus, China flexes its power in the Pacific. How its military is entering new territory.  and the response that is seemingly coming from this country underground. And former President Obama telling Democrats to, quote, toughen up. Is he right? Thank you for being with us tonight. We still got a long way to go. 45 minutes. I'll be back on the other side in four. I'm Blake Berman. See you then.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I wouldn't call them jail cells. I would call them a facility where they are held and that are secure facilities, but are held to the highest levels of what the federal government requires for detention facilities.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: The Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem addressing the conditions at Alligator Alcatraz, the migrant detention center in the Florida Everglades, which is now facing criticism, especially from Democrats.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: The conditions that we saw inside this internment camp, which it is nothing less than that description, were really appalling. They are essentially packed into cages, wall-to-wall humans, 32 detainees per cage.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Now, despite the pushback, Secretary Noem is now looking at other states for similar facilities. It comes as ICE continues to conduct raids across the country. And the White House press secretary, Caroline Leavitt, touting their work with a list of arrests that she put out on social media today, writing, quote, while you were enjoying your weekend, the brave men and women of ICE were removing violent, criminal, illegal aliens from our communities.  With me now, the California Democratic Congressman Ami Bera, member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, once again with us tonight here on the Hill. Thanks for being with us. I hear the DHS Secretary say that these Alligator Alcatraz, the facility there, is at the highest levels of standards there. If that's the case, Congressman, if you take them at their word, at face value, would you be for more of those going forward?  Well, what I'd say is if that is the case, they ought to invite you in there, Blake, to take a look and see what the high standards are. I look forward to talking to my colleagues from Florida, getting a sense of what they saw when they were in there. My gut sense is that these are substandard conditions, that folks are just herded into really unsanitary conditions. Again, I haven't seen it for my own eyes, but I do want to talk to my colleagues and get a sense here.  You know, we saw the raids there in your home state in California last week. We carried those images live here on the Hill and on NewsNation. The government now says 350-plus undocumented workers, including 14 children, four people were picked up who had been convicted at one point in time of kidnapping, rape, or burglary. California safer now?  You know, I think California has always been pretty safe. And most crime statistics over the last four or five years are way down. So I think California is pretty safe. If he wants to go after criminals, folks with warrants and so forth, that's fine. I think he's going to find a lot of support amongst Democrats. But he's going after kids. He's going after farm workers, other folks, folks that have been in our communities for a long time. I think that's where he's going to lose public support. And if you look at those poll numbers, he is starting to lose some of that support.  So what's the balance here? Because I just read off what the government says occurred there in part last week. And I think anybody would acknowledge, at least when it comes to those kids and violent criminals, that you need to step in.  Yeah, I mean, so for violent criminals, that's fine. Again, he's not going to see any pushback. What we're starting to hear is that they're picking up families, they're approaching folks that look like they might have brown skin and so forth, they might have an accent.  I don't think that's what the public voted for. You know, you're hearing the farm workers afraid to go pick the crops. You're having construction workers being afraid to go to work. Those guys are not criminals. Those men and women are here helping support our economy. I think we ought to have an honest conversation about where we want to go with immigration at this point. You always have one. It's why I enjoy talking to you and having you on the show. Ami Barrett, Democrat there from California. We'll talk to you again soon.  Great. Thanks, Blake. Be well. You as well. Programming note, by the way, for this Wednesday, it is a big day for NewsNation and our partners over at The Hill. The first ever Hill Nation Summit featuring some of the most influential folks in this town and beyond, both sides of the aisle. Democrats and Republicans, you know it's what we do. And by the way, would you look at that? I will be interviewing Christy Noem.  DHS Secretary herself. My conversation with Kristi Noem, Wednesday afternoon. We'll play some of that for you here on The Hill, Wednesday evening, 6 o'clock Eastern, right here on News Nation. Still much more ahead tonight here on The Hill. Minerals, magnets, the military. China has been making calculated moves to bolster itself as a global superpower, but now the U.S. is fighting back and in a way,  that maybe you haven't thought of before. All the conversations about what's going on in the air, on the ground, and at sea. What about underground? I'll explain, other side of the break.  Welcome back here to The Hill on NewsNation. The threat from China is growing, and now America's top competitor is aggressively inserting itself, its navy rather, in the Pacific. Today's Wall Street Journal, for example, with this headline, how China's military is flexing its power in the Pacific. The Journal reports the U.S. is, quote, sounding the alarm as China ventures even closer to the shores of Western allies. It comes as the U.S. is aggressively trying to counter China's dominance below the ground.  The Defense Department announcing a first of its kind. We've never seen this before. A public-private partnership with MP Materials, a company that operated the only rare-earth mine in the United States until recently. And just on Friday in Wyoming, a ribbon-cutting ceremony with the Energy Secretary Christopher Wright for the second rare-earth mine in the U.S., the first one to open in 70 years.  that ribbon cutting with Christopher Wright out there. You can see some of the video from it. Scroll forward here a little bit if we can, because I want to show you what the problem is and the issue is.
