China mines almost 70 percent of the world's rare earth minerals, while the U.S., way behind at 12 percent. China also has about half  of the world's known reserves. The U.S. well back in seventh place. China showing no signs of slowing down either, doubling down on its exploration efforts. Here's a headline from the South China Morning Post reporting that China just discovered an additional 38 rare earth sites this year alone.  They also have a chokehold on the global supply chain. Now, in June, its rare earth exports surged to the highest level since 2009, an issue that the House will address directly in a hearing tomorrow. Now, the President stressed the importance of rare earth minerals, even leveraging mineral rights in peace talks all around the globe, particularly with Ukraine and the Congo.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We're looking to do a deal with Ukraine where they're going to secure what we're giving them with their rare earth and other things. We're getting for the United States a lot of the mineral rights from the Congo.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Now, U.S. Rare Earth is developing a manufacturing facility in Oklahoma as part of an effort to help make that state a leader in the production of rare earth magnets. With me now here on the Hill, Josh Ballard is the CEO of that company, USA Rare Earth. Thanks for being in. Nice to see you. Appreciate having me. So this story all of a sudden got really big because of the renewed trade war between the U.S. and China, and China basically is trying to put a hold on those rare earth magnets. What are they? Why are they so important? Yeah.  So rare-earth magnets, you have to imagine them as they're the technology that enables the electrification of the economy. So everywhere where you think about electricity being translated into motion, that's where these magnets are used. TVs are the obvious example, they can be used in drones, they can be used all through a car, cell phones, speakers, they're throughout the economy. Okay, so it's this phone, it's that camera, all this stuff here. Underpins modern technology.  How big of an issue is this? Because I just ripped off some of the stats there. China has 70% of the rare earth supplies. That's right. 70% of the rare earth supplies, over 90% of the processing, over 90% of the metal making, over 90% of the magnet production. And importantly, there's key rare earths that was on the China control list about two months ago that they control over 98% of, which are key for defense and some of the higher performance magnets that we need in these technologies.  What can we do about it? Like, is this solvable? This is the United States. We can solve anything, right? Is this one of those things? It's absolutely solvable. How? Of course we can. So there's two sides to it. I'm going to start from the easier, magnets and metal making. We can surge that here in the United States. We gave it up over the last four decades. We can certainly bring it back. We need some support from the government to lift up this entire industry. But of course, we can surge it and build it fairly quickly. The deposits, however, that's a harder nut to crack. This stuff is very hard to get out of the rock. It's not like digging coal and just taking it out and using it.  It's in the parts per millions within the rock. It takes a lot of science. It's going to take many years to do it. So you name check the government there. You're in town. Obviously, I presume there might be some sort of connection there. What can the government actually do? Because there's a real question here, like we saw the MP Materials deal, of if the government should be involved with a private American company. Yeah.  You also could make the argument that this is something that we have to win or we have to catch up on. That's right. We have to win it. We have to catch up. And the government's got to be super creative. We did it in 2008 when the auto manufacturing was suffering during the crisis. So that was a crisis. That's right. And this is a crisis. You believe this to be a crisis. Why?  These underpin our ability to create new defense technologies, right? They underpin a lot of modern technology today, and it's getting cut off. Ford was just saying just, what, a week or two ago that they were going to have to shut down production lines because they didn't have what? Magnets. And this is happening throughout. We have customers calling us every day, worried about their own magnet supply. So this could shut down specific industries. So it's a small industry in itself, a few billion, but it enables trillions of dollars of the economy.  So we already saw one company get into business with the government. Are you guys planning to do that? Do you want government investment in your company? We are looking for the government to support to build this industry. Absolutely. We need a moat from China. China gets a lot of subsidization, a lot of money from the government, tax kickbacks, and so forth. It's not a competitive environment that we can compete against, but it's an industry we have to build here. So there's going to have to be a moat built. So the creativity from the Trump administration has been welcome to the industry, frankly. Can China shut us off?  They absolutely can. Yeah, they more or less have. They're starting to let it eek out. But it's like anything else, right? Like, if they shut us off, it just, it escalates, and that gets dangerous for them, I would think. It does. I mean, there's a balance here, right? I mean, if they overplay their hand, then we're going to just do it much faster and drop them, right? Let me leave you with this. Where are we, say, in a decade?  In a decade, I think we're going to have a number of operating mines here in the U.S. We'll have a good amount of those rare earths being mined here. And I think we can build up our magnet and metal manufacturing within a decade to support U.S. industry. All right. We'll leave it there, Josh Fowler.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you, sir. Good luck here in town.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I appreciate it. All right. Still to come tonight, here from the Hill, former President Biden defending the use of the auto pen and his comments capturing the attention of President Trump.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: The Otoe Pen, I think, is maybe one of the biggest scandals that we've had in 50 to 100 years.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So as the former president and his party address the controversy, another one awaits involving a big meeting up on Capitol Hill. With who, we'll explain, and what those two have said in the last 24 hours when The Hill returns.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: NewsNation Wednesday, the Hill Nation Summit. A first-of-its-kind bipartisan event bringing those in the know and those in power together. With all-day special coverage starting at 6 a.m. Eastern. Interviews with Speaker Mike Johnson and DHS Secretary Kristi Noem and more. Plus special guests. Join Chris Cuomo live at 8 p.m. Wednesday only on NewsNation.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Here to the Hill on NewsNation and the Center of Politics, we're getting two very different versions of former President Biden's use of the auto pen when it came to clemency decisions during his time as president. According to the New York Times, President Biden defended his use, its use rather, and in speaking to the decision-making process during an interview, quote, I made every single one of those. The auto pen is, you know, legal.  As you know, other presidents used it, including Trump. Now, Biden relayed the decisions were always his and that there were plenty of witnesses. They were discussed, documented, executed. But the Times also reporting something else. When it came to clemency, President Biden didn't approve every name that came across his desk. Obvious question there. So who did? Additionally, when it came to clemency, Biden only used his own hands.  rather than the auto pen once. And that was when he issued a full pardon to his son, Hunter Biden. President Trump would opine from the White House today with a much different narrative than the one presented by the Times.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Look, the auto pen, I think, is maybe one of the biggest scandals that we've had in 50 to 100 years. This is a tremendous scandal. And I guarantee he knew nothing about what he was signing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Also taking some headlines from Biden's former boss. At a fundraiser this past weekend, President Obama would lend today's Democrats some tough love when it comes to how to deal with the age of Trump. Quote, I think it's going to require a little less navel-gazing and a little less whining and being in fetal positions, and it's going to require Democrats to just toughen up.  Sounds like things are going well on that side of the aisle. Full panel with me now. Lance Trover, former spokesperson for Doug Burgum's presidential campaign. Scott Bolden, laughing at that one, NewsNation political contributor. Carla Sands, former ambassador to Denmark and Greenland. And Joe Cunningham with us for the first time, former Democratic congressman from the great state of South Carolina, well represented on this show, that state is. Hello to you all. Hello. Thanks for being here. Appreciate it. You satisfied with that response from Joe Biden?  I just want Joe Biden to go away like a former president. And why talk about the auto-pin when that plays directly into the Republicans' talking point? Here's what I was trying to figure out today. I could sit here and say, you know what, all Joe Biden has to do is come out and talk and say whatever he wants and it ends it, right? And so he came out and he talked, and it obviously doesn't end it, but I get to the question of why now? Why do you think he came out now for this?  Because I think that he is really concerned about the Republican narrative about his presidency and his competence. He should have been talking about the 2005 DOJ memorandum that said the auto pen is effective and constitutional to use it. Donald Trump's used it. Every other president's used it. And why not talk about that to put it to bed, this Republican narrative? Donald Trump doesn't know whether Biden was all there or not. He's just he just speaks in this hyperbole and his MAGA supporters just eat it up.  Then make it true. So, I found it fascinating, Joe, that the one clemency that he signed by hand was his son, Hunter. Yeah.  I mean, it's a loser of an issue for Biden to be talking about. Any time they roll him out to speak on this, it hearkens back to the lack of credibility the Democratic Party has right now. I'm in South Carolina, so we have every presidential contender or wannabe contender coming through our state. And when I see folks come through, not rip the Band-Aid off on President Biden and the fact that he should not have run for re-election in the first place, and it should have been an open process, a Democratic process, especially coming from a party that says, save democracy.  That's old history, though, so... But it all goes back to credibility, though. It may be old history, but, you know, you can talk about anything you want, but unless somebody is credible, and right now the Democratic Party doesn't have the credibility, it's because of those old issues, as you say. They need that to move forward. You give him any credit for coming to speak out on this? I mean, he had to answer the question at some point. Biden? Yeah. I want more Joe Biden interviews. The Republican Party, more, more, more every day. He needs to be out here with you tomorrow night, like, doing an interview. I'd love to talk to him. I mean... You sound like a real man now.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: you

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, well, I think that the more Joe Biden talks, the worse things get for the Democrats. But I think it's the same for Obama. I don't think they want to hear from Obama either. They are both yesterday's news and leftovers. They both did not do a good job for our economy. The people were worse off at the end of their presidencies. And I think it's time for new blood. But they keep beating these same dead horses and taking the 20% issues on big issues. The 20%, well, we have the 80% on President Trump's team.  What about to Carla's point, Joe, of Barack Obama coming out and giving this advice? Again, I have a lot of respect for former President Obama. I think he lost a little bit of credibility when he did not call for an open process after Biden stepped aside. And again, that goes back to the ethos of the Democratic Party and basically repairing that credibility. Hold on, you're a Democrat and you're trashing your party right now. What gives you the hope? I'm being honest. That's trashing.  Listen, I would rather hurt them with the truth than comfort them with a lie. And I'm being honest and transparent as I have been for the last number of years on where the party needs to go. And it starts with being honest with American people.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: But I think that the Biden staffers are going to have consequences because what they did, were they getting paid? They're doing investigations right now and I think they're also investigating, I know this, Obama and Biden targeting Trump and there's going to be consequences there too.  So to Joe's point... It's a big deal. It's a thousand water days. It's over. It doesn't really matter.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I want to ask you, though, about Joe's point, because here was the hill, Scott. Mark Cuban, Democrats' only message is Trump sucks. Quote, Trump sucks. The sky is blue. Trump sucks. That's not the way to win. It's not because it's not about Trump. It's about the people of the United States of America and what's good for them. Is Mark Cuban right?  Mark Cuban is right, and Barack Obama's tough love message, I like that. Now it's got to manifest itself. Because here's the deal, everyone knows what Donald Trump is and isn't, and everybody knows what he's done with this big beautiful bill, but you still gotta have a message, you still gotta give people hope.  And if they don't like Trump, whether it's MAGA or Trumpism, if you don't like Trump, they've got to have an alternative. And most people don't think right now they've got an alternative. The Democrats are in the 30s and 40s in most polling. You've got to get out of that dump, come up with a message, any messenger. To the other side of the aisle, Lance, as Democrats try to deal with this.  Man, your party and Jeffrey Epstein and how all of that was handled now. I don't know if you saw the top of the show, but I was talking to Sean Spicer about...  The first six months of Trump, you could argue, was successful, exceptionally successful, I think a lot of Republicans would say. But then the last week, woof, with Ukraine, a totally different position, whether you support the decision or not, I'm not saying the decision was that. And then Jeffrey Epstein, it's not what the base thought it was going to get eight days ago.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think if we're talking about Ukraine, the president committed to end the war. He didn't say he was going to end it on behalf of one side or the other. He said he was going to get the war over. I don't know that the base is, like, really upset there. They just want to get the war done because they're tired of shoving money... I mean, Marjorie Taylor Greene coming out today and saying... Yeah, there's going to be folks who disagree with it, but I think the base understands the commitment is to end the war. That was the commitment. And just quit shoveling billions and billions of dollars over there. They're going to be buying... NATO's going to be buying our weapons. We're not just going to be handing them over.  Which I think is what everybody kind of wanted. They wanted to like help out Ukraine, not at our expense.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: How do you address this though? The base upset over the client list. Oh. Laura Trump came out today and basically said there could be, I'm paraphrasing, could be more coming from the admin going forward. Look, it's been reported out today they're exploring different options. I think clearly they're going to have to take some further steps on that. What that is, also to be within the confines of the law and what the Justice Department can put out there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yes, I do. I think Trump may be dealing with the intelligence community, and there may be, you know, they may have activated some of those perps, and they're not able to reveal their names because they're actually working for the government. I'm not saying that it's a good idea. I'm just saying that the IC community holds a lot of power in the United States. The people on the left and the right, they want justice for these victims. They want to know who the perps were. And I think there's going to have to be some kind of disclosure to close this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So how does this unwind from your side of the aisle to say, OK, we can move on now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Because you're nowhere near that right now. I think they'll find a way.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, the Democrats, I'm sorry, the Democrats and the Republicans both want this disclosed. And I got to tell you, here's the but-for test. The only reason you wouldn't disclose and keep your word if you're in Trump world to all those MAGA supporters, the only reason you wouldn't do it is because Donald Trump's name is all over these files.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: No, it's national security. That's not right.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Don't do that. National security. You can do national security all you want, but Donald Trump and his FBI director and Bondi of DOJ all promised before they got in office that they would release these files. Now they've looked at the files, and the only reason you wouldn't do it to satisfy your base... You're an attorney by trade.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You don't actually believe that's the only reason.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: When it all comes down to it, it would be the only reason you wouldn't release it. I mean, look, Epstein's been leveraged for political reasons for a while, and it's been used to get the base, Republican base, all hungry, and they want to be fed. And they're hungry, and they're going to eat something. So, I mean, now they're eating each other. I mean, as you look at this wedge that's been  being driven by itself well that that's the question is that in the end all be all obviously but you know it's it's a it's a it will be a bit unnecessary unnecessary self-inflicted wound and there's moral indignation by the people of the united states about this all right i got to move on i know we can talk about it all night and i don't know that and i don't know that i don't think it's going to come uh... tonight here on the hill there is a big summit tomorrow featuring that guy featuring that guy right there  I'm going to explain to you why, on the other side of the break, it is bipartisan, and it is absolutely something you should think about, and it's why we're covering it. And coming up on Elizabeth Vargas Reports, why one columnist says Zoran Mamdani is not the answer for New York City's working class. That's seven minutes out. My take on the other side of the break. Stay with us.  on the top stories here is what's trending right now on the hill dot com this is the big one in this town today the president announcing uh... can flip forward to it every other president announcing a big weapons deal for ukraine in its war against russia on those weapons going through nato the president says that the u s will be paid for those weapons this is the back-and-forth over the weekend between the vice president of the gala california governor jay uh... gavin newsome  The VP was over at Disneyland, and the two went back and forth at each other on social media. And I actually watched this live yesterday. Chelsea star Cole Palmer on Trump joining team for trophy ceremony. I was a bit confused. The players were up there getting their awards from the president after the big FIFA team event. And it was fascinating watching the players interact with the president of the United States. They obviously don't do that often.  To check out these stories and more, all you have to do is scan the QR code on your screen or head on over to thehill.com for the very latest. All right, time for my take now. And I talk about AI, artificial intelligence, a lot on this show, a lot more than you will see anywhere else on cable TV.  And just look at how this week is starting. Today, the Pentagon unveiled it's awarding a contract up to $200 million worth to Google, OpenAI, Elon Musk's Grok, and Anthropic. Now, the government says they want the best AI talent solving for military use cases. And in Pennsylvania tomorrow, President Trump will be the headliner to tout what is reportedly a $70 billion investment in AI and energy, the president traveling to a summit being touted by the Republican Senator Dave McCormick.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We're going to do an energy summit in Pittsburgh later this summer.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It aims to gather global leaders in energy and artificial intelligence. Axios is reporting that the Democratic Governor Josh Shapiro, Senator John Fetterman will be there as well, the Treasury Secretary, the Commerce Secretary, a who's who. Now, it feels like this is kind of like the 90s all over again, when many were trying to figure out that internet thing.  There is no doubt that AI is hard to grasp. The reason why the government is getting involved is pretty simple. It's where the money's flowing. Regulation is a real question. But this is also a battle with China, which is why you are seeing both parties jumping on board, as they should be.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Secretary Brooke Rollins underscores the importance of public-private partnerships in achieving health goals. She highlights the USDA's role in implementing changes through nutrition programs like SNAP and school lunches. Secretary Rollins discusses working with farmers and states to obtain waivers and ensure healthier food options are available. She also addresses the issue of illegal immigrant workers in agriculture, emphasising the need for a 100% American workforce while exploring solutions like automation and leveraging able-bodied American workers.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. emphasises the harmful effects of petroleum-based dyes in food, particularly on children's health. He highlights the industry's commitment to removing these dyes by 2026 and the FDA's approval of vegetable-based dyes as alternatives. Secretary Kennedy also defends Medicaid reforms, stating they aim to control growth rates without cuts, and emphasises the fiscal responsibility of such measures.
summary.SPEAKER_02: The host (possibly Larry Elder) expresses support for the administration's efforts to remove artificial dyes from food and emphasises the urgency of the issue. He also discusses the broader implications of food quality on public health, particularly among children. The host questions the implementation of these changes in programs like SNAP and school lunches. He also touches on Medicaid reforms, criticising claims that they will lead to significant health harm, and brings up the topic of illegal immigrant workers in various industries, seeking solutions that protect farmers while upholding the law.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the administration's efforts to improve public health through dietary changes and regulatory reforms. They focus on removing petroleum-based dyes from food, promoting vegetable-based alternatives, and utilising public-private partnerships to achieve these goals. The conversation also touches on broader health-related issues like Medicaid reforms, immigration policies affecting the agricultural industry, and the importance of a dignified workforce.

video_title: New UFO research found unidentified object with significance: Professor | Elizabeth Vargas Reports

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: In order to solve the biggest mysteries of our universe, there need to be scientists willing to study them. But the stigma surrounding UFOs has discouraged generations of researchers from taking a closer look at the age-old question, are we alone? Well, now that's all changing, as real scientists with real degrees and real academic credentials are taking on the topic. A group of scientists just published a paper about how to scientifically study UFOs, and they've done their own field work to show how it's done.  They say most of the UFOs they have studied on camera were man-made things, like drones or helicopters. But there was one, they say, that they couldn't figure quite what it was. So what was it? Joining us now is University of Albany physics professor Matthew Zydagas, who published this research. All right, so tell us more. How did you go about doing this, and what did you find?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, we had the focus of having an instrumented field study for UAP. So it's not the first, but what we've done is we've published our work in the highest impact factor journal to ever carry a paper on this topic. So while we don't have  some kind of final conclusive smoking gun evidence of something anomalous. What we've done is really help break down the stigma and the taboo by publishing our results in a major journal, Progress in Aerospace Sciences.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So you were able to identify most of the objects, but one you could not. What do you think that was? Can you describe what properties it had?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: That's right. So we found one dark spot with white dots in it in one of our camera systems. Now, by itself, that could be anything. It could be a camera artifact or glitch. But it seemed to have some correspondence.  at least to a small degree of statistical significance with an ionizing radiation event and with Doppler weather radar data hits using publicly available National Weather Service and NOAA data. So again, not conclusive statistically, but the strange hint that there was something physical in the sky and that it wasn't just a camera glitch at the time.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: When was this?  Like when did that happen?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: This was in July of 2021. So I went with a group called UAPX and we were part of a documentary film called A Tear in the Sky.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And just very quickly, you started to get interested in this because of the infamous 2004 Tic Tac video from the USS Nimitz. That's what sort of sparked your interest in all this?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So, that kind of solidified my interest, but I already had interest much earlier from childhood, growing up watching Unsolved Mysteries and shows, you know, like that with Robert Stack, and seeing all the famous cases like the Cash Landrum and Rendersome Forest incident. And I just thought there's all these famous cases, even before 2004, that I found the evidence compelling that there was a there there, that there was something to study and try to understand.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And it's worth noting, we still don't know what that video, the tic-tac video, that's still a sort of unexplained mystery. The pilots who saw that in the sky are convinced it was something otherworldly. Matthew Shadagas, fascinating. Come back and tell us more when you have more, but it's fascinating and it's a great step forward for scientists to be studying this as well. Appreciate it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you so much.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer probes Professor Zydagas about the study's methods, findings, and the unexplainable object. They express interest in the implications of the research and its potential to change public perception of UFOs. The interviewer also asks about the timing of the incident and the inspiration behind Professor Zydagas's interest in the field.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Professor Zydagas explains that the study involved an instrumented field study for Unidentified Aerial Phenomena (UAPs) and was published in a prestigious journal to enhance credibility. He describes the unexplainable object as a dark spot with white dots, associated with ionising radiation events and Doppler weather radar data hits. Professor Zydagas emphasises the statistical significance of these findings but acknowledges their inconclusiveness. He also mentions his long-standing interest in UFOs, sparked by childhood curiosity and various famous cases, and notes that the infamous 2004 Tic Tac video solidified his determination to pursue scientific research in this area.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a scientific study on UFOs conducted by a group of researchers led by Professor Matthew Zydagas. The study aims to break down the stigma surrounding UFO research and presents a methodological approach to investigating these phenomena. The researchers conducted fieldwork and analysed data, identifying most UFOs as man-made objects but finding one unexplainable anomaly.

video_title: 'There is no client list': Jeffrey Epstein's former lawyer | Cuomo

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Is the government hiding a client list or anything that the Trump administration could release tonight?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: No, there is no client list. There never has been a client list. A client list suggests that Jeffrey Epstein made a list of people to whom he trafficked women. What there is, is a redacted FBI affidavit  from accusers, there are several of them, from accusers that accuse Jeffrey, that accuse various people of having improper sex. And that has been redacted. The names of the people accused have been blacked out. Now, of course, because I was the lawyer and I did all the investigations, I know who all these people are. I could figure out, based on everything that  I saw who Mr. X is, Mr. Y is, and Mr. Z. I can tell you right now, none of them are public figures who are currently in office. Some of them were previously in office. Some of them are dead. But there is no client list.  And the redactions could be undone if you go to court. So, many of the things that are being suppressed are being suppressed by two judges in Manhattan. And they're doing it largely to protect the alleged accusers, who are, in the view of the judges, victims, even though we don't know what their actual status is, but the judges have  issued orders, which is why I can't disclose things I'd love to disclose, saying that you can't disclose this information. But Pam Bondi and the Justice Department and Donald Trump are not responsible for that. I don't know of any information that they could disclose that they haven't disclosed. Now, maybe there is some, but I'm simply not aware of it. And so I think it's important to place the blame where the blame deserves to be placed.  The vast majority of people who are in the files—and I know them all. I've seen all the names. The vast, vast majority of them have already been disclosed. They're in articles all over the world. They're in books that have been written. So, if we got everything, everything, you would be shocked how few  Names are there that haven't already been disclosed. The media hasn't, by the way, done a good enough job in finding the people who have been disclosed in the public record. So that's that list. Then there's the videotapes. People say there must be sex tapes. I know the whole story there. There is a videotape, maybe several videotapes.  They came under the following circumstances. Before any of this happened, Epstein was robbed by one of his employees of money and of a licensed gun. And he called the Palm Beach police, and they installed video cameras, not in the bedrooms, but in the living room.  And those video cameras recorded some people, but there's no sexual allegations there. So, there's nothing to that. And then there's Tucker Carlson's absurd allegations about the Mossad. There, I know it from very, very personal experience. Why?  I was representing Jeffrey Epstein. I asked him about everything, including whether he had any contacts with intelligence agencies. If he had, he would have been dying to tell me that, because I could have used that to get him a better deal. If he had worked with the Mossad or the CIA, that would have been golden for me. But, of course, he said no. And then I checked it with my sources in Israel.  Let me clear. I once represented the Mossad. When five Israeli Mossad agents were captured in Cyprus, the head of the Mossad asked me to represent them. I did. I got them out. And the Mossad sent me a congratulatory note. I'm friendly with many of the people who have been heads of the Mossad. I'm not going to tell you who my sources are, but I can tell you with absolute certainty he had no connections to Mossad.  He only got connected to Israel very late in this when he met Ehud Barak and he made business dealings with him. But there was no connection to Mossad. The reason that story generated is because his girlfriend, Ghislaine Maxwell's father, probably did have a connection to Mossad, Robert Maxwell, but it had nothing to do with Jeffrey Epstein. And as far as the suicide is concerned,  Of course it was a suicide, but it was a suicide, I believe, assisted by jailers. It was not a suicide that he could have committed alone. I think the jailers had something to do with his cellmate being dismissed, with the cameras being turned off. So there are things that can be hidden. But there's no smoking gun here, and there's no fault on the part of this administration, as far as I can tell.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

summary.unstructured_summary:
{'high_level_summary': 'The conversation discusses the Jeffrey Epstein case, clarifying several misconceptions. The key points are
: there is no client list; the redacted FBI affidavit contains accusations against individuals, none of whom are current public figures; the Trump administration is not responsible for suppressing information; most names in the files have already been disclosed; there are no sex tapes involving sexual allegations; Epstein had no connections to the Mossad; and his suicide was likely assisted by jailers.', 'SPEAKER_01': 'The speaker (likely Alan Dershowitz) denies the existence of a client list. He explains that the redacted FBI affidavit contains accusations from accusers against various individuals, but none of them are current public figures. He asserts that the Trump administration and Pam Bondi are not responsible for suppressing information, which is being done by two judges in Manhattan to protect the alleged accusers. The speaker also reveals that he knows many of the names in the files and that most have already been disclosed to the public. He discusses the videotapes, clarifying that they were installed in the living room after Epstein was robbed and do not contain any sexual allegations. Additionally, he strongly denies Epstein had any connections to the Mossad, stating he would have used that information to Epstein\'s advantage in court and that he personally checked with his sources in Israel. The speaker also believes Epstein\'s suicide was assisted by jailers due to negligence in his cell security.', 'SPEAKER_00': 'The interviewer (SPEAKER_00) does not provide direct statements but guides the conversation by asking questions about the government hiding information related to the Trump administration and Jeffrey Epstein. They seem to be seeking clarity on the existence of a client list, the responsibility for suppressing information, and any potential involvement of public figures or intelligence agencies. The interviewer\'s final remarks promote their news channel, emphasising its commitment to fact-based and unbiased news.'}

video_title: Masked ICE agents afraid of 'humiliation' of going into society arresting people: Rivera | CUOMO

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Democrats are pushing legislation that would require ICE agents to remove their masks when arresting illegal migrants, or I guess arresting anyone. Why is that the focus?  Why aren't they fighting about the policies and about how the Fourth Amendment is being interpreted and the locations that are being used? Why play to the petty aspect? I'll tell you why. Because this is the BS that works on social media. The mask. Let me tell you, there's good reason and sus reason for them to wear masks. If you were getting doxxed based on what you did at work, you might be a little bit more careful about your identity also.  A sitting Democratic member of Congress wanted to dox. You know, this can be a real problem. You know, this Representative Carbajal doxed an Immigration and Customs Enforcement employee who was subsequently attacked by rioters and sent to the emergency room. That's messed up. Now, you can say, well, I think what they're doing is messed up. Fine. Let's have that fight.  Let's have that fight. Let's fight about what the policy should be. The Democrats should be involved in that, but who gives a damn about the mask?  Let's discuss. Former Acting Deputy DHS Secretary, Senior Fellow for the Center for Renewing America, Ken Cuccinelli, and NewsNation correspondent at large, Geraldo Rivera. Ken, the answer to the question, who cares about the masks, is sitting right next to you in handsome form. Geraldo Rivera cares about the masks and says, real men don't wear masks. Why do the masks matter, my friend?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, normally when police are conducting their business, you wouldn't want them wearing masks. You would want them to have their name tags on, because it's part of accountability. However, there's a balance of concerns here. And your first priority has to be the safety of your officers. If your officers aren't safe, they aren't even going to be able to do their job. And when we have  lots of different types of folks, most appallingly congressmen, but lots of different types of folks trying to dox these agents, then their safety is put at risk. And let's be real clear, Chris, this isn't just about the officers. You and I both know that what's the real threat is your family.  your family gets put at risk. And that's the implicit threat here. It isn't just the safety of officers. Officers, they take these jobs knowing that they step into danger every day, and they do it for us, and God bless them for it. But they're not putting their families on the line to do it. Well, the doxing puts their families on the line. It's really repugnant. It's awful.  And, frankly, if the case can be made connecting the doxing to the violence, then those cases should be prosecuted.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You know, listen, I get it. And believe me, if people knew what my family has been through, one, they would stone me for staying in this business. And, two, they might even have some sympathy. Yeah, I doubt it. Geraldo, what's the counterargument? What bothers you about the masks? What matters about what we're seeing with ICE enforcement policies that should be the focus?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I'm shocked that my brother disagrees with me so dramatically on this issue, Chris, because—and hello, Ken. Can you imagine a world where cops wore masks, where sheriffs wore masks, where the FBI wore masks?  where court officers wore masks. You cannot. They shouldn't. Because of the ominous danger and the wicked effect that law enforcement in masks would have on society. We would all be terrorized. And I submit to both of you that that is the reason they all wear masks. It's not the doxxing. As far as I know, there's been a handful of cases, maybe just one or two,  What they're afraid of is the humiliation of going into society and arresting otherwise law-abiding people. The statistics are out now. Over 70 percent of the people arrested so far have no criminal record.  What is going on here is horrible, and you have to give some equity to the people who are being targeted for these unprecedented sweeps that are now temporarily, at least, on pause because of a federal judge in Southern California crack.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Opposes the idea of ICE agents wearing masks, arguing it would have an ominous danger and wicked effect on society, terrorising the public. Believes that the masks are worn to avoid humiliation of arresting otherwise law-abiding people, citing statistics that over 70% of those arrested have no criminal record. Downplays the significance of doxing, mentioning only a handful of cases.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Acknowledges the importance of accountability but emphasises the priority of officer safety. Argues that doxxing puts not only officers but also their families at risk, creating an implicit threat. Suggests that cases connecting doxing to violence should be prosecuted.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Argues that the mask mandate is a distraction from the real issues like policy debates and Fourth Amendment interpretations. Highlights the safety concerns for ICE agents due to doxxing, noting an incident where an agent was attacked after being doxxed by a sitting Democratic member of Congress. Emphasises the need for a focus on substantive policy discussions rather than petty matters.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses a proposed legislation by Democrats requiring ICE agents to remove their masks during arrests. The speakers debate the merits and underlying reasons for this legislation, with differing viewpoints on accountability, officer safety, and the impact on public trust.

video_title: Trump facing MAGA crises with Epstein and immigration handling: Vittert | On Balance

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: six months into his administration, Donald Trump faces now two crises. Each represents, as crises do, danger and opportunity. Tonight, Bill O'Reilly on whether Trump can solve the problems. Ambassador John Bolton on Trump's tough stance with Vladimir Putin. Plus, former AOC supporter Lucy Biggers exposes the Mamdani fantasy in New York. But first, our Wyatt Matters segment.  We've always known President Trump as a different kind of president. Six months into his administration, we are starting to see if he will be a transformational president. He faces two crises inside his own coalition, inside MAGA, Epstein and immigration.  Epstein is a crisis of confidence in the base. Immigration will test his willingness to defy the base for his legacy. As we've noted, the president has wins so far that are significant. Stock market highs, Iran strike success, tariffs now bringing in serious cash, a closed border. Establishment Washington said all of those things were impossible. But the Epstein case is unlike every other kerfuffle President Trump and his administration, Trump 2.0, have faced.  Because the handling of the Jeffrey Epstein files is not a case of MAGA vs. the media, because then MAGA can fight back against the media. And there have been a lot of made-up scandals so far in the first six months. Where was MAGA vs. the media? And MAGA's won. Just think about Signalgate. Remember? Haven't heard about that in a long time. It's gone. This is MAGA vs. MAGA, or grassroots MAGA vs. Washington MAGA. And the base right now is furious with Trump and his administration.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I will not rest until we go full Jan 6 committee on the Jeffrey Epstein files. Release the Epstein files, am I right?

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I blame Pam Bondi.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Those are fighting words, not from the left, but from Turning Point USA, which is the campus activist group that is all about Donald Trump. And Trump spent this weekend trying to defuse the crisis. He wrote on Truth Social, what's going on with my boys, and in some cases, gals? They're all going after Attorney General Pam Bondi. He's doing a fantastic job. We're on one team, MAGA, and I don't like what's happening. And then Charlie Kirk, who is the young acolyte of Donald Trump.  one of his most vocal supporters, got a phone call from Trump over the weekend. Just take a look at the difference of Charlie on Friday versus today on his radio show.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: How many of you raise your hand and think this is a big deal, the Epstein thing? Would you raise your hand? So, I mean, every hand has gone up. I'm done talking about Epstein for the time being. I'm going to trust my friends in the administration. I'm going to trust my friends in the government to do what needs to be done, solve it, balls in their hands.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And now you see the power of Donald Trump. Because all the MAGA influencer types understand that if they lose Trump, they lose their audience. The audience will not turn on Trump. The audience will turn on the influencers. Trump is MAGA. And that brings us to the next fight. If the MAGA faithful are furious over Epstein, their heads are going to positively explode over any talk or even ideas about offering amnesty to illegal immigrants.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: What do I think about amnesty for farm workers? I think it's the most grotesque thing I've ever heard. Are you joking? They all must be deported. Mass deportations now. Amnesty never. No amnesty. Repeat after me.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: No amnesty. Period. End of story. Amnesty should be the biggest slur in the entire English language. Amnesty is a repugnant word. Amnesty is disgusting because it's a slur against you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Keep in mind, Charlie Kirk is also in the never amnesty camp. Trump now must choose between keeping his base happy or taking, we talked about this over last week, his unique point in history.  concrete steps to cement his legacy as president. A comprehensive deal on immigration would do that, and amnesty, probation, parole is going to have to be part of some grand deal. But for now, the focus is on Epstein. Trump must get past it. Bill O'Reilly noted the Epstein saga could really hurt Trump's credibility. He writes the Justice Department does have information, and Attorney General Pam Bondi, as well as Attorney General Merrick Garland, should both answer general questions about the investigations. It's their responsibility to do that. President Trump should

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Now the focus is on Epstein. Trump must get past it. Bill O'Reilly noted the Epstein saga could really hurt Trump's credibility. He writes the Justice Department does have information, and Attorney General Pam Bondi as well as Attorney General Merrick Garland should both answer general questions about the investigations. It's their responsibility to do that. President Trump should  Order it. Bill with us now, host of the No Spin News on BillOReilly.com, author of the upcoming book Confronting Evil, Assessing the Worst of the Worst, Bill's content on YouTube.com, backslash Bill O'Reilly. Bill, it is good to see you, as always. I don't think Donald Trump has any power over Merrick Garland, but who exactly should he order Pam Bondi to answer questions from other than you and me?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: the press. I mean, just hold a press conference and invite the former Attorney General Garland. If he doesn't come, put an empty chair there with his picture on it, because Garland had the information that the Trump people have for four years.  This is more of a mystery than it is a crisis. I disagree with the word crisis. I don't think it's a crisis for the country. It might be a political detriment to the Republican Party and Donald Trump, but it's not a crisis for the country. There's no evidence that there's any cover-up of a pedophile ring or any of that. And without such evidence, it just becomes a curiosity.  But it is a dangerous situation because Americans are starting to lose credibility with the Justice Department.  And they, many, many millions of Americans believe, fix is always in for the rich and powerful. It's always in. And they were hoping that President Trump would blast that. And now the president is — he's not doing anything actively. But, certainly, he could order Pam Bindy to have a press conference and, in general terms, tell the folks what the Justice Department knows, what they found out.  Now, my reporting says it is not Pam Bondi who's making any decisions at all. It is the assistant attorney general, Todd Blanche. Do you know that name? Sure. Todd Blanche?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: So he was Trump's lawyer in the New York City stuff. And Trump really trusts him. And he has far more access.  to Donald Trump than Ms. Bondi does. And from what I'm being told, I believe it's accurate, Blanche has basically said, look, if we give out too much specific information, we're opening a lot of doors here that our opponents are going to run with and make things up and take out of context, which is absolutely true. But to guard your flank,  You have to respect your supporters. And your supporters, most of them want a pretty good idea of what the Justice Department knows. Does that make sense to you?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: It does. I don't believe it, because the reporting a couple of days ago... What don't you believe? Well, a few things. One, I didn't say it was a crisis for the country. I said it could be it was a political crisis for Donald Trump. But number two, I think what you're saying is a little different than what you said last week, because last week you were saying the reason that this isn't being released is because Trump, who is the president, he has absolute authority here.  was worried that by releasing all of the names, the client list that Pam Bondi said she had and now somehow says doesn't exist, that it would be guilt by association, right? If, oh, you were associated with Epstein, everyone then was going to have to prove they were not a pedophile. That, to me, though, is very different than what you just said about Todd Blanche, number one. But number two, there's no journalist in the world that should accept that.  So you're saying there's Trump friends? You're saying there's Trump friends?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I use the word general, okay, because I assume that people watching last week on this program remember what I said, and I wrote it on BillO'Reilly.com, that you cannot give out specific names.  Because those people would be damned. The media would run wild with it, not put it into context. You can't ruin lives like that. I didn't think I had to restate that. So then why did Pam Bondi say she was going to release it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Why did Trump run on releasing everything?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I have no idea. That is the mystery. Why did Pam Bondi say, I have a list on my desk, and I'm looking it over, and we're going to release it? I don't know.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Believes Trump should order Pam Bondi to hold a press conference and provide general information about what the Justice Department knows regarding the Epstein investigation. He argues that the public is losing credibility with the DOJ and that Trump needs to address this. However, he also acknowledges the concerns of Todd Blanche, Trump's lawyer, about releasing specific information that could be misused by the media.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Questions why Trump and Bondi have backtracked on their previous statements about releasing information related to the Epstein case. He points out inconsistencies in Bill O'Reilly's views and argues that the media should not accept vague explanations. He emphasises the need for transparency and accountability, particularly from former Attorney General Bondi.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the Epstein saga's impact on Trump, the role of Attorney Generals Bondi and Garland, and the information held by the Justice Department.

video_title: W're starting to see deals, they aren't getting enough attention from the market, says Jim Cramer

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: They don't start big, but we're beginning to see deals, important ones, and they aren't getting enough attention from the market, or from the media for that matter. If anything, even the unofficial start to earnings season, they're being dismissed, and that's just plain stupid. I was on downgrade today of Goldman Sachs, the principal deal house, and I almost have to laugh about how wrongheaded that is. Sell, sell, sell.  Oh, and let's not forget, these mergers aren't just good news for the investment banks. They're good news for the entire stock market, which may be sensing something, because we started the day down big, and then rebounded with the Dow closing up 88 points. This will be advancing 0.14%, and then as a gaining 0.27%. You know what, it's actually a stupendous comeback, especially in light of some of the incredibly aggressive, some would say negative, tariff news from the president this weekend. Everywhere I went, people said, oh boy, I guess the market's going to be down big on Monday. I said, no, not so fast.  Regular viewers know that I think we have two markets here. Big institutional investors, they've generally been selling, but individual investors have been buying stocks hand over fist. I don't think they seem to care about the tariffs. They know that everybody sold it for the Liberation Day announcements, and anyone who did, it turned out to be a big mistake. They missed a big move. But don't be so short-sighted. We're seeing the beginnings of an M&A boom here. Even as it may not feel like it, because often the deals seem, well, dowdy or, let's say, not clear yet or in the future.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Don't miss a second of Mad Money. Follow at Jim Cramer on X. Have a question? Tweet Cramer. Hashtag Mad Mentions. Send Jim an email to madmoneyatcnbc.com or give us a call at 1-800-743-CNBC. Miss something? Head to madmoney.cnbc.com.

summary.SPEAKER_01: SPEAKER_01 highlights the emergence of significant M&A deals that are not receiving enough attention. He criticises Goldman Sachs for downgrading the market and predicts an M&A boom. He notes the stock market's rebound despite negative tariff news, suggesting individual investors are optimistic while institutional investors are selling. SPEAKER_01 emphasises that these deals are good news for both investment banks and the overall stock market.
summary.high_level_summary: SPEAKER_01 discusses the undervalued importance of recent M&A deals, their positive impact on the stock market, and the divergence between institutional and individual investor sentiments.

video_title: Jim Cramer talks the latest in consumer M&A and spinoffs

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Hey, I'm Kramer. Welcome to Mad Money. Welcome to Kramerica. Other people are my friends. I'm just trying to make a little money. My job is not just to entertain, but to educate you. So call me at 1-800-743-CBC or tweet me at Jim Kramer. They don't start big.  But we're beginning to see deals, important ones, and they aren't getting enough attention from the market, or from the media for that matter. If anything, even the unofficial start to earnings season, they're being dismissed, and that's just plain stupid. I was on downgrade today of Goldman Sachs, the principal deal house, and I almost have to laugh about how wrongheaded that is. Sell, sell, sell.  Oh, and let's not forget, these mergers aren't just good news for the investment banks. They're good news for the entire stock market, which may be sensing something, because we started the day down big, and then rebounded with the Dow closing up 88 points. This will be advancing 0.14%, and then as a gaining 0.27%. You know what? It's actually a stupendous comeback, especially in light of some of the incredibly aggressive, some would say negative, tariff news from the president this weekend. Everywhere I went, people said, oh, boy, I guess the market's going to be down big on Monday. I said, no, not so fast.  Regular viewers know that I think we have two markets here. Big institutional investors, they've generally been selling, but individual investors have been buying stocks hand over fist. I don't think they seem to care about the tariffs. They know that everybody sold after the Liberation Day announcements, and anyone who did, it turned out to be a big mistake. They missed a big move.  But don't be so short-sighted. We're seeing the beginnings of an M&A boom here. Even as it may not feel like it, because often the deals seem, well, dowdy, or let's say, not clear yet, or in the future. I mean, you could have seen it on Kraft Times. It's reportedly breaking up soon. People are yawning. So what? They're saying big deal. I say, no, that is dead wrong.  Company said to be planning to keep its faster growing brands like maybe Heinz Ketchup, a lot of new derivatives there, Kraft Mac and Cheese, Pacific, I'm sorry, Philadelphia Cream Cheese, while separating the brands with the slowest growth like Oscar Mayer packaged foods, Velveeta Cheese. The deal putting Heinz and Kraft together sounded like a match made in heaven in 2015. How could it fail? Great name brands, orchestrated by Warren Buffett and the brilliant people from 3G Capital, the uber successful Brazilian private equity firm, felt like the center of the store blockbuster.  But then people stopped going to the center aisles of the supermarket, and that spelled trouble for Oscar Mayer, for Jell-O, for Miracle Whip, for Maxwell's, for Velveeta, which apparently can survive thermonuclear war, and Cheez Whiz of Whiz Whip fame if you go to Geno's in Philly, which remains my go-to place when I head to the city of Brooklyn.  Here's what's amazing. People now think these brands have no value. But you know what. That's what they said about W.K. Kellogg. The cereal business when it split with Kellogg Nova the fast growing part of the Kellogg family which of course got a bid until the cereal choir couldn't couldn't resist C.R.E.A.L. and S.E.R.I.A.L. cereal choir. Ferraro stepped up and paid three point one billion for the maker of Fruit Loops and Corn Flakes. That was some deal last week. It was amazing.  Sure it's supposed to be a nightmare in a world where human health and human services secretary RFK Jr. is on a crusade against food coloring. But it was a dream come true for Ferraro which has spent 13 billion dollars in 10 years to expand around the globe. They don't want to be just a small Italian company. My feeling is that if Giovanni Ferraro sees value in food loops he might see some value in some of the Kraft Heinz brands too. Or consider Kenview.  Two years ago this company was spun off by Johnson and Johnson which went to unload his fantastic consumer business. Think like Tylenol, Neutrogena, Listerine, Aveeno, Sudafed, Pepsin, Band-Aid, Zyrtec and so many others all under one roof. The company picked this fellow Thibaut Mangan. He's the leader. He was the leader of J&J's consumer health division to run it.  We learned today that he was sacked after activist pressure and Kirk Perry, a current director, was named interim CEO. Kenview also announced a strategic review of its brand stable. That's what we're hoping will happen at Kraft Heinz. Is this shocking? Was it amazing that Kenview already got rid of the CEO in two years? Well, yes, if you saw the numbers.  Can you reported minus 4 percent organic growth. And Walsh was expecting plus 2 to 4 percent. But I bring this up because more deals are coming in that space. Any one of the majors we thrilled to snap some of these brands because there's very little organic growth in the industry. The only way you can have any growth is by it.  All right, now how about this merger today between Beckman Dickinson, the Life Science and Diagnostics Division, which have been shopped extensively, and Waters, a really strong company. We've had them on. A dominant player in exactly those fields. The deal was done in a very confusing reverse Morris Trust way, which is one of those tax saving situations that the street almost always hates, but the CEOs think is so smart. And they hate it because they aren't easy. They're not clean.  The merger was greeted with horrors for waters which saw its stock plunge 13.5 percent. That's part of the greeting. It shouldn't have been down that much but people didn't understand it. Back in things since getting a thirty nine point two percent stake in the newly combined waters it enters tell you this morning its stock actually finished in the black.  seemed like a great deal to me, especially because the company got $4 billion in cash and assumed $4 billion in debt. Really good deal for Beckton Dickinson. But again, it's hard to get your head around, so it didn't bring out many buyers, at least not today. Believe me, that will change and people say that not everyone lost. Oh, by the way, big winners included Barclays, which represented Waters in Citi, worked with Beckton Dickinson in a $17 billion transaction. They made out like bandits.  Well, how about one of tonight's guests, Huntington Bank shares, which announced today it was buying Veritex. I thought it was a tech company. No, it's a Dallas-based bank for $1.9 billion. I know, not huge, but it puts Huntington in the queue to shed its regional status, become much more of a national bank, at least in the parts of the nation that are good for business. CEO Steve Steinauer says that Veritex will help his Ohio-based bank move into a number of cities in Texas, which is one of the great growth states in the union.  I think this is the kind of deal we'll start to see more and more of now that we have a new banking regulatory regimen and antitrust authorities that won't reflexively block acquisitions. We'll talk to Steve Steiner later in the show about how this acquisition fits into Huntington's aggressive long term plans. In the end what matters is that deals are getting done even if they're sometimes being done at prices that don't people don't like like the waters deal.  I'm extremely confident that someone will want some of Kenview, if not all of Kenview, because those brands grow slowly. But if you put a bunch of them together, you might have something that Wall Street is very excited about. And again, it's not just about the takeover targets. These M&A deals are incredibly lucrative for the banks that orchestrate them.  The results won't necessarily be seen this quarter, so I can see why Citizens JMP, a brokerage house, might take Goldman Sachs from buy to hold. Goldman reports Wednesday, and you won't see the bump in numbers from the deal market yet. However, these Heart of July deals are terrific for the fall. You don't usually get a lot of deals during the summer, and I don't think it makes sense to sell Goldman here and then try to get back in it later. Good luck.  Even if they miss the quarter on Wednesday, it's not going to stay down for long. I'm clearly not alone as the stock actually rallied more than eight bucks today despite this downgrade. Here's the bottom line. You don't get a wave of deals out of nowhere. You get a ripple and then ever bigger waves. Right now we're in the ripple stage. That's when it's best to do some buying.  By the way, even if you think brands like Maxwell Health and Visine and Corn Pops died years ago, don't worry about it. They may not be excited to you, but there are plenty of potential buyers who are excited about that. We'd be happy to snap them up, and the regulators are no longer blocking every M&A deal under the sun. As we head into the bank earnings tomorrow, don't think about the past with Washington leaning against every deal. Think about the future, where it looks like the government is encouraging deals and is in no mood to get in the way of capitalism, at least the way we used to know it. Let's go to Rick in Oklahoma.  Booyah. Booyah. Rick, what's up? I've been a club member for about two years. Oh, excellent. Hello?

Not bad Jay.

lines.text: How are you. I'm doing excellent. Thank you.  Hey, I'm a longtime listener and Charter Club member. Thanks for helping me retire early.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: There you go. That's as I told Casey Sullivan, our boss, we are changing people's lives. It's different from compensation that that you're used to with dollars. It's a different kind of compensation. I like it more. How can I help you?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I used to work hard for my money. Now my money's working hard for me. In January, I started building a large position and it's best to breed company. Now I'm in the house of pain.  I agree that it doesn't matter where stocks been. It's about where it's going. And I don't think this company is going to meet earnings expectations later this month. And we'll keep calling. Anyway I want to sell half my position now and the rest into any strength before earnings. Maybe invest the proceeds in one of my growth stocks. This stock flat line that looks like dead money. What are your thoughts on United Health.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: You know what. United Health is very very tricky and it might be a long term turn. But I will tell you this. Steve Hemsley is the only person I know to possibly turn this thing around. Hemsley is back as CEO. He was amazing. I think you have to have fortitude to be in it. I don't like this situation because there's so many winners as you say. But at least I want people to know that I think Hemsley is the real deal.  All right look you don't get a wave of deals out of nowhere. And now we're starting to see something happen. I think it's a sign that you got to do some buying. Look at the dip today. It was such a great opportunity again. My money tonight is one one year since CrowdStrike to outage took down millions of PCs worldwide. And I'm sitting down with the company's bankable CEO to dig into their  incredible recovery efforts. Then Zimmer Biomet announced an acquisition this morning that will strengthen its robotic surgery portfolio. I mentioned a couple of acquisitions not this one too small but I'm hearing about robots in the future and what they're going to do because that company is not growing fast enough. And I think this might accelerate it. And it's steel season. As I've said Huntington Bank shares are staffing up Texas based vertex.  What does it mean for the Lone Star State? What does it mean for the Buckeye State? What's it mean for your money? I'm going one-on-one with Huntington's top brass to break it all down. So stay with Brinkman.

summary.SPEAKER_01: Jim Cramer is optimistic about the current M&A landscape, viewing it as a sign of potential growth opportunities. Cramer points out that the market is often shortsighted in dismissing these deals, especially those involving well-known brands. He also discusses the role of individual investors in driving the stock market and suggests that M&A activity is a positive indicator for the economy. Cramer provides insights into specific companies, such as Kraft Heinz, Kenview, Beckman Dickinson, and Huntington Bank, analysing their potential for growth and the impact of their acquisitions. He also acknowledges the challenges and uncertainties associated with some of these deals but remains confident in their long-term prospects.
summary.high_level_summary: Jim Cramer discusses the undervalued opportunities presented by various mergers and acquisitions (M&A) deals that are currently flying under the radar. He emphasises that these deals, though often overlooked or dismissed, signal a potential M&A boom. Cramer highlights several specific examples, including Kraft Heinz, Kenview, Beckman Dickinson, and Huntington Bank, explaining the strategic implications and the value potential for investors. He also underscores the positive impact of M&A on the overall stock market and the investment banks orchestrating these deals.

The deal putting Heinz and Kraft together sounded like a match made in heaven in 2015. How could it fail? Great name brands, orchestrated by Warren Buffett and the brilliant people from 3G Capital, the uber-successful Brazilian private equity firm, felt like the center of the store blockbuster.  But then people stopped going to the center aisles at the supermarket, and that spelled trouble for Oscar Mayer, for Jell-O, for Miracle Whip, for Maxwell's, for Velveeta, which apparently can survive thermonuclear war, and Cheez Whiz, of Whiz Whip fame, if you go to Geno's in Philly, which remains my go-to place when I head to the city of Broadway.  Here's what's amazing. People now think these brands have no value, but you know what? That's what they said about W.K. Kellogg, the cereal business, when it split with Kellanova, the fast-growing part of the Kellogg family, which, of course, got a bid. Until the cereal choir couldn't resist, C-E-R-E-A-L-N-E-S-S-E-R-I-A-L, cereal choir Ferraro stepped up and paid $3.1 billion for the make of Froot Loops and Corn Flakes. That was some deal last week. It was amazing.  Sure, it's supposed to be a nightmare in a world where Health and Human Services Secretary RFK Jr. is on a crusade against food coloring, but it was a dream come true for Ferraro, which has spent $13 billion in 10 years to expand around the globe. They don't want to be just a small Italian company. My feeling is that if Giovanni Ferraro sees value in Fruit Loops, he might see some value in some of the Kraft Heinz brands, too. Or consider Kenview.  Two years ago, this company was spun off by Johnson & Johnson, which wanted to unload its fantastic consumer business. Think like Tylenol, Neutrogena, Listerine, Aveeno, Sudafed, Pepsi, Band-Aids, Zyrtec, and so many others all under one roof. The company picked this fellow Thibaut Mangan, he was the leader of J&J's consumer health division, to run it.  We learned today that he was sacked after activist pressure and Kirk Perry, a current director, was named interim CEO. Kenview also announced a strategic review of its brand stable. That's what we're hoping will happen at Kraft Heinz. Is this shocking? Was it amazing that Kenview already got rid of the CEO in two years? Well, yes, if you saw the numbers.  Canview reported minus 4 percent organic growth, and Wall Street was expecting plus 2 to 4 percent. But I bring this up because more deals are coming in that space. Any one of the majors would be thrilled to snap some of these brands because there's very little organic growth in the industry. The only way you can have any growth is buy it.  All right, now how about this merger today between Beck and Dickinson? This was the Life Science and Diagnostics Division, which had been shopped extensively, and Waters, a really strong company. We've had them on. A dominant player in exactly those fields. The deal was done in a very confusing reverse Morris Trust way, which is one of those tax saving situations that the street almost always hates, but the CEOs think is so smart. And they hate it because they aren't easy. They're not clean.  The merger was greeted with horrors for waters, which saw its stock plunge 13.5 percent. That's part of the greeting. It shouldn't have been down that much, but people didn't understand it. Beckton Davidson is getting a 39.2 percent stake in the newly combined waters, yet after selling off this morning, its stock actually finished in the black.  Seemed like a great deal to me, especially because the company got $4 billion in cash and assumed $4 billion in debt. Really good deal for Becton Dickinson. But again, it's hard to get your head around, so it didn't bring out many buyers, at least not today. Believe me, that will change and people say that not everyone lost. Oh, by the way, big winners included Barclays, which represented Waters in Citi, worked with Becton Dickinson in a $17 billion transaction. They made out like bandits.  Well, how about one of tonight's guests, Huntington Bank shares, which announced today it was buying Veritex. I thought it was a tech company. No, it's a Dallas-based bank for $1.9 billion. I know, not huge, but it puts Huntington in the queue to shed its regional status, become much more of a national bank, at least in the parts of the nation that are good for business. CEO Steve Steinhauer says that Veritex will help his Ohio-based bank move into a number of cities in Texas, which is one of the great growth states in the union.  I think this is the kind of deal we'll start to see more and more of now that we have a new banking regulatory regimen and antitrust authorities that won't reflexively block acquisitions. We'll talk to Steve Steiner later in the show about how this acquisition fits into Huntington's aggressive long-term plans. In the end, what matters is that deals are getting done, even if they're sometimes being done at prices that people don't like, like the Waters deal.  I'm extremely confident that someone will want some of Kenview, if not all of Kenview, because those brands grow slowly. But if you put a bunch of them together, you might have something that Wall Street gets very excited about. And again, it's not just about the takeover targets. These M&A deals are incredibly lucrative for the banks that orchestrate them.  The results won't necessarily be seen this quarter, so I can see why Citizens JMP, a brokerage house, might take Goldman Sachs from buy to hold. Goldman reports Wednesday, and you won't see the bump in numbers from the deal market yet. However, these Heart of July deals are terrific for the fall. You don't usually get a lot of deals during the summer, and I don't think it makes sense to sell Goldman here and then try to get back in it later. Good luck.  Even if they miss the quarter on Wednesday, it's not going to stay down for long. I'm clearly not alone as the stock actually rallied more than eight bucks today, despite this downgrade. Here's the bottom line. You don't get a wave of deals out of nowhere. You get a ripple and then ever bigger waves. Right now, we're in the ripple stage. That's when it's best to do some buying.  By the way, even if you think brands like Maxwell House and Visine and Corn Pops died years ago, don't worry about it. They may not be excited to you, but there are plenty of potential buyers who are excited about that. We're happy to snap them up, and the regulators are no longer blocking every M&A deal under the sun. As we head into the bank earnings tomorrow, don't think about the past with Washington leaning against every deal. Think about the future, where it looks like the government is encouraging deals and is in no mood to get in the way of capitalism, at least the way we used to know it. Let's go to Rick in Oklahoma.  Booyah. Booyah. Rick, what's up? I've been a club member for about two years. Oh, excellent. Hello?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: First time caller, and thanks for all you do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Oh, thank you. It's been a tough, you know, yeah, just working around the clock right now, it seems, but I'm very delighted. Thank you so much. How can I help you?

lines.text: I have a very, very fast shout out to the OKC Thunder for winning the NBA championship.

lines.text: Absolutely. They did a good job. OK. And I have a few hundred, a few hundred pairs of wind stock.  with the company? Oh, I think when, you know, we were, we were at win earlier this year and I was very worried about China. I still am, but my, they've got a good thing going. Craig Billings is such a good manager. He's actually terrific. And I'm glad to see that stock is finally starting to move. It's still very inexpensive on a PE basis. How about we go to Jay in Washington? Jay. Hey Jimbo. How's it going? Not bad Jay. How about you? I'm doing excellent. Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Hey, I'm a longtime listener and Charter Club member. Thanks for helping me retire early.
