lines.text: There you go. That's as I told Casey Sullivan, our boss, we are changing people's lives. It's different from compensation that that you're used to with dollars. It's a different kind of compensation. I like it more. How can I help you?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I used to work hard for my money. Now my money's working hard for me. In January, I started building a large position in this best to breed company. Now I'm in a house of pain.  I agree that it doesn't matter where stock's been, it's about where it's going. And I don't think this company is going to meet earnings expectations later this month, and we'll keep calling. Anyway, I want to sell half my position now and the rest into any strength before earnings. Maybe invest the proceeds in one of my growth stocks. This stock's flatlined and looks like dead money. What are your thoughts on UnitedHealth?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You know what? UnitedHealth is very, very tricky and it might be a long-term turn. But I will tell you this, Steve Hemsley is the only person I know who could possibly turn this thing around. Hemsley's back as CEO. He was amazing. I think you have to have fortitude to be in it. I don't like this situation because there's so many winners, as you say. But at least I want people to know that I think Hemsley's the real deal.  All right, look, you don't get a wave of deals out of nowhere. And now we're starting to see something happen. I think it's a sign that you got to do some buying. Look at the dip today. It was such a great opportunity. Again, we made money tonight. It's been one year since CrowdStrike to outage took down millions of PCs worldwide. And I'm sitting down with the company's bankable CEO to dig into their  incredible recovery efforts. Then Zimmer Biomet announced an acquisition this morning that will strengthen its robotic surgery portfolio. I mentioned a couple acquisitions, not this one too small, but I'm hearing about robots in the future and what they're going to do because that company is not growing fast enough and I think this might accelerate it. And it's steel season. As I've said, Huntington Bank shares are staffing up Texas-based Vartex.  What does it mean for the Lone Star State? What does it mean for the Buckeye State? What's it mean for your money? I'm going one on one with Huntington's top brass to break it all down. So stay with.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Don't miss a second of Mad Money. Follow at Jim Cramer on X. Have a question? Tweet Cramer. Hashtag Mad Mentions. Send Jim an email to madmoneyatcnbc.com or give us a call at 1-800-743-CNBC. Miss something? Head to madmoney.cnbc.com.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's hard to believe that it's been almost a year since CrowdStrike, the cybersecurity play that we own for the Chapel Trust, accidentally caused widespread computer outages with a fully file update. Not a hack, a file update. It sent millions of systems offline, hauling businesses across the globe. Now fast forward today, though, and it's like the outage never happened. Not only is CrowdStrike stock up more than 135% from its post-outage lows, it's up almost 40% from where it was trading before the outage. That's because cybersecurity is essential, and this particular cybersecurity firm is incredibly well-run and loved in the industry.  I've never seen such a rapid executed turnaround. Can it keep running? Let's take a closer look with George Kirsch, the bankable founder and CEO of CrowdStrike. Mr. Kirsch, welcome back to Bad Money.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Great to be here, Jim.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: George, I know this was an event that you took head on. Not only did you not hide, but you went out, told everybody everything. Could you give us a bit of a minute by minute of what happened and how you swung into action?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, as you recall, Jim, you were on vacation that Friday and I had to get you out of bed or whatever you were doing to get it on the line to get in front of this and talk to the public, talk to people. Obviously, a big part of our success at CrowdStrike has been transparency and accountability. Right.  There was an issue with a configuration file that caused the outage. We were able to revert it back and then the work began to help customers recover. But the first thing that we wanted to do was to make sure everyone knew what happened and what we're going to do about it to make it right.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's funny, people regard you as a PR mastermind. I don't think it's true. I think where you are was someone who just said, here's what I'm going to do. I'm going to do it. Get ready. I'm sorry. Let's move. And that's not PR. That's just action.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: It was, Jim. You think about that day, which I certainly remember, and I'm sure you do as well, as not many CEOs are going to just run on TV and talk about this, right? They're going to consult their lawyers and PR firms and everything else. And for me, it was important to make sure that we explained what happened, that we took accountability for it, and told people how we're going to fix it and work with all of our customers, which has paid, I believe, dividends.  Love us. We have more customers because of the ability to be transparent and yeah, we had a glitch. We fixed it, but given what we've talked about and what we put out on the one year anniversary, just an update of all the changes that we've made and all the resiliency that we built in and all the safeguards.  It's been an incredible journey with our customers and partners and lots of people who pitched in. So I think we just tried to do the right thing and always keep the North Star as the customer is always in focus for us and do it right by the customer.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, I saw you in Italy. You were at that point on your tour. I mean, it wasn't like a, it was an apology tour. What can I say? And did everybody agree to see you that you called or were there some people who said, listen, don't bother. I don't want to see you ever again.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: You know, for the most part, we were able to, excuse me, talk to or see customers that wanted to see us. They understand that things happen. And in fact, there are many customers, you know, we went through what happened and why it happened and why it won't happen again, but they sort of, you know,  chuckled at the end and said, you know, they break more things than anyone else when they change their own system. So they were a bit understanding, and they realized that these sort of things can happen. But from my perspective, you know, I think it was a great to get in front of these customers to meet with them. And, you know, they want to see people that they don't, they want to actually, they don't want you. Yeah, they want to see. Yeah.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Now, you know, I was kind of disturbed by it. There's there were cyber spending cuts in this most recent in the big, beautiful bill, a one point two billion cut in cyber spending, 10 percent drop. How could anyone ever think they can get away with that? I mean, the federal government is being hacked every second.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, when I think about the federal government or any governments in general, they're certainly under cost pressure. And what CrowdStrike has been able to do with its platform strategy is reduce overall costs, reduce overall complexity, reduce the number of agents or the pieces of software that are running in an environment and give them better outcomes.  So I think for the first time you see the federal government really focused on running itself like a business and trying to drive cost and complexity out of it. With our AI technology in Charlotte, with the ability to consolidate, with the ability to understand from an intelligence perspective what these nation states are actually doing, I think it actually is going to play into our favor long term.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I was thinking about transparency and thinking about the idea that you have to own up about what happens. And I was surprised to see, I know Delta sued you, and I was looking at their annual report, and they said, this is a February 25 annual report, the airline claimed it not experienced any material cybersecurity incidents over the past three years, reported only immaterial cybersecurity expenses.  I mean, it's almost as if until the clients own up that they got hurt. I think people can say, you know what, I can get away with this. I'm not going to put any money in this.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, I mean, that's the thing. When you look at these sort of cyber issues that are out there, you know, we respond to, I don't know, probably more than 50 percent of the large breaches that are out there helping customers actually recover from them. And then generally they become customers. But a lot of times you'll see a lack of investment.  in cybersecurity until something bad happens. And I think that's one of those areas when you look at the secular trends around security, you know, security is up sometimes in the market, security is down. But at the end of the day, security and technology are always going to advance forward. The technology change is just too rapid. And all of these technologies are going to need security. So from a secular perspective,  We think it's a great place to be. And, you know, companies are going to need more and more security as the attacks continue to be more and more sophisticated.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We keep hearing about Jason Wong talking about that the machines will be able to reason and reason really well. Right now, you get a right prompt and you get it right. When the machines can reason, won't they figure out how to get into anybody? If the bad guys can program it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, that's the hard part right now. When you think about how fast AI is moving, it's hard part, but it's also an opportunity. The bad guys are moving much faster and there's always this time element of security. Obviously, you want to prevent as much as you can, but if there's an incident, you want to be able to identify it very quickly and then be able to remediate it. And with AI, it really democratizes how many more adversaries are out there, even with limited skill sets.  From that standpoint, the threat environment continues to evolve, it continues to get faster. On the same side, the defenders like CrowdStrike, who have used AI since I started the company, it was machine learning, now it's gen AI, are able to also combat what these adversaries are doing.  You've got to use AI to protect customers and you also have to use AI to protect AI. And at the end of the day, we think we're in a fantastic spot. We think we're in a leader in that position with our Charlotte AI technology.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I know when I read people like Dan Ives, who's one of my favorite, who just says, listen, you are the gold standard. I couldn't agree more. Last question I have is I speak to a lot of people who have been hacked.  They don't want to talk about it. I get that. This is pre when you have to disclose it, but also post. And they all say the same thing, which is like, you know, I got this call from George Kirchner. You want to know if I could, if he could do anything to help. But you weren't there. They weren't paying you. You do that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Yeah, we do that all the time. I mean, obviously I have relationships in the industry, but even without a relationship, you know, we try to help all the time, whether it's a customer, non customer. A lot of times what we'll see when we investigate something is we'll see an ancillary intrusion into another company and they may not be a customer of ours. So we'll routinely call him up and basically say, hey, look, we think we saw something. We're happy to help. You know, if you have other service providers, you know, work with them, but we're there to help and.  At the end of the day, security really is a community effort, and it really comes down to the people in security, it comes down certainly to technology, but you have to use the collective community to be able to protect everyone else. And we want to be good stewards of this information and help out as many people as we can.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: because your competitors all said the same thing to me, which is I have nothing but good things to say when the outage occurred. Of course, I was looking for a story about, well, what is this? How did this happen? They all said, by the grace of God, because they know how hard you work and how good your company is. Last question. Look, we bombed Iran. We're talking about going hard against Russia. The Cold War with China doesn't seem very cold. It seems very warm. So what does the geopolitical situation look like?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Whenever there's geopolitical tensions, the cyber attacks go up. We've seen it. We've seen wiper malware that's destructive malware. We've seen intrusions into critical areas that are focused on really understanding, you know, the lay of the landscape and what's happening in the governments, governments around the world, right, as things move.  So that geopolitical tension really does drive additional security needs. And as I said, it's only going to get worse as AI now comes into play and as the adversaries and even nation states leverage more and more AI, create this sort of virtual army of  agents that can attack other countries. You just have to be on your game. And I think it's a great opportunity for CrowdStrike, you know, certainly where we are today and the long term opportunity to get to our goal of 10 billion.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, thank you, George. And everyone should know you can George is very transparent. You can go back and read this one day. It'll just be a case study. We'll know. But when something goes wrong, you go the George way. You don't do anything else. George Kurtz is founder and CEO of CrowdStrike. I always love having you on, George. Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Thank you, Jim.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Yeah, buddy, he's back in for the break.

lines.text: Coming up, as pickleball injuries rise, Kramer's eyeing one company poised to cash in on America's fastest growing sport. Next.

And is it enough to get investors excited about a stock that's been more or less range bound for years? Let's talk about it with Ivan Tornos. He's the chairman, president and CEO of Zimmer Biometro. Mr. Tornos, welcome back to Made Money.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

We're going to have portable navigation, portable robotics. We're going to have mixed reality applications. And yes, we will have now the only, and I want to say that out loud, the only autonomous robot that can do more than executing surgical tasks.  he can control and understand the entire surgery. So it's breadth of portfolio, category leadership, more patient and customer choices.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So just tell me if I'm a shareholder of Monogram, you've got a very interesting structure, this CVR, which seems to me might be a good thing to have.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: It makes a lot of sense for patients. It makes a lot of sense for shareholders. This deal is EPS neutral right away from 2025 through 2027. And it's accretive after that. We generate revenue starting in 2027. And to your point, the CDR makes a lot of sense. The enterprise value of this acquisition is about $168 million. And we pay as we go.  And I hope we do end up paying everything with these earnouts, because that would mean Zimbabwean Mint really driving market share in a very meaningful way over the next five years. So again, I hope we end up paying every milestone.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I think that's a very positive attitude it could be. Ivan, tell me what's going on right now in this market, because I look at Stryker, I look at you guys. I mean, you're really an incredibly high tech company, so is Stryker.  And yet your price journeys multiples are lower than I think they should be. What would it take to get the kind of multiple expansion that you and I both know you should be getting given how high tech you really are?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Look, listen, the stock has been challenged in the past for some challenges, and there is short-term uncertainty. But what it is certain is that technology that solves meaningful problems for customers and patients, at some point, will get rewarded. So, Jim, I don't think it's any more complex than giving it some time and proving every quarter that all this innovation that we're acquiring really, truly changes the standard of care in the way that monogram technology will change the standard of care.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So let's give you some time. All right, so give me a sense of baby boomers, what they're doing, and millennials, what they're doing. And we play pickle with your pickle paddles, and we know that people who are just doing kind of non-impact exercise are suddenly doing impact exercise. They're part of the people who suddenly get hurt. I know so many people are getting new knees. It's anecdotal. I know new hips. My wife's getting a new knee, so I'm really focused on this.  And it just seems like it's like an epidemic of use. What are you seeing out there?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We love pickable players like you and your wife. We love people that are mobile. We're in the business of restoring mobility, and we've been doing since 1927. Today, one of every three primary care visits here in the U.S. is a patient with some sort of arthritis issue.  And look, there are 600 million patients on Earth that should be going to see those primary care doctors, and most of them are not doing that. We're getting older. We're getting more mobile. We want to get a better lifestyle. We want to be young again. And technology, like robotics, like smart implants, like best-in-class knee and hip products, like the ones we've been commercializing since 1927, gets you back on the pickable court.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So we are busy, but I think we're going to get busier. One last question. How about holding costs down? Does it hold costs down if you have the full, full sweet soup to nuts?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: The most important element of cost is reducing the time in the hospital, reducing the time in surgery, making sure that readmissions don't come back. Efficiency won't work. And smart technology, like monogram technology, drives efficiency and best-in-class outcomes. That means you're getting back to the pickleball court sooner. That means you're not spending time in the hospital. That means you potentially can do your surgery in an ASC, ambulatory surgical center. So yes, efficiency does reduce cost.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Well, look, congratulations on the deal. Everybody wants this stuff to be as robotic and as efficient as possible. Thank you, Ivan Tornos. He's the chairman, president, CEO of Zimmer Biomech. Good to have you on the show again, sir. Thank you. Thank you, Jim. I appreciate the time. We'll be back in a few minutes.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Coming up, everything's bigger in Texas, including Huntington Bankshare's footprint after today's acquisition. Kramer talks to the CEO about its $1.9 billion deal. Next.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: At this point, we've got a real bank merger. One of my favorites, Huntington Bank shares, the Ohio-based regional bank, announces buying the Texas-based regional bank Veritex in an all-stock deal that values the target at just under $2 billion. Now, the grand scheme of things is this is a small transaction. I didn't even know Veritex, but it helps Huntington grow in Texas, a market where it was already expanding aggressively. Plus, the company also pre-announced most of the key lines of its second quarter earnings report due Friday. The numbers look pretty darn good.  When you back out some one-time items, Huntington posted solid earnings with better than expected net interest income and fine-looking credit quality metrics. So let's dig deeper with Steve Steiner. He's the chairman and president and CEO of Huntington Bank. Here to get a better read of the situation, Mr. Steiner, welcome back to Mad Money. Jim, great to be with you again. Thank you. Okay, so Steve, let's talk about why you want to expand in Texas, how good that market is, and why Veritex is the right partner.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: But Jim, as you know, we're very large in the Midwest. And as we look to diversify our earnings and revenue capabilities throughout high growth areas, Texas is a logical next expansion for us. We've been there since 2009. We've had great growth and success.  And we've got $5.6 billion in loans outstanding. We'll cross $6 billion this year anyway. We've got a couple hundred employees in Texas. We call them colleagues. And so we're familiar with it. Texas itself is an economic powerhouse, and we're very excited to be going there with Veritex, a great organization.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: That's interesting. In the conference call, Steve, I thought it was very  When you said, look, they have an incredible story. It's very different story from most of the banks you deal with. And then even at this fellow Malcolm Holland, who I guess I imagine must be some incredible entrepreneur that a lot of people want to do business with. And he's staying on.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: He is, and think about this. He started the bank in 2010. Remember how tough it was then. And they have just been on a roll since. Malcolm is an important leader for us going forward. We partner well with banks, like we did with TCF four years ago. And that has proven to be a home run opportunity, a combination that has delivered fantastic results. We're very optimistic about doing the same with Malcolm and his team at Veritex.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

So we thought it was a good de-risking move at the right time, and we have plenty of capacity to do it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We don't anticipate another. Okay. When I read through your financials, I said to myself,  I would not necessarily call the Fed chief too late, pal. I know that in a less political time, I think people would just say he's being prudent.

But we now have the big, beautiful build pass, so we know what taxes are. If we get one, we get through the tariff uncertainties, which looks like it's going to be another month or two. I think the underlying economy is in good shape. And we're seeing that in the credit quality. And I think the industry will have good credit quality this quarter.

lines.text: The lightning round is sponsored by Charles Schwab. Coming up, new week, new acronym. Kramer's got a fresh batch of stocks to watch and reveals the names next.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And the winner is Pork.  As in P-A-R-C, your money in these four stocks to stop worrying about tariffs, China, the Fed, pretty much anything else. Just enjoy the magic carpet ride.  If you're a tape reader as I am, then you've noticed that you tend to see four stocks go by more than any others. Palantir, Applovin, Robinhood, and Coinbase. Park. They're the meme stocks of this era. Stocks that long ago kind of ceased to be stocks, at least in a traditional way. They now become chits in the great game that is the stock market. And they're moved up like the old GameStop through sheer force of buying from home gamers who refuse to sell. Except that unlike GameStop, these are all amazing growth companies.  It's exciting to see how the mean people have figured it out. Buy the stocks of companies that are doing well and don't worry about how much you pay for them if they have great growth. There will always be someone who will want to pay more for growth. And they are right, because growth is the only safety in this market. That's why today I said I wanted to find an acronym for them, not to ridicule them, but actually because I enjoy them. I'm thrilled for them. I got to see that they're getting it. I wanted a consensus.  around these four insanely strong stocks and how they just don't have any quit in them. So Park has been born. There were others that people, let's just say now many people in my Twitter file, chose to use a far less flattering anagram embracing the same four letters in reverse order, perhaps because they don't understand how this game works.  So let me tell you, first, all four of these companies are actually fabulous businesses, well run with dynamite financials, great leadership, even if their stocks have certainly rallied to gonzo levels. Palantir is among the fastest growing tech companies I can recall. It's got a projected annual growth rate of 18 to 25 percent out to 2030, with a market capitalization of $352 billion. May not sound that impressive. Two years ago, it was $35 billion.  What does Palantir do? I say, what doesn't it do? You bring Palantir in to look at patterns to figure out how to run your business better. I've never heard anyone say that they aren't terrific at what they do, making your company money almost the minute you bring them in. They're also trying to make the Pentagon more efficient, but that's a tall order. I hope they succeed. So should you.  Applovin is a hugely profitable way for companies to advertise through mobile video games, which are typically free as long as you watch the ads. This company's got software and AI solutions that make its model unassailable. They have no real competition. The revenue growth is stunning. It was a $10 billion company two years ago. Now it's $120 billion, as this is the company that can get your ad in front of everyone who plays games on their phone. I know it's richly valued. I don't care. When you have no competition, well, guess what?  You do pretty darn well. Do I have to describe Robinhood to you? It's an app. No, it's a bank. No, it's a repository of wealth for the millennials, whatever you want to call it. Robinhood has 25 million accounts and it offers ETFs, options, gold, and crypto. It came out of nowhere. This company was worth $11 billion two years ago. Now it's $88 billion. Again, incredibly profitable. Out of nowhere. It seems to have captured young people who would otherwise not bother to invest. You know what I say? Hallelujah.  Finally, Coinbase means crypto. 52 million Americans have kept their crypto there, part of 100 million users globally. It's the only crypto company in the S&P 500, so it's the perfect poster child for the group. Again, Coinbase, immensely profitable, and at 40 times earnings, it's actually the cheapest of the group. How can that be?  All right, there you got it. It's Park. Now, why did I think of this? Because on Friday, we held our CNBC Investing Club annual meeting. It was a joyous event. We really lit it up. One individual wanted to know if we'd ever recommend speculative stocks. I said, we run a charitable trust. And while I approve of speculation, most people don't, I didn't feel it was in keeping with our mission. But I thought about it all weekend. I realized that I should just give you the list of stocks where it seems like if you enter a sell order and it was found out, they'd tar and feather you.  Is there any valuation that would be too much to pay for park? I can tell you from where I stand, absolutely not. The money is parked in these names. The buyers are insatiable. They are for speculation about as great a gift as you could possibly have. At least for now and probably for some time to come. Just remember to ring the register for some of it on the way up. Try to take out your cost basis and then the ultimate thing you could do, play with the house's money. Oh, shh, I won't tell anyone that you sold it, I promise.  I like to say there's always a bull market somewhere. I promise I'd fight just for you right here. I made money. I'm Jim Cramer. I'm going to see you tomorrow.

lines.text: I'm on your page. I think the accelerated depreciation will be a huge boost to the onshore manufacturing and other expansions that companies are looking to do in the US. And so we're the fourth or fifth largest equipment financer in the country. We love this provision. We think it's going to be very significant to economic activity in 26 and beyond.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Don't miss a second of Mad Money. Follow at Jim Cramer on X. Have a question? Tweet Cramer. Hashtag Mad Mentions. Send Jim an email to madmoneyatcnbc.com or give us a call at 1-800-743-CNBC. Miss something? Head to madmoney.cnbc.com.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Expresses concern about the Fed chief's actions but acknowledges the strength of certain economic parts. Is optimistic about the potential unleashing of trillions of dollars in spending due to tax bill changes, particularly depreciation and R&D credits, which many people underestimate.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Agrees with SPEAKER_00 on the prudence of the Fed's cautious approach to interest rates, drawing parallels with the 1980s economic situation. Highlights the positive impact of the recently passed tax bill, specifically the accelerated depreciation provision, which is expected to boost onshore manufacturing and economic activity in the US.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Promotes the CNBC show "Mad Money" hosted by Jim Cramer. Provides various ways for viewers to engage with the show, including social media, email, and phone.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the economic outlook, the Federal Reserve's interest rate policies, and the impact of a recent tax bill.

video_title: NYC Mayor race: Andrew Cuomo to run as an independent

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: as we profile the New York City Democratic primary, a crowded field, where the field also going to be very full for the full election come November. A live look right now there in the Big Apple here on this day. And a familiar name re-entering the race, not as a Democrat, but as an independent. We're talking about Andrew Cuomo, the former governor.  Let's be joined right now by Fox 5's Linda Schmidt. Linda, thank you so much for joining us here on Live Now from Fox. This wasn't really a surprise, but what did we make of the announcement today?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: No, it definitely wasn't a surprise. But first I have to tell you, there's covering politics here in the city. It is always fun this year, particularly so. First of all, Zoran Mamdani, he crushed Andrew Cuomo in the Democratic primary. That was just three weeks ago. So since then, Andrew Cuomo has been flirting with the idea strongly of running as an independent. Now today he made it official. He is in.  Andrew Cuomo releasing this video on X late this afternoon. I am in it to win it. The former governor announcing he is staying in the race for mayor and is running as an independent. This follows Cuomo's crushing defeat to Democratic Socialist Zoran Mamdani during the Democratic primary three weeks ago. On that night, Cuomo sounded as though he was throwing in the towel. And a member of his team told me he was done.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Tonight was Assemblyman Mondani's night, and he put together a great campaign, and he touched young people and inspired them and moved them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: But over the past three weeks, Cuomo decided he has a good shot.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: The Democratic primary did not go the way I had hoped. To the 440,000 New Yorkers who voted for me, a sincere thank you. I am truly sorry that I let you down.  But as my grandfather used to say, when you get knocked down, learn the lesson and pick yourself back up and get in the game. And that is what I'm going to do.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Political pundits and strategists believe that having both Cuomo and Mayor Adams running as independents will split the votes and almost ensure that Mamdani will become the next mayor. Mayor Adams has no intention of dropping out.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Andrew is a double-digit loser in the primary. He lost by 13 points. He had his opportunity.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Cuomo is now following in his father's footsteps. In 1977, Mario Cuomo ran in the Democratic primary for mayor against Ed Koch and incumbent Mayor Abe Beame. He came in second.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I must tell you, without stretching now, we've been getting calls all morning. I got a call from one of my children at home that said, Dad, it's as though we won. Everybody's calling to congratulate us. I'm sorry we didn't win.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Mario Cuomo then chose to run as an independent in the general election, saying that supporters were urging him to do so. He lost to Ed Koch.  All right, now we're going to have to wait and see what happens in November. Now, Mario Cuomo ran as an independent for mayor back in 1977. He lost. Now his son is doing the same thing. He is running as an independent for mayor. So we're going to have to wait and see what New Yorkers think. Is he going to win? Is he going to lose? It's going to be interesting to watch.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And as you mentioned right at the outset, you kind of expect the unexpected when it comes to New York City politics. I want to ask you because it's two big personalities, Andrew Cuomo and Eric Adams. Do you think there is any chance they try to coalesce together behind one candidate to try to take down Mondani?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: You know what, anything is possible because they definitely don't want Mom Donnie, who is a democratic socialist. So people behind the scenes are working together to try to prevent him from winning the election in November. So you never know. Right now, though, they are both firm. They have planted their feet and they are saying, no, we are not dropping out. Mayor Adams is not dropping out. Andrew Cuomo clearly not dropping out because he announced that he is now officially running as a Democrat. I mean, as a independent.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: And I do want to ask you, because we saw the primary happen, a double-digit win there for Mondani, and it feels like the momentum continues on. And this final election is a few months out. He did post under that tweet for Cuomo with his fundraiser. How much momentum is Mondani trying to still maintain?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, his campaign has gained a lot of momentum since the Democratic primary. And again, that was on June 24th. So that was three weeks ago. Since then, there have been multiple unions.  major powerful unions in New York City who have in the past backed Mayor Adams, who have in the past backed Governor Cuomo, who are now backing Mom Donnie since the primary. Now, a lot of people will look at that and say, okay, so the unions are backing him, but does that mean all the rank and file members, all the members of the union, are they going to go out and vote for this candidate?  While people are not sheep, people tend to vote for who it is that they want to vote for. Some may follow the leadership of the union, but not everybody does.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, that is a very good point. And as Cuomo posted on social media, just the amount of people or the lack of people, just 14% of New Yorkers casting their ballot in that New York primary, that could sway some people as well. The turnout is significantly higher. All right, Linda, thank you so much. I appreciate you reporting here on Live Now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: You bet. Always happy to be with you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right. Thank you so much. All right. Great conversation, as always, as the New York City mayoral race. Obviously, Mondani really has a lot of momentum, the favorite heading into November. But with now Andrew Cuomo, Eric Adams as independents, they have name recognition in their favor. And again, I want to just talk about this is this is was the announcement on social media from Andrew Cuomo, the former governor, saying he's, quote, in it  to win it. Let's take you out to this, his full announcement on social media, just to give you a sense of what he said today as he really re-entered the race for a rematch of sorts with Mamdani.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Hello, I'm Andrew Cuomo. And unless you've been living under a rock, you probably know that the Democratic primary did not go the way I had hoped.  To the 440,000 New Yorkers who voted for me, a sincere thank you. Thank you for believing in me, in my agenda, and in my experience. And I am truly sorry that I let you down. But as my grandfather used to say, when you get knocked down, learn the lesson and pick yourself back up and get in the game. And that is what I'm going to do. The fight to save our city isn't over.  Only 13% of New Yorkers voted in the June primary. The general election is in November, and I am in it to win it. My opponent, Mr. Mondani, offers slick slogans, but no real solutions. We need a city with lower rents, safer streets, where buying your first home is once again possible, where child care won't bankrupt you. That's the New York City we know. That's the one that is still possible.  You haven't given up on it, and you deserve a mayor with the experience and ideas to make it happen again, and the guts to take on anyone who stands in the way. Every day, I'm going to be hitting the streets, meeting you where you are, to hear the good and the bad, problems and solutions, because for the next few months, it's my responsibility to earn your vote. So let's do this. I'll see you out there.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: All right, thank you so much for that. That was what Andrew Cuomo said on social media earlier on today as he's staying in the race despite that wipeout in the Democratic primary in New York some three weeks ago.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Host discusses Cuomo's independent run, its implications, and the current state of the NYC mayoral race with Linda Schmidt.
summary.SPEAKER_03: Cuomo acknowledges his primary loss but expresses determination to run again as an independent, emphasising his experience and vision for the city. He criticises his opponent and highlights key issues like crime and affordability.
summary.SPEAKER_04: Linda Schmidt reports on Cuomo's announcement, its timing, the potential vote split, historical context, and union endorsements. She notes the low primary turnout and its possible impact.
summary.high_level_summary: Andrew Cuomo announces he is running as an independent in the New York City mayoral race after losing the Democratic primary. This move splits the independent vote, potentially benefiting Democratic Socialist Zoran Mamdani. The conversation discusses Cuomo's chances, the historical context of his father's similar run, and the current political dynamics in NYC.

video_title: NEW DETAILS: Kentucky shootings leave 2 dead, state trooper hospitalized | LiveNOW from FOX

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Welcome back to Fox News, I'm Andy Mack.  in Lexington on Sunday. A live picture right there. It all started after a traffic stop near an airport. Asher, thank you so much for joining us. The gunman may have had a connection to the victims at the church. Explain this to me.

Then, according to police, House carjacked another vehicle and took off. He ended up at the Richmond Road Baptist Church, about 16 miles away, where he shot four more people.  Witnesses say he was looking for the mother of his children there, but when he found out that she wasn't there, witnesses say he killed the pastor's wife, 72 year old Beverly Gum. Gum was the grandmother of his children and Gums family says how shot her right in front of a two month old baby.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Thank you.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right. Thank you so much. A sad story there. And obviously some connections to those victims. Two dead, three injured in this on that Richmond Road Baptist Church. And you saw the connections. Let's take you right now out to this update from earlier on today with Lexington police providing an update. They did reveal the gunman's name today, the identity of him, Guy House. Let's listen in to this update from Kentucky.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Good afternoon. Again, I am Sergeant Badge Tower with the Lexington Police Department Public Information Office. Thank you for coming today. We want to provide some limited updates on the events occurring at Terminal Drive and Old Richmond Road yesterday, Sunday, July 13th, 2025.  Chief Lawrence Weathers will provide an update on the investigation. This information will be limited as the Kentucky State Police will be taking over as the lead investigating agency of the entire incident. The Lexington Police Department will not be able to answer any questions. And going forward, all updates will be provided by and all inquiries should be directed to the Kentucky State Police.  Chief Weathers is joined today by Kenneth Payne with one Lexington. And also with Sergeant Matt Sudduth with the Kentucky State Police. Chief Weathers.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you, Sergeant Towery.  Good afternoon, everybody. As Sergeant Tower said, we want to provide a limited update about the shootings that occurred yesterday on Terminal Drive and Old Richmond Road. The suspect has been identified by the Fayette County Coroner's Office as Guy House, age 47.  The two deceased female victims from Richmond Road Baptist Church have been identified as Beverly Gum, age 72, and Christina Combs, age 34. On behalf of the Lexington Police Department, I would like to extend my condolences to the families of Ms. Gum and Ms. Combs, as well as the other victims and their families.  I would also like to provide you with an update on the two other injured victims from the Richmond Road Baptist Church. Both of the male victims are reported to be in critical condition. Out of respect for the victims and their families, we will not be releasing their identities.  As Sergeant Towery mentioned, the Kentucky State Police will be taking over as the primary investigating agency, and any follow-up information will be released by the Kentucky State Police. The officers who responded to the church encountered a very tragic scene. They began providing first aid and care to the individuals who had been shot  until paramedics arrived. I'm proud of the responding officers. I'm proud of them and their actions to care for the victims. The officers went from securing the scene to assisting the victims in an instant.  Yesterday's violence was a tragedy, and it impacted many people in our community from the loss of Miss Gum and Miss Combs, the other victims who sustained injuries, including a Kentucky State trooper, their families, the Richmond Baptist Church family and many others.  we join them and the community to mourn this tragedy. Just as our community experiences devastating event, we saw our community come together and neighbors helping neighbors from the community member who called to report a Kentucky state trooper being shot.  the work of our officers and employees, and all of those who have stepped up to offer support, we want to thank you. Your efforts to show that even in dark times, there's always light. In incidents like this, we want to make sure we continue to remember the victims, their families, and all who were impacted by this tragedy.  I would like to thank all the government leaders, law enforcement and community partners, our community members, and even people outside of Kentucky who assisted with this investigation or offered support to us and the victims. I would also like to thank Mayor Linda Gordon and her office for their continued support of the Lexington Police Department and our officers.  with several of our officers being involved in the shooting of the suspect.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right, just listening in there to Kentucky officials provide an update as they have identified this, the suspect, as Guy Howes after the shooting that took the lives of two individuals, injuring three others, including a state patrol officer.

Respectively, the Dragon Bravo fire causing evacuations along the Grand Canyon's North Rim and destroying numerous buildings, including the historic North Rim Lodge. Stefan, the sky with the Southwest Area Incident Commands as fire crews are working around the clock to put the fire out.  very clear we're in an aggressive firefight. We had booked three days at the North Rim of the Grand Canyon in the cabins right there. It wasn't overcrowded with people. I could get seats on the back deck of the lodge and look out over the view. There were seats on the sofas inside. It was just magical.  But little did she know she would be some of the last people to ever see it in its glory. Early Thursday night, she was evacuated. They could see the glow of the flames and smoke as they drove out. Now she's sad for the memories that are forever lost. It makes me very sad.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04

lines.text: Lauren, thanks so much. Just really sad and really devastating, the loss of this historic lodge there in one of the nation's most beautiful locales. He says, I just spoke to park officials to get an update and offer help, thanks to everyone working so hard to contain this fire. He says, well, in the meantime, another one of our friends and colleagues here at Fox 10 Phoenix, Lindsay Ragus, she's following all of this reaction as well. She joins me in the Live Now newsroom. Lindsay, good to see you. This is a hard story to tell. What more do we know? Who have you heard from today?

We're going to tell you about it. A 2006 fire that burned very similarly.

video_title: Trump Threatens 100% Tariffs on Russia, Pledges Arms for Ukraine | Bloomberg Businessweek

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: Bloomberg Audio Studios, podcasts, radio, news. This is Bloomberg Businessweek Daily, reporting from the magazine that helps global leaders stay ahead with insight on the people, companies, and trends shaping today's complex economy. Plus, global business, finance, and tech news as it happens. The Bloomberg Businessweek Daily podcast with Carol Masser and Tim Stenevek on Bloomberg Radio.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: President Trump threatened to impose stiff financial penalties on Russia if it does not end hostilities with Ukraine. That's within 50 days while pledging fresh weapons supplies for Kiev. Trump said the levies would come in the form of secondary tariffs. Without providing details, the president has used the term in the past to describe duties imposed on countries for trading with American adversaries.  Angela Stend is senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. She's also the author of Putin's World, Russia Against the West and With the Rest. She's a former national intelligence officer for Russia and Eurasia at the National Intelligence Council, also served in the Office of Policy Planning at the U.S. Department of State. Angela, good to have you with us this afternoon. Secretary Lutnick followed up afterward. He said it would be a secondary sanction or secondary sanctions, I should say. What exactly does that mean for a country that has had sanctions on it for years?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: So the actual tariffs or sanctions on Russia wouldn't mean very much tariffs because we barely trade with Russia. I think $5 billion last year. But what that would mean is sanctions on China, sanctions on India. They're the two largest purchases of Russian oil. Probably a country like Turkey as well, which purchases a lot of Russian oil.  So they are threatening those countries. I believe that President Trump said 100 percent tariffs. There's a Senate bill which would impose 500 percent tariffs, secondary tariffs on these countries that purchased Russian hydrocarbons. So that's the real threat. Not so much to Russia. Angela, how meaningful would it be for these countries?  So, I mean, it would be meaningful because they are the largest purchases of Russian oil. But then we don't know how they might retaliate. India, of course, is a country that's been drawing closer to the United States.  So to have that kind of tariff on India would also, I think, affect other aspects of the US-Indian relationship. So I think they're kind of all waiting. I should say that saying that Russia has 50 days to end the war, you have to realize that Russia is now in the middle of a very brutal summer offensive. And if you give them 50 days, the summer will be over by then. So Russia can still do an enormous amount of damage to Ukraine in those 50 days.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, in terms of moving the needle on actually ending this conflict, Dr. Stent, is this enough in your view to actually push Russia to stop its bombardment of Ukraine?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, the most important thing at the moment are the weapons supplies. I mean, the Ukrainians desperately need air defenses. They need those Patriot batteries. And today, President Trump said that there's 17 of them available. So what's going to happen is European allies are going to purchase  American Patriot missiles and other weapons, they are then going to give them to Ukraine. So that enables President Trump to say to his base, well, we're not spending any more money on Ukraine. Whether that's enough to help Ukraine really give the message to Putin that he cannot win this war,  I think that's doubtful. I mean, Putin's not going to stop until he really believes that he's not going to win this. And for that, the Ukrainians need an enormous amount of weapons, including, in the end, weapons that could strike Moscow. But we haven't said that we're going to provide those yet.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Well, let's listen to exactly what the president said earlier. Here he is in the Oval Office with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte. We're we're going to be sending them weapons and they're going to be paying for them.  We, the United States, will not be having any payment made.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: We're not buying it, but we will manufacture it, and they're going to be paying for it. This is a very big deal we've made. This is billions of dollars worth of military equipment is going to be purchased from the United States, going to NATO, et cetera. And that's going to be quickly distributed to the battlefield. Ukraine will take it up. And, you know, say what you want about Ukraine.  When the war started, they had no chance. And they still would have had no chance if the equipment, they had the best equipment.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Because we do make the best planes and missiles, and we make the best military equipment in the world, by far.  That was President Trump earlier today. He was in the Oval Office with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte. Dr. Stead, I want to talk about the weapons portion of this and the significance that you see in an environment where many in the Republican Party were happy not to provide Ukraine with any aid. How do you view this politically for President Trump and also whether or not you think this is enough  of a move by the United States, and again, the president saying the United States is going to provide them, NATO member states are going to pay for them, if that's enough to give Ukraine the edge against Russia.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, so first of all, this certainly has split the MAGA base because there's still significant numbers of people, beginning with Vice President Vance, who think that we shouldn't be supplying Ukraine. And then you had the undersecretary in the Defense Department, Elbridge Colby, apparently order the end of supplying Ukraine with weapons.  because he thinks only the Europeans should do this. President Trump reversed that order that apparently he hadn't heard about before. So yes, I think this is still a contentious issue within his base. Is that enough to help Ukraine? I mean, Ukraine just needs an enormous amount of these  Patriot batteries. If it gets 17 extra ones, that's terrific. Ukrainians themselves are manufacturing their own drones now. They're also making deals with European countries to co-produce them. But we really don't know whether that is enough, because the Russians are also stepping up their production of weapons. And they're also using their drones in very creative ways to try and get around some of the barriers that the Ukrainians have put in their way.  So at the moment, things are very difficult for Ukraine. And I think only very significant numbers of weapons can help them push this back. And they also do have a mobilization problem. Russia has many more people that can mobilize. It's got North Koreans fighting for the Russians. The Ukrainians do face the shortage. And they are so far refusing to draft 18 to 25-year-olds.  But they are under pressure from some of the Western countries to do so.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Angela, we saw a report last week that North Korea is supplying as much as 40 percent of Russia's ammunition. Just how much of an asset is this for Russia?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Oh, North Korea is an enormous asset for Russia now. We now hear they may send as many as 30,000 more Koreans troops to Russia to help and with the ammunition. So without North Korea, it would be very difficult for Russia to do what it's doing. Iran is less important now, by the way, because the Russians are producing their own drones. But I would say the single most important country in terms of weapons supplies right now is North Korea.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Dr. Angela Sten, we always appreciate you taking the time and joining us on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. Dr. Angela Sten is senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, also the author of Putin's World, Russia Against the West, and with the rest.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You're listening to the Bloomberg Businessweek Daily podcast. Catch us live weekday afternoons from two to five Eastern. Listen on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with the Bloomberg Business app. Or watch us live on YouTube.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Let's talk about the world of Elon Ank. The money behind Elon Musk's trillion dollar empire is increasingly flowing in one direction, and that's toward AI. Musk said on Sunday that he plans to hold a vote by Tesla shareholders on whether the company should invest in XAI, the cash burning AI startup that he founded two years ago. It comes shortly after SpaceX, his mammoth rocket launch company, agreed to invest about two billion dollars into the AI firm. This, according to people familiar with the matter.  Dana Hall and Ed Ludlow write about Elon turning to Tesla and SpaceX to fuel his ambitions. Dana Hall is Bloomberg News senior technology reporter. She's also a contributor to the Elon Inc. podcast. You can catch new episodes of that every single week wherever you get your podcast. She joins us from our San Francisco bureau.  Dana, Tesla is, I know it's not a car company, because we're told it's not a car company. I heard you chuckle there. We're told it's not a car company. They do Optimus, they do the self-driving stuff, but listen, what moves the company's stock? How many cars they delivered? Do they have any business, according to the folks you talked to, making an investment in this money-losing AI company?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, so the money needs of XAI are enormous. I mean, billions of dollars are pouring into artificial intelligence. There's huge need for compute and data centers. And XAI is building out this big data center in Memphis called Colossus. And as we've seen so often with Elon Musk, he runs five companies, but they're not really separate. They have overlapping investors, engineers, management,  sometimes boards, and Musk often, I don't want to say robs Peter to pay Paul, but he will co-mingle his companies in a way that is very unlike any other corporate CEO that we've seen. And I think in his mind, AI is the future.  Tesla is also an AI company. If they can invest in XAI, they maybe get preferential access to Grok. We're already seeing that Tesla is now integrating Grok, the chat bot, into its cars. We know that Tesla has sold Megapax to XAI for that Memphis data center. So, they already are working together quite a bit.  And I think, you know, a lot of investors, particularly the retail investors, see this as a way to get in on XAI. I mean, so there probably is a fair amount of shareholder support for this idea, at least from the retail side.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Yeah. And speaking of support, so of course, Musk is planning to hold a vote by Tesla shareholders on whether or not the EV maker should invest in XAI. Does Elon usually let other people, including his shareholders and supporters, weigh in on his decision making?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, so Tesla's a publicly traded company, and so this would be a management proposal that would likely be spelled out in the proxy. We know that Tesla is having a shareholder meeting on November 6th. We have not seen a proxy yet, but this idea is something that Musk has floated for over a year now. I mean, I think he first polled people on X, like should Tesla invest $5 billion in XAI like a year ago? And so it sounds like now it's likely to be in the proxy.  So, I mean, because it is a publicly traded company, shareholders have to weigh in. It would be a sizable investment for Tesla.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I want to read a post that you link to in the piece that you and Ed wrote. It's from Grok on X. First off, we deeply apologize for the horrific behavior that many experienced. We have removed that deprecated code and refactored the entire system to prevent further abuse.  This was on Friday, Dana, and it was about the horrific behavior. It was referred to itself as Mecca Hitler, and it had posts that praised Adolf Hitler and appeared to call the Holocaust, quote, effective. This is this is the chat bot for XAI. Is this thing ready? Like like if you're a Tesla investor,  Do you have pause about sending money from Tesla to a company that has made a mistake such as this in the AI race?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I know, right? That is a very good question. Well, I think like when you say Tesla investor, you know, there's sort of two camps of investors. There are institutional investors, a lot of index funds. You know, Tesla obviously joined the S&P 500 back in December 2020. And then there's this very rapid  retail shareholder base that is wildly enthusiastic, very on board with Elon, and they're really betting on Elon in the future. And if the future is not car sales, it's got to be something. And so I see that this is all part of Elon's big plan to really position himself  as a leader in AI. Remember that XAI was founded after OpenAI by his rival, Sam Altman, came out with ChatGPT, and so you're seeing Grok try to be a big player in this field. Yes, they have absolutely made mistakes. The whole Hitler thing from last week was horrible. I think it's notable that Grok apologized, or XAI apologized, and they seem to be sorting it out.  Yeah, I mean, the other question I have is like, do Tesla owners want Grok in their cars? I mean, I'm assuming there's a way to opt out or not, you know, enable that if you want, but I don't think that when people buy a Tesla, they necessarily signed up for Grok.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So Musk has, of course, really stepped away from that whole political sphere that he was in for a little while, but... Except when he tweets. I was going to say, is it fair to say that that's the case? He's trying to step away, I will say.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I don't really buy that, to be honest. I mean, he had to step away from Doge because his time as a special government employee had a limit. You can only serve X number of days per year as an SGE. And so that came to an end, but he just can't help himself.  feel strongly about something, like he cannot keep his mouth shut. So we saw him tweeting over the weekend about the Epstein files. I mean, and he is still talking about creating a third party. He has, you know, for all intents and purposes, quote unquote, stepped away from Doge. But I think he still has ambitions to be a player in the midterms to potentially really start this third party. And, you know, he has poured so much money into  American politics already, I don't see him going quietly into the night on that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: As we think about ex-AI, I mean, is there still a conversation about his head being in too many places right now with too many business ventures?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I mean, that's an ongoing perennial criticism of Elon, that he's spread too thin, that he's distracted, that he's got too many things on his plate, but that's the way he's operated for years. I mean, he simultaneously ran Tesla and SpaceX for decades, and SpaceX is the most valuable company in the world right now, and Tesla still has a $1 trillion market cap.  I feel like a lot of long-term investors see past that, and they think that Elon is a genius who can hyper-focus where he needs to and when he needs to, and that that criticism hasn't really held up. He is able to execute when he's hyper-focused, and he hyper-focuses a lot, like every day.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: How can we look to Tesla's acquisition of SolarCity close to a decade ago as sort of a blueprint for a private investment, or an investment in a private company such as XAI?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, it was the same kind of deal, right, where SolarCity was struggling and really needed a bailout, and so Tesla bought SolarCity, which was rife with all of these conflicts of interest because Elon was the chair of the board, was the largest investor, so it was like, you know, some people forget, like, Tesla acquired SolarCity. I mean, SolarCity was a company that Elon founded with his cousins, so this was, and you know, and now, I mean, Tesla still has a solar roof division somewhat, but it's the same thing, like,  Tesla has money, XAI needs money. Elon's going to go to his board and say, we should invest. They're going to bring it to the shareholders. I'm sure there'll be a campaign around it. I would imagine that it could pass, unless there's really strong institutional opposition. The SolarCity deal was rife with all these conflicts and it went to court, but ultimately Tesla prevailed and it ended up being okay for shareholders. They took a bath initially, but the company has still achieved great heights.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Chief Investment Officer Nancy Tangler said that an investment into XAI will further dilute the declining EV business. Is this something that you're hearing from sources as well?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I mean, absolutely. Tesla used to be all about selling cars. The company used to say that it was going to make 20 million cars a year by 2030. They've completely abandoned that. Elon now tweets things about how  owning a car will be like owning a horse like the future is all about shared mobility and ride sharing and AI and optimists and You know, we haven't heard anything about the Mexico plant in months I mean, I think that that plant is basically dead for all intents and purposes. So I  Yeah, I mean, you know, Tesla has got to find a way to make money. And if they can catch the AI wave and get a return on their investment in XAI, ultimately, that's seen as a good thing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: In about 30 seconds or less, how's SpaceX doing in regards to the everyone trying to do the space race right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: SpaceX is the dominant launch provider in the United States, full stop. I mean, there's no other way to get to the International Space Station except for on SpaceX in the United States. So I think that they, and they have Starlink. So I mean, even though they've had some setbacks with Starship, they are the dominant provider in the U.S.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So next time the president threatens to cut off contracts with SpaceX, just remember what Dana said, full stop. They're the dominant provider of this technology.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Go ahead. The Pentagon just gave XAI a contract today with some other AI companies as well, up to $200 million per each to do AI for the government. So those contracts keep flowing.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Dana Hall, Bloomberg News senior technology reporter, also contributed to the Elon Inc. podcast. Catch new episodes of the podcast each week.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: This is the Bloomberg Businessweek Daily podcast. Listen live each weekday, starting at 2 p.m. Eastern on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with the Bloomberg Business app. You can also listen live on Amazon Alexa from our flagship New York station. Just say Alexa, play Bloomberg 1130.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: President Trump and his allies have seized upon a new way to criticize Fed Chair Jay Powell. His handling of an expensive renovation of the Federal Reserve's headquarters.  I think if Jerome Powell stepped down, it would be a great thing. I don't know that he's going to, but he should. Jerome Powell's been very bad for our country. We should have the lowest interest rate on Earth, and we don't. He just refuses to do it, and yet he's spending $2.5 billion rebuilding the Fed.  That was President Trump just yesterday in Maryland. This construction project offers the clearest example yet of how Trump and those in his orbit are looking for every opportunity to scrutinize Jerome Powell's leadership at the Central Bank, even beyond his economic stewardship. Bloomberg News Federal Reserve reporter Amara Omokwe joins us now from our Washington, D.C. bureau. A $2.5 billion  renovation, the topic of the renovation coming up when Jay Powell defended the renovations as necessary during his testimony to the Senate Banking Committee late last month. Some of those are just flatly misleading. The idea of elevators, you know, it's the same elevator. It's been there since the building was built. So that's a mischaracterization. And some of those are no longer in the plans. You know, that's earlier. The plans have continued to evolve.  I do want to bring in Amara Amokwe. She's been writing about this. She's Bloomberg News Federal Reserve reporter. She joins us from Washington, D.C. $2.5 billion is what is at issue here. What exactly is the Federal Reserve renovation happening right now? And who started planning this? Like, give us the details here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, so the Fed is currently renovating two historic buildings here in Washington, D.C., and they've said those renovations are basically meant to consolidate all their operations in one place and really restore these two historic buildings that are very old and that the Fed says haven't been, like, comprehensively restored in quite some time. And so that's kind of the Fed's rationale for these renovations. They were approved by the Fed's board.  several years  And then also taking issue with what Fed Chair Jerome Powell said about some of the design features in the renovation when he was on the Hill last month talking about these renovations. And some of the administration officials are basically alleging that Powell was not truthful in that testimony.  And that seems to be what they're using to kind of lay the groundwork to say that perhaps President Trump has cause to remove Chair Powell from his position on the Fed's Board of Governors, because, of course, to remove someone from the Fed's Board of Governors, you have to meet a very high legal standard, which is cause something like malfeasance or neglect of duty. And so some administration officials seem to be trying to use this renovation issue to try and establish that cause.  Amara, as you mentioned, this is not new. This renovation has been going on for quite some time now. But is this the first time that the magnitude of the renovation is really being questioned? Yeah, I would say so. And what kind of set this off was media reports about some of the features in the renovation. Basically, there was a media report that sort of characterized some of the features in the renovation as very lavish, very extravagant. And so that led to Republican senators, when Chair Powell was on the Hill,  last month, that led them to sort of question him over why there are some of these features, why the costs for the project have increased over the years. And so that is what kind of sort of brought this issue into the forefront recently. And then we've really seen the administration kind of seize upon it and use it as part of their overall sort of criticism of Chair Powell's stewardship of the Fed, both, you know, when they're talking about  his interest rate, his stance on interest rates, and then also when they're talking about how he has managed this construction project.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: What are observers of the Federal Reserve saying about this and to what extent this could be? You know, this is not part of the Fed's dual mandate by any means, right? Stable prices, maximum employment. The Fed chair has laser focused on that mandate that comes from Congress. He tells us that when we hear from him.  every few weeks. Well, what are observers saying about this sort of, I'm not going to call it a sideshow because that's, you know, that's editorializing a little bit, but it's not core to the Fed's mission by any means. And it's, it's very political.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: it is  We know that Chair Powell's term is up next year, next May. And the search, President Trump's search for the next Fed chair is also on. And so it really does raise questions about what that search will look like and who President Trump will ultimately pick. Is he going to pick someone who is going to be more receptive to his views and the pressure that he puts on them when it comes to monetary policy and some of these other issues about the institutional management of the Fed?  I think even beyond chair power, it really does raise these questions about what the Fed looks like when the next chair takes over.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Amara, in regards to this renovation, what can really be done at this point? I mean, the builders are building. This has been going on for some time. Does the president then have the authority to come in and just cancel the entire thing, scale it back?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: How does that look?  I mean, I think the Fed has said that a lot of different input went into getting approved for this project, including the National Capital Planning Commission. Like, there are a lot of different bodies that sort of weighed in on this project. And I don't think it's within the president's purview to sort of stop the project. Like, in the law, the Fed has authority over its own buildings, because the Fed in so many ways is an independent agency.  But I think what the administration and what President Trump are really trying to do, they're trying to sort of question the optics around this, right? Bill Pulte, one of the administration officials who has really focused in on this renovation, will say things like, you know, Jerome Powell is keeping interest rates high.  and making affordability difficult for Americans while he builds himself a $2.5 billion palace, right, essentially. I'm paraphrasing. But that's essentially, like, some of the lines of criticism. And so what you really see administration officials doing is really calling into question the credibility of Chair Powell. And, again, you can't separate those efforts from the efforts that the administration is putting forward to try and make the Fed follow their lead on interest rates.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Tomorrow, what happens to a Federal Reserve, to the Federal Reserve, if Fed Chair Powell is forced out in some way? There's a Deutsche Bank analyst who essentially says that we could see a drop of at least three to four percent in the trade-weighted dollar. This is George Saravelos of Deutsche Bank. There would be 30 to 40 basis points off in fixed income. He essentially argues that all this is underpriced.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, I think any economist you talk to, any investor who you talk to will say, look, if Fed Chair Jerome Powell is pushed out, or if there's any sort of inkling that the Fed is bowing to President Trump's pressure, and any questions start to arise about whether the Fed is continuing its independence, like, that is not good for the economy, one, and then that is not good for sort of the buy America trade, right? We could see pressure on the dollar. We could see pressure on treasuries.  To be clear, President Trump has continued to say that he's not going to fire Chair Powell. But I think these sorts of questions, again, sort of raise the stakes when it comes to what's going to happen with Chair Powell's replacement. Because any feeling that the Fed's independence is being compromised or that we have a person who's more likely to listen to Trump could be bad for sort of the Buy America trade.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Amara Mokwe, Bloomberg News Federal Reserve reporter joining us from Washington, D.C.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You're listening to the Bloomberg Businessweek Daily Podcast. Catch us live weekday afternoons from 2 to 5 Eastern. Listen on Apple CarPlay and Android Auto with the Bloomberg Business app or watch us live on YouTube.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Fastenal shares rising as much as 6.4% earlier in the session. They're up right now 3.4%. It's a new all-time high for the company after they reported net sales for the second quarter that came in in line with estimates from analysts up 8.6% over the same period last year.  This is a $52 billion market cap company. They distribute construction and industrial supplies, nuts, bolts, screws, anchors, rivets, and other fasteners, as well as industrial, janitorial, and safety supplies, cutting tools as well. The company sells to builders, manufacturers, governments, and more.  Really, it's a great read on the entire industrial and manufacturing economy, specifically here in the U.S. We've got with us the CEO of Fastenal, Daniel Flornes. He joins us from Winona, Minnesota. Dan, welcome to Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. Shares up today. Shares up more than 25% so far this year. New all-time high. In the earnings release, though, you said that, quote, the market conditions remain sluggish. What conditions specifically?  You know, we sell to a wide range of customers and industries, as you mentioned, across North America and in 26 countries in total, but mostly in North America. Our customer base has been relatively subdued for the last several years. In the fall of 2022, we saw some indicators saying it was going to slide. And we felt that as we moved into the second and third quarters of 2023. And it's been really weak since then.  About 30% of our business is very production-centered business within manufacturing. So are there any signs that that part of the business is improving, that those customers are seeing sentiment improve? Are you hearing anything from them?  I think the biggest sign that we're seeing is the knife has stopped dropping. You know, we were trying to catch that falling knife for a two year period. When I talk to our district and regional leadership throughout the world, the feedback I hear is, you know, they're not talking about this $200,000 a month customer whose business is off 60, 70%. You have a much more stability. Now it might be stable at a lower level than it would have been two years ago,  but it's much more stable and so it allows our inherent growth to shine through. So we've really been in this prolonged downturn, especially in the industrial economy. Are you seeing any particular green shoots or signs of inflection? And if so, which markets are you most optimistic about?  Yeah, so we're seeing some green shoots. For us, we are seeing some impact in energy. However, I would say that's probably more us taking market share than it is a lift in the tide.  About 25% of our business is outside of the industrial. And within there, we're selling, we're doing quite well. I hear a lot of commentary from our folks with data center builds, with even warehousing customers. And we've made really good inroads over the last three years into the government sector. And that primarily was an offshoot of COVID.  During COVID, when supply chains blew apart, we stepped in to serve a lot of that market when they were not being served. And those folks have remembered that, and we've grown our business there. So we need to, of course, talk about tariffs. How have tariffs really changed your thinking about product sourcing, particularly for fast centers, which we know, of course, are primarily sourced in China, Asia? What other options are you evaluating to mitigate the tariff impact here?  You know, so back in 2018, we did some short term moves of our supply chain, but it was fairly limited because you just can't change. There's so much QC involved with vetting suppliers that you couldn't move it fast enough. What we had done quietly over the last five, six years is continue in that progress.  because the tariffs that were put in place in 2018 were sticking, and we expected more of it to happen. And we wanted to better diversify the supply chain for our customer. We did look at a lot of options. There aren't a lot of options within North America. We looked at some options of doing some manufacturing ourself. The problem is the economics still didn't work. So it was really for us more about diversifying supplier base in general.  Are the economics of that going to work now in this new tariff regime? I think during the first Trump administration, the goal was to move things out of China, but as many companies are learning right now, it doesn't matter if it's China, Vietnam, or India, if it's not in the United States, there is going to be a tariff on it. At least that's what it seems like is going to be the case. Yeah. Um, economics still do not work. And, uh, and, and, and part of the challenge there,  isn't just the economics, it's the amount of time. When we were researching it, um, very in depth, uh, two and a half years ago, one of the, one of the challenges is it's easy to find a site. It's relatively easy to get a building up and get a supply chain set up. When I say relatively easy, I mean, timeframe of what it takes to do it.
