video_title: 'WIN-WIN': US ambassador to NATO explains why the NATO deal Trump brokered is so important

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: All right, great pleasure joining us now. Ambassador to NATO Mr. Matt Whitaker is a very important spot. Matt Whitaker, thank you for coming on. Tell me if I've got the story basically right and maybe you could walk us through the transfer.  NATO will be purchasing the new missiles and then will hand it over to Ukraine. But there's something, they already have some Patriot missiles and we're going to give those over. It wasn't clear to me, Matt. I don't want you to give me any state secrets, but tell us what you can tell us.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, well, it's good to be with you. It's good to see you, my friend, Larry. You know, I think the first thing people need to understand is, you know, when we had the NATO summit a month ago in The Hague, you know, it's really set a new path for our European allies in Canada that are all members of NATO. And that was that no longer is the American taxpayer going to foot the bill for traditional security and defense of Europe.  You know, for 76 years, American presidents have been talking about that. Donald Trump delivered it last month. And now the next step is to make Europe pay for the defense and the support of Ukraine, which Joe Biden and, you know, some members of Congress decided that the U.S. taxpayer and the hardworking Americans should be paying for that.  Obviously, America makes the best weapons, and everyone wants them. And Ukraine, to defend themselves, President Trump's been clear, they should get access to U.S. weapons. And so Europe has come through the NATO structure and said, we'll put up the money, we'll buy these American weapons, and we'll send them to Ukraine to defend themselves.  Now, there is already a lot of support for Ukraine happening, and weapons are constantly moving, and that's anything from Patriot missiles, which you mentioned, to things like just ammunition and other types of armaments. But this idea that President Trump has put together and brokered, I think really is a big win for Ukraine.  Ukraine to defend itself, but it's also a big win for the American taxpayer. They no longer have to pay for this, but at the same time, the jobs created by creating more weapons for the Ukrainians to use, I think it's just a win-win.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: But you know what else, Matt? Look, you look at this story here. President Trump doing his best to talk to Putin, to deal with Putin, to arrange a ceasefire with Putin, etc. And Putin was playing Trump. He was playing him, right? They'd end the phone call, as Trump said today, and as First Lady Melania apparently said, you know, Putin would get off the phone and then start bombing civilian places, which is terrible. You can't play Donald Trump. Trump is going to end this kind of appeasement.  We're going to go after him with much greater force, I think, than ever before. Isn't that part of the story here? You've got the US and NATO. It looks to me like acting in concert, allied, and they're going to give Putin, certainly send Putin a message to check his grandiose ambitions. Isn't that part of this story?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yeah, no doubt about that, Larry. And, you know, not only is it going to be the golden age of America under Donald Trump, it's also the golden age of NATO, where NATO is refocused on war fighting on Europe. And so, you know, I mean, this is a moment, I think, where everything has come together to work. But, you know, it's only come together because of Donald Trump's leadership. And, you know, being in the room today with him and Secretary General Rutte, it was very clear.  That we all understood what we were supposed to do. You know what the path forward is. And you know it's really extraordinary. But you know what you're seeing also on the continent of Europe. And you know as you know I spend most of my time over there.  What you're seeing is you're seeing countries like Germany, France, Great Britain that are doubling their defense spending, that are really stepping up to become the allies we need them to be because we cannot be everywhere at all times. And especially as it relates to the European continent and opposing Russia, that has to be taken and handled by primarily our European allies. We're still gonna be able to fly  B-2 bombers halfway across the world drop bombs and have those guys home for pizza with their families undetected. But at the same time, we need to make sure our allies are very strong. And that's what's happening. And this is the announcement today, I think, is the next step in that.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I agree. It's the first time, really, that people are going after. We are going after Putin. Putin cannot get away with this stuff. The appeasement is over. You know, you don't play Donald Trump. He is too smart and too tough. That came out today. And I think you're going to be a very busy chap. And you've got a great partner in Mark Rutte from the Netherlands. I think you've got a great partner there as well. Anyway, Matt Whitaker, Ambassador to NATO, thank you. Appreciate it. Good luck to you. Godspeed.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Good to see you, Larry. Thank you.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Ambassador Whitaker explains that NATO has decided to have Europe pay for Ukraine's defence, marking a shift from the US footing the bill. He credits former President Trump with brokering this deal, which he sees as strengthening NATO, boosting American jobs, and ensuring European allies take greater responsibility for their security.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host praises the new NATO arrangement where Europe buys US weapons for Ukraine, seeing it as a win-win for Ukraine and the American taxpayer. He also emphasises the need to end appeasement towards Putin and suggests that under Trump's leadership, the US and NATO will act more forcefully against Russia.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses NATO's new approach to funding Ukraine's defence, with Europe now purchasing US weapons, and highlights a shift in US policy towards greater European responsibility for its defence.

video_title: Washington Today (7-14-25): Pres. Trump: 100% secondary Russia tariffs if no Ukraine war ceasefire

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Welcome to Washington Today from Monday, July 14th, 2025. I'm Gary Starykow. Thank you for joining us. President Trump is upping the ante with Russia to end its war with Ukraine. He made two announcements today. First, 100% tariffs on any country that trades with Russia unless a ceasefire is reached within 50 days. And second, a weapons deal with NATO members to send weapons to Ukraine. This comes as a bipartisan Senate bill that puts sanctions on Russia.  that its two lead sponsors say could be the sledgehammer. The president needs to end the conflict. It comes up in the Senate. We'll hear from the president, NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte, and Senators Lindsey Graham and Richard Blumenthal, the two men behind the sanctions bill coming up. Also in the Senate, Republicans are focused on their bill to take back more than $9 billion in federal funds  including for public broadcasting and foreign aid. This is the same House Republican bill that passed last month in the House and the Senate has until Friday to approve it, but it's facing opposition from a handful of Republican holdouts over those foreign aid cuts and also from Democrats who say any rescissions would hurt future bipartisan government funding talks. We'll tell you all about it coming up.  The Associated Press reporting that it wasn't immediately clear what products could be targeted by the tariffs announced by the president today. But here's what he said in the Oval Office.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: And we've made a deal today, and I'm going to have Mark speak about it, but we've made a deal today where we're going to be sending them weapons and they're going to be paying for them.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: We — the United States will not be having any payment made. We're not buying it, but we will manufacture it, and they're going to be paying for it. Our last meeting of a month ago was very successful in that they agreed to 5 percent, which is more than a trillion dollars a year. So they have a lot of money. And they have — these are wealthy nations. They have a lot of money. And they want to do it. They feel very strongly about it. And we feel strongly about it, too. But we're in for a lot of money, and we just —  We don't want to do anymore, and we can't. But we make the best, and we're going to be sending the best to NATO, and in some cases to maybe, at Mark's suggestion, if we go to Germany, where they're going to send early-on missiles, and they'll be replaced, and NATO is going to take care of it. It's going to be coordinated by NATO, and they're going to work very much with Matt Whitaker, who's right here, who's a great ambassador. And Matt's going to be coordinating.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: You better do a good job, Matt.

lines.speaker: Unidentified SPEAKER
lines.text: I will.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: But Matt's going to coordinate. He's a very talented guy. He's going to coordinate everything.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: So in a nutshell, we're going to make top of the line weapons and they'll be sent to NATO. NATO may choose to have certain of them sent to other countries where we can get a little additional speed, where the country will release something and be mostly in the form of a replacement. And we heard NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte was at today's announcement. Here's what he had to say.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: This is really big.  want the Europeans to pay for it, which is totally logical. And this is building on the tremendous success of the NATO summit, the 5 percent, but also the decision to keep Ukraine strong and the decision to increase our defense industrial production.  So based on that, this is – that was Europe stepping up. This is again Europeans stepping up. So I've been in contact with many countries. I can tell you at this moment Germany massively, but also Finland and Denmark and Sweden and Norway. We have the Kingdom, the Netherlands, Canada. They all want to be part of this. And this is only the first wave. There will be more. So what we will do is work through the NATO systems to make sure that we know what Ukrainians need.  so that we can make packages. Of course, in a way, we discussed it this morning with Pete Hexhead at the Pentagon, in a way that, of course, the U.S. will put on its stockpiles necessary to defend this country. That's absolutely clear. But it will mean that Ukraine can get its hands on, really,  massive numbers of military equipment, both for air defense, but also missiles, ammunition, et cetera, et cetera. So if I was Vladimir Putin today and hear you speaking about what you were planning to do in 50 days at this announcement, I would reconsider whether I should not take negotiations about Ukraine more seriously than I was doing at the moment, if I was Vladimir Putin. But when I'm Ukraine, I think this is really great news for them. So I really want to thank you for that. And it means the Europeans paying for it.  And again, I mentioned all these countries, we will deal with that. And exactly as you said, it might also mean that countries will move equipment fast into Ukraine and then the US later backfilling it, because speed is of the essence here.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte and Reuters reporting that the weapons package would include the Patriot air defense missiles. And in writing about the tariffs, they call it, quote, a major shift in Western sanctions policy. Throughout the more than three year old war, Western countries have cut off most of their own financial ties to Moscow.  but have held back from taking steps that would restrict Russia from selling its oil elsewhere. That has allowed Moscow to continue earning hundreds of billions of dollars from shipping oil to buyers such as China and India. Reuters goes on to write, still Trump announcement of a 50 day grace period was greeted with relief by investors in Russia.  where the ruble recovered from earlier losses and stock markets rose. That's from Reuters today. Here's more from the Oval Office.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: What was the tipping point for you in making this decision?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Was it a conversation with President Putin? Was it a piece of intelligence? And why are you giving 50 more days?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I think the — well, I think it's over a short period of time.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: I think they'll forget. I've just really been involved in this for not very long. And it wasn't initial focus. This is — again, this is a Biden war. This is a Democrat war, not a Republican or Trump war. This is a war that would have never happened.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: It shouldn't have happened. A lot of people being killed.  When the final numbers come in, you're going to see a lot more people are being killed in this war than you think, than you've been writing about. It's a very deadly war. They're all bad, but this is a very deadly war. The numbers are going to be far greater. An apartment house comes down, and they say two people were slightly injured.  No, many people were killed and those numbers will be at some point accurately reported.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: So far, they're not. It's a deadly war. I think that you're just going to see. I think you're going to see strong movement. I hope so. I hope so. You know, the secondary tariffs are very, very powerful.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: What about the tariffs that

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: the

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_03
lines.text: It's certainly good that they're doing it. And Lindsey Graham's working hard. The whole group, John Thune, all of them, they're all working hard. And they're in coordination with Mike Johnson, Speaker in the House. And I think they are, they've actually crafted a pretty good piece of legislation that's probably going to pass very easily. And that includes Democrats. And there's some little tweaks.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I don't want to say I don't need it, because I don't want them to waste their time. It could be very useful. We'll have to see. But we can do secondary. We're probably talking about 100 percent or something like that. We can do secondary tariffs without the Senate, without the House. But what they're crafting also could be very good.  Delaware Democratic Senator Chris Coons, who's on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, posted on social media today, quote, I'm heartened that Trump is realizing that Putin is the only obstacle to peace in Ukraine. Today's announcement should help ensure that Ukrainians fighting for freedom have the weapons they need to defend themselves so they can be better positioned to secure a lasting peace.  And we heard that question about the Senate sanctions package. That bill would allow the president to levy a 500 percent tariff on imports from countries that purchase Russian uranium, gas and oil. Here are the bill's lead sponsors, Connecticut Democrat Richard Blumenthal and South Carolina Republican Lindsey Graham, who talked about it yesterday on CBS News Face the Nation. Here's Senator Blumenthal.  This has to be a critical moment for these sanctions and bringing down this sledgehammer at this moment was emphasized by all of the European allies who were at the meeting that Senator Graham and I attended.  in Europe, they are absolutely in solidarity, one after another, in that closed-door setting, express the view that these sanctions have to be tough and rigorous to change behavior. And so the waiver language that we will have in this bill is very much alike the  provisions that have existed in past similar measures that give the president the ability to act in the national security but also provide congressional oversight and I think that kind of assurance to my democratic colleagues is very important but  What is most important, I think, at this moment is our unity. Senator Graham and I, Republican and Democrat coming together, the European leaders with diverse views, also in unity. And we want to make use of the seized assets, again, in a unified way. I think a multifaceted approach here is the only way to bring Putin to the table, because he's a thug. He understands only force.  And here's Senator Graham. Putin has calculated that we would get tired and Europe would get weary. He made a huge mistake. NATO was bigger and stronger, and we're more committed to ever to make sure he does not take Ukraine by force.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So Congress is on the verge of passing the most consequential sanction package in the history of the country.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It will give President Trump tools he doesn't have today, a literal sledgehammer. And the big offender here is China, India, and Brazil. India buys oil from Russia cheap and resells it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: That's despicable. I've talked to President Trump. He said last week, it's time to move. He's tried to entice Putin to the table. But my goal is to end this war. And the only way you're going to end this war is to get people who prop up Putin  make them choose between the American economy and helping Putin. And you can only have one negotiator, and that's going to be President Trump with maximum flexibility to end this war. China, India, and Brazil, you're about to get hurt big time if you keep helping Putin.  South Carolina Republican Senator Lindsey Graham and Connecticut Democratic Senator Richard Blumenthal on CBS News faced the nation yesterday. And late this afternoon, Politico reporting that Senate Majority Leader John Thune said today he would hold off on advancing the sanctions package targeting Russia's trading partners after President Trump said he was prepared to act himself later this summer if Russia doesn't move toward a peace deal with Ukraine.  Politico quotes Senator Thune saying, If at some point the president concludes that it makes sense and adds value and leverage that he needs in those negotiations to move the bill, then we'll do it. We'll be ready to go. That from Senator Thune.  Now to the Republican funding cuts bill in the Senate this week. As we said, they have until Friday to pass this bill. It's the same bill that passed the House last month by two votes. In total, it cuts $9.4 billion in federal funding. And according to the AP, that includes $1.1 billion in cuts to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, two thirds of which that money helps fund local public radio and TV stations for their operations.  It also includes $8.3 billion in foreign aid programs. Among them, $900 million to combat HIV, AIDS, malaria, and other diseases. $800 million for a program that provides emergency shelter, water, and sanitation in war-ravaged countries.  $4.15 billion for two economic, civil, and institutional development programs in developing and strategically important countries, and $496 million for food, water, and health aid in countries hit by natural disasters and conflicts.  Other cuts are aimed at the global HIV AIDS program known as PEPFAR, which is credited with saving 26 million lives around the world and has broad bipartisan support in Congress. Republicans who have voiced concern about this bill include Senate Appropriations Chair Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, and Mike Rounds of South Dakota. In his Leader Time remarks this afternoon, Republican Leader John Thune talked about the 2026 agriculture bill.  Mr. President, the appropriations process is officially underway here in the Senate. Last week, the Appropriations Committee held its first mark of appropriations bills for fiscal year 2026. And I'm pleased to report that the committee referred two bills to the floor with bipartisan support.  And today I want to talk about one of the bills that came out of last week's markup, and that's the Agriculture Appropriations Bill. Mr. President, agriculture is the lifeblood of our country. And in places like my home state of South Dakota, farming and ranching are a big part of our way of life. I know how hard American farmers and ranchers work to deliver food, fuel, and fiber to America and to the world. And I know this work can be challenging, and at times, unforgiving.  In recent years, farmers and ranchers across the country have faced some pretty fierce headwinds. Higher input costs and depressed commodity prices strained their budgets, and higher interest rates made financing more difficult. Then there were the supply chain disruptions, natural disasters and drought, and things like bird flu, African swine fever, and the new world screw worm that threatened livestock.  Mr. President, just two weeks ago, Republicans passed a reconciliation bill that addresses many of the challenges head-on by bolstering programs that farmers and ranchers depend on.  But as I said then, farmers and ranchers' priorities are going to continue to be a priority here in the Senate. And the Agricultural Appropriations Bill is an example of that. Mr. President, our colleagues on the Appropriations Committee have reported a bill that provides robust funding to support America's farmers and ranchers. It provides important funding to the Farm Service Agency, including support for $10.5 billion in capital access for farmers and ranchers.  And it supports efforts to track foreign-owned land to prevent our adversaries, like China, from buying up America's farmland. It also makes investment in rural development programs at USDA. In South Dakota, that money goes far in supporting water programs, electricity, and broadband programs in rural areas.  This bill also invests in conservation programs, and it advances efforts to help farmers and ranchers get their products to the market. I'm glad to see support for processing capacity for meat, poultry, and egg products. And I'm pleased that this bill also promotes programs that help state-inspected plants operate across state lines, which provides producers with more options for their products and supports smaller processors.  The bill also includes funding for the Agriculture Marketing Service to help facilitate greater access to international markets for American agriculture products. And the updated market data that will result from investments in this bill will help farmers and ranchers make better decisions about their businesses. Part of Senate Republican Leader John Thune's Leader Time remarks. Now, the Republicans' rescissions package was on the mind of Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer.  The so-called rescissions package continues the destructive Republican pattern. Cut now, ask questions later. The same thing that's happening with FEMA and the National Weather Service is happening right here. Again, use that chainsaw. Cut, cut, cut. Don't look at what you're cutting, what its effect will be, whether it's waste or whether it's sinew and bone. And then later say, oh, maybe we shouldn't have done that.  And you know what, Mr. President? Our Republican senators, most of them, know this is wrong, but they're so afraid of Donald Trump. Yesterday, he threatened any of them who voted against the full rescissions package that we have before us would face his wrath. What is going on here? Does anyone stand up to these horrible, horrible cuts that hurt the American people?  Republicans in real time are cutting health care. They're cutting education. They're cutting aid for our veterans. Veterans are not getting, they ask them. The veterans know they're not getting the health care they used to. And making things even worse, Donald Trump's tariffs are coming in at the worst possible time. And in a few short months, they're going to raise the cost of groceries. They're going to hurt small businesses and do untold damage to our economy.  And now this package suffocates public broadcast. Well, did they even know when they said they wanted to cut it? You know, Donald Trump doesn't seem to like it. How much it helps our rural communities? It's the only place they can rely on for local news, for weather reports? That farmers across rural America depend on public broadcast to get weather reports? Because there's no other way?  Did they know that it cuts international aid that ensures America's national security? Did they even think of the consequences? Just because Donald Trump says he wants it cut and everyone knows he doesn't know the details of any of this stuff.  The rescissions package is certainly troubling, but the pattern behind it is even worse. It sets the stage for even more party-line devastating cuts in the future, to health care, to education, anything Republicans decide they don't like. All on a party-line vote, all because of obeisance and fear of Donald Trump, not a conviction that he's doing the right thing. This is a dark omen moving forward.  Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer and Politico Congress reporter Jordan Carney reporting Missouri Republican Senator Eric Schmidt, who is spearheading the rescissions package in the Senate, was at the White House this afternoon to meet with President Trump on the funding clawback per person familiar with per person familiar with what happened there.  White House Budget Director Russell Vought is also coming to the Hill tomorrow, according to Jordan Carney. And she's also reporting the Senate wants to take first votes on this bill on Tuesday. Now, you can see the Senate's consideration of this bill live all week on C-SPAN, too.  C-SPAN.org and the free C-SPAN Now mobile app. The House is also back to work this week on their agenda, several cybersecurity bills, including legislation requiring the Commerce Department's National Telecommunications Agency to examine the cybersecurity of wireless networks, and a bill directing the Consumer Product Safety Commission to create a pilot program to study the use of AI.  House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries spoke to reporters today. One of the issues on his mind, today's White House Russia announcement. Vladimir Putin has spent the entire year punking Donald Trump and the Trump administration. Donald Trump promised many things to the American people and continues to betray the American people and break promise after promise after promise in a whole lot of areas.  including Donald Trump's promise that there would be peace in Ukraine on day one of his presidency. How is that working out? Donald Trump has spent the first six months of his presidency playing footsie with Vladimir Putin.  And the response from Vladimir Putin, a sworn enemy of the United States of America, has been to unleash terror on Ukrainian children, communities, and civilians. Donald Trump has zero credibility in this area. Is he just now figuring out that Ukraine is a friend to the United States of America and Russia is an enemy? Is he just now figuring out  that the United States should always stand on the side of democracy, freedom, and truth, which is standing with Ukraine, as opposed to standing on the side of authoritarianism, tyranny, and propaganda, which is what he's been doing by standing with Russia and Vladimir Putin? Is he just now figuring this out? Congress has to act independently in this area, and we should sanction Russia and continue to keep the pressure on.  Vladimir Putin, and Russia, a sworn enemy of this country, until the Ukrainian people are able to achieve victory for themselves, our NATO allies in Europe, and the free world.  And from USA Today, Texas Democratic Representative Mark Veazey has introduced a resolution calling for the release of all unclassified files related to the Jeffrey Epstein case. Representative Veazey posted on social media yesterday, quote, either Trump and his acolytes fueled the rumors of the significance of these Epstein files to help his campaign or something is there. Put up or shut up.  USA Today noting that candidate Donald Trump said last year that he would support releasing additional details about the Epstein case, but a memo by the Justice Department and FBI that came out July 7th reported no evidence of a client list or that Epstein had been murdered while in custody.  This comes after President Trump posted on social media over the weekend his support for Attorney General Pam Bondi and FBI Director Kash Patel's handling of the case, writing, quote, Let's not waste time and energy on Jeffrey Epstein, somebody that nobody cares about. But Leader Jeffrey's was asked about it this afternoon. The American people deserve to know the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth as it relates to this whole sorted Jeffrey Epstein matter.  Democrats didn't put the Jeffrey Epstein thing into the public domain. This was a conspiracy that Donald Trump, Pam Bondi, and these MAGA extremists have been fanning the flames of for the last several years. And now the chickens are coming home to roost. The American people deserve to know the truth. What, if anything, is the Trump administration and the Department of Justice hiding?  What are you hiding? If you're not hiding anything, prove that to the American people. And if you are trying to hide something, as many of Donald Trump's MAGA supporters apparently believe, then the Congress should actually work hard to try to uncover the truth for the American people. There are only two things that are possible here. Option one,  Donald Trump, Pam Bondi, and the MAGA extremists intentionally lied to the American people for years about the Jeffrey Epstein situation. That's option one. Option two is that, in fact, there's reason for the American people to be concerned as it relates to what  information has not been released that could be damaging to the Trump administration and the friends and family of the Trump administration and their billionaire corrupt supporters. And so they're actively engaging in a cover-up. Option one, they lied for years. Option two, they're engaging in a cover-up. At this point, it seems reasonable that it can only be one of the two things.  And so it's Congress's responsibility in a bipartisan way to ask the questions and try to get answers on behalf of the American people.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: all the files related to Jeffrey Epstein. Have you had a conversation with those members? Do you plan to? Do you support those pieces of legislation?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: I haven't had a conversation with those members or an opportunity to evaluate the resolution and the legislation. However, I think transparency and sunlight for the American people is always the better course of action.  House Democratic Leader Haim Jeffries speaking to reporters earlier today. Here's Yasmin Wright, White House reporter for Notice.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, I mean, it's a big question is what happens going forward. Obviously, President Trump has been vocal over the weekend in that social media post, basically saying it was time to put the Epstein files behind his MAGA base. But I talked to one MAGA strategist who is close to the White House, who basically said that  The president's base is unmoved by that post, telling people to move on, but also telling people to kind of lay off attorney general Pam Bondi, who has basically faced the brunt of the attacks when it comes to how this administration has handled the Epstein files. So folks in that base are unmoved and they're going to continue asking questions.  I think that the onus is now on president Trump to see how he continues to respond. If he basically ignores his base, something that folks have been vocal about saying that for really the first time in this first six months, they view it as Trump misjudging the moment or misjudging where his base is at. We know that president Trump is somebody who likes to check in on his base and who likes to be up to date on how they're feeling and how they're reacting to the post. So there's going to be a question about how president Trump handles this.  but also a president, a question about how deputy FBI chief Dan, Dan Bergino handles this. Obviously we know that he did not show up for work on Friday. A notice was able to confirm because he was so upset at Pam Bondi over her handling of the Epstein case. So there's going to be a question of whether or not he shows up today. He shows up the rest of the week and how long he does stay with the administration. But obviously there are some major questions that they're going to have to decide on in that building behind me.  about how they go forward because we know that President Trump likes to be very loyal to his base because he feels as though they are very loyal to him. But in this case, they're having a real issue.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: Jasmine Wright, White House reporter for Notice on this morning's Washington Journal on the White House handling of the Jeffrey Epstein files. You're listening to Washington Today.  In a nation divided, a rare moment of unity, this fall, C-SPAN presents C-SPIRE, where the shouting stops and the conversation begins in a town where partisan fighting prevails. One table, two leaders, one goal, to find common ground. This fall, C-SPIRE, on the network that doesn't take sides, only on C-SPAN.  Welcome back to Washington Today from Politico. Late this afternoon, a divided Supreme Court has cleared the way for the Education Department to fire almost 40 percent of its workforce, four months after President Trump ordered his administration to begin closing down the department. The justices, by an apparent 6-3 vote, lifted an injunction.  from a federal judge in Boston that was granted back in May against the firing. That judge found that the staff cuts were so drastic they would prevent the department from carrying out duties mandated by Congress. The judge also said the mass firings appear to be part of Trump's plan to eliminate the education department entirely despite a lack of congressional authorization to do so. That from Politico late this afternoon.  Yesterday was the one year anniversary of the assassination attempt on Donald Trump. And today, a group of Republican study committee members introduced a resolution marking the anniversary. Here's Pennsylvania Republican Mike Kelly, whose hometown of Butler, Pennsylvania, was where the attack occurred. Yesterday, I returned to the Butler Farm Showgrounds, where I was with the president a year ago. I met with the Comptore family during a celebration of Corey's life.  They are incredibly strong, and I know all of us on stage continue to send our thoughts and prayers to them as we seek more answers about what actually happened that day. Now, we're here today to highlight new Resolution HR 571, which formally recognized the events of 2014 and July 13th in Butler, Pennsylvania. The resolution also condemns the rise in political violence we have seen across our nation over the last year.  from the assassination attempts against President Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania, and West Palm Beach, Florida, to the attacks against Governor Josh Shapiro in April, and to the deadly attacks on the Minnesota state lawmakers just last month. Let's be clear.  We must stand up together to oppose violence against our nation's leaders all across each party. And I want to thank my co-lead on the resolution, RSC Chairman August Fluger from Texas. When we talk about this, though, we can have as many resolutions as we want to bring it forward. And I've heard person after person, politician after politician, get up and say, I am absolutely appalled by the violence that's taking place in this country today.  And we've got to stop using that type of language. And with 24 hours, they're out talking again about who should not be sitting in certain offices. So it's one thing to have a resolution. It's one thing to be resolved the fact we're not going to keep talking like this. What I'm asking all our Congress, everybody that's in the Congress, everybody that's in elected office, please watch what you say. Don't start off saying we should never do this.  and then within 24 hours go out and make statements again that incite people? That's a false lead. It's a false premise. Our resolution is an attempt to get people to speak the way they should speak. In America, the way we settle things is by votes.  Pennsylvania Republican Congressman Mike Kelly, and in an article on city and state PA dot com, Representative Kelly said he still wonders why federal law enforcement agencies allowed Donald Trump to go on stage that day, saying, quote, they knew there was a suspicious person on the grounds for an hour and a half before the president came out on the stage. After everything was said and done, I still ask, why did they let President Trump come out on the stage when they knew the site was not secure? That will forever be my question.  Also from today, from CBS12.com in Palm Beach, Florida, what was meant to be a surprise inspection turned into a tightly managed tour. But what Florida lawmakers saw inside Alligator Alcatraz left them horrified. On Saturday afternoon, four Florida representatives, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Darren Soto, Maxwell Frost, and Jared Moskowitz were given what they call a sanitized tour of Alligator Alcatraz.  from officials at Florida's Division of Emergency Management and also federal officials. The members stated that despite the alleged limited access and sanitation of the tour, the conditions were, quote, horrific. They reported seeing people held in cages, unsanitary eating conditions, people begging for freedom, a man who said he had been hospitalized for days, among other concerning conditions. Representative Frost talked about what he saw in a town hall on Saturday.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: These are very nuts and bolts questions. Do you know how many people are there? Or is the gender breakdown? Is it all males? And are they from all over the country or all from Florida?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_04
lines.text: There's just under 1000 people there right now. Their goal is to get to 4000 capacity, 4000 beds by August. I'm going to a couple of weeks here. They're going to be adding an additional 1000 beds to it within the next week or so. And we saw that those new cages that they were working on the demographic. This facility.  It is a mix of people. There are a lot of people there who just have a civil offense or just something very low that they were picked up for all the way up to people who have done violent crimes and all in between.  There is a wristband system when they arrive that they put on them to determine what kind of offense they had, most of them being civil offenses and small offenses, and they do not have them segregated. It's just a big hodgepodge of people all put together. And I asked a few questions.  on mental health issues and how people can seek mental health help. If I ask the company, there's a third-party company that's doing all the medical work. I'm looking through my notes to try to find a name for you guys. It's a third-party company that's doing all the medical work. I asked them, how often are you asked by the  People running the facility who might not be able to be put in the general population because of a health condition because of this and that they weren't able to answer the question. Then it looks like there's not a ton of communication on that front either. This leads me to another thing that I forgot to mention that I think is really important. This facility, when we 1st pulled up.  It was mainly third party security companies that were running the parking and the security and all of this. Then we get into the facility. And when we were at that, at the tent where all the cages are, the people holding us back and the people in there dealing with the detainees were from a third party security company. We barely saw any federal agents  A few people from the National Guard, a few people who are trained law enforcement officers, but it was mainly essentially cops for hire. Not any different than the people who want you, you know, if you were to go into a concert or go to a sports game. And these are a lot of the folks who are dealing with the detainees, transporting them around the facility and are essentially running the whole thing. So this is also a huge source of taxpayer money just going to corporations, but also  What worries me too is these people do not have the training you need to run a facility like this. Florida Democratic Representative Maxwell Frost on a town hall on Saturday talking about what he saw at the immigrant detention facility known as Alligator Alcatraz.  CBS12.com also reporting that Florida Republican Governor Ron DeSantis defended the management of that detention facility, saying, quote, it's not the Four Seasons. It's a professional processing center to effectuate the deportation of illegal aliens. That's what it's for. It's professionally run. It's going to be value added.  And from CNBC.com, dozens of U.S. ice cream producers say they are planning to remove artificial colors from their products by 2028. CNBC writes the producers, which represent more than 90 percent of ice cream sold in the U.S., are the latest food companies to take voluntary steps to remove dyes since Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said back in April that the U.S. aimed to phase out many synthetic dyes from the country's food supply.  Secretary Kennedy talked about it at an event today that included Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and officials from the International Dairy Foods Association. I'm particularly happy to be here today because this is relevant to my favorite food, which is ice cream.  Since we came in about five and a half months ago and started talking about eliminating dyes and other bad chemicals from our food, we've had this extraordinary response from the industry. And Brooke just rattled off this inventory, this extraordinary inventory of national corporate food producers have all made commitments  to remove food dyes from their food. And with this addition today of the dairymen and the dairy food producers, we now have about 35% of American food industry that has made commitments. And that's an addition between 35% and 40%.  And that is in addition to the 35% of the food industry that was already organic and healthy and chemical free.  Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. CNBC notes several major food manufacturers, including General Mills, Kraft Heinz, James Smucker, Hershey and Nestle USA, have previously announced their plans to phase out synthetic food coloring. The IDFA said artificial dyes are safe, but that ice cream makers are taking this step in part to avoid disruption to sales from state efforts.  to phase out dyes from school foods and also West Virginia's recent food dye ban. You can see more from all of these events at C-SPAN.org and the free C-SPAN Now mobile app. That's also where you can get our complete congressional coverage and where you can find this program as a podcast. You can also find it on YouTube. Just search Washington Today.  And for more on the stories that are shaping Washington every day, get our daily email word for word. You can go to C-SPAN dot org slash connect to subscribe. I'm Gary Sterkhoff. Thanks a lot for listening today to Washington Today.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Ambassador Whitaker explains that NATO has decided to have Europe pay for Ukraine's defence, marking a shift from the US footing the bill. He credits former President Trump with brokering this deal, which he sees as strengthening NATO, boosting American jobs, and ensuring European allies take greater responsibility for their security.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The host praises the new NATO arrangement where Europe buys US weapons for Ukraine, seeing it as a win-win for Ukraine and the American taxpayer. He also emphasises the need to end appeasement towards Putin and suggests that under Trump's leadership, the US and NATO will act more forcefully against Russia.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses NATO's new approach to funding Ukraine's defence, with Europe now purchasing US weapons, and highlights a shift in US policy towards greater European responsibility for its defence.

video_title: 'What's the point of 50 days?': Gen. Clark on Trump's Russia ultimatum | NewsNation Now

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Every Patriot missile that gets to Ukraine is a big help. And if we can get a couple more Patriot batteries there, well, that's a big help. But the Russians are flooding Ukraine with drones. So, you're not using the Patriots against drones. You're using the Patriots against enemy big missiles that are coming in. And so you need things to take out that. And, really, if you want to get rid of the drone problem and the missile problem,  you have to shoot the archer, as my friends say, not the arrows. And so that means you need long-range strike capability. And you have got to hold the line where you are, so you need small arms, you need 155-millimeter artillery rounds, and you need all of the sort of communications gear, radar gear, electronic warfare stuff that goes with it.  We don't know what's in that package that President Trump says he's going to approve, except we know there are Patriot missiles there. And that's a good thing. But how many? That's the question. And will it be enough? And then, Laura, you've got to look at the other side of it. Why 50 days? Why don't we tell Vladimir Putin, stop, stop now?  Why are we waiting 50 days? We've been talking about this for a long time. Now, if you were going to look at this in a constructive way, you'd say there's already discussions going on. I've showed you, Mr. Putin, that I'm serious on this. We're going to send weapons and a lot more weapons. So why don't you just stop your attacks tomorrow, and then we'll talk about the other details on the ceasefire? That's what a strong leader could do.  Now, what President Trump is doing is a little bit different. I know he wants to bring Russia back into the international community, so he doesn't want to offend too badly. And he's got supporters who don't support giving assistance to Ukraine. But 50 days, 50 more days of missile strikes and drones against Kyiv, 50 more days of Russian massing its forces and trying to do a breakthrough, what's the point of the 50 days?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, and let's see if the 50 days is really 50 days, right? Because we've heard deadlines before. He's laid it down. So we'll see if that sticks. I also got to ask you, because you're so familiar with the weapons that we were just talking about, but you're also familiar with the rhetoric and the tone. Because President Trump has been expressing high frustration with Russian President Putin, saying that he's not serious about a ceasefire. So let's take a listen to what he said today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I speak to him a lot about getting this thing done. And I always hang up and say, well, that was a nice phone call. And then missiles launched into Kiev and some other city. And I said, strange. And after that happens three or four times, you say, the talk doesn't mean anything.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: All right. So what is your reaction to that? You know, when we take a look at what he's saying, how is Putin likely to view Trump's change of heart? Or will he even consider it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: I think it goes 30 percent of the way. I think it's good to announce the defensive missiles. But we're, again, playing a patty cake with Mr. Putin by giving 50 days. It's more rhetoric. It sounds OK. But what's the holdup here? We have been going for six months on this. If we mean Putin to stop, tell him to stop.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Right. So we've got the 50-day thing and then he's threatening sanctions against Russia.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Put them on. I mean, we've been talking about them for three months. The Senate has held up its bill that was ready to go because President Trump said he might put sanctions on.  So, it seems like, again, this is Washington politics. And, unfortunately, we got people dying. And people in Europe — Laura, I have to tell you, people in Europe are looking at this as this is the first of the third World War battles, because what they see is  Russian troops lining up in Belarus to go against the Baltics. They see Russian forces in Finland, opposite Finland. They see Chinese support for Russia. They see what Russia and China are trying to do to help Iran. This is not just something you can turn your back on. And so every day matters. We should tell Russia to stop and stop now.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: If you were at the table, how would you advise those that are involved in this right now?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Well, I think Putin's going to keep going as long as he thinks he can step on President Trump and get what he wants. So you've got to do three things. You've got to mobilize Europe and reinforce with U.S. forces in Europe and NATO.  You've got to really surge equipment into Ukraine, and you've got to tell Mr. Putin in no uncertain terms, it's over, bud. It's over.

They criticise the 50-day deadline as too lenient and advocate for a stronger, more decisive stance against Russia. video_title: Hundreds of pets rescued from Texas flooding by local group | NewsNation Live

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Organizations like Austin Pets Alive are working to relocate, rescue, and reunite owners with their beloved pets. Dr. Ellen Jefferson is president of that group. Thank you so much for being with us this morning. How many pets and animals so far have you all been able to help rescue?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: We are approaching about 800 animals that have been helped along the entire Guadalupe River and San Gabriel River complex. This flood is much bigger than just Kerrville.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: So it's about 800 total that we've been able to help so far. Wow. And what condition are these animals arriving in?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: It's a mix. So the majority of those are animals that were already in the animal shelters that exist, the government shelters that are there. And what our job is as first responders is to go in and try to move those animals out to safety as fast as possible so that they won't be euthanized to make room for the animals that are coming in for lost and found.  And so that gives those government shelters that are on the ground the capability to be able to take in animals and hold them for a stray period that's much longer during a disaster than normally seen in animal shelters. And then we also deployed thousands of people to do search and rescue on the ground and worked with families and many, many people.  animals that are being owner surrendered in the field or where family members are trying to recuperate from losing other family members and trying to find safe placement for their pets.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Have you gotten to a point where you're able to unify pets and their people parents?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yes, we have done some of that. We are working with one trailer park in particular really stands out because it's only a park of maybe seven or eight trailers, but every single person within that has extremely devastating stories.  And those stories are range from losing family members, because the family member was trying to save the rest of the people and pets in the in their trailer to people that were swept away and found many, many miles later in trees alive.  and people that got out in the nick of time that had to leave their pets behind in their trailers. And one of the most miraculous things that we've seen is that many of the pets that were left behind in trailers, not all, but many of them were found alive near the wreckage. So, you know, we're just so in awe of animals' ability to survive.  given what's been thrown at them. And of course, many were lost, hundreds, hundreds, maybe thousands, I'm sure thousands actually were lost and are deceased. But we're so thankful for those bright spots of hope where we can see pets that survived and then we can reunite them with their family.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Wow. Well, I appreciate you highlighting some of the miracles in the midst of so much devastation. I also want to highlight as well scams that are out there. And I know you guys have been dealing with them as well. What do you want people to know about those looking to take advantage of a horrible situation?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: I think the biggest thing that we've seen is Venmo. Personally, that we've seen is Venmo. We do discourage people from using GoFundMe unless they are aware of, have a personal connection to the family. The Venmo fraud that we've seen is that people are adding numbers or letters to a handle for Venmo. So make sure that you go to the charity section of Venmo to select what charity. Those are verified charities.  And if you're using Venmo as a link, don't do that. Go to Venmo app and search for charities that will prevent you from giving to somebody who should not be receiving funds that you intend for organizations like ours.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Yeah, some of these groups pretending to be animal shelters. So make sure that you are on a reputable site. Doctor Jefferson, thanks for the work you and your team are doing. 800 animals rescued so far. Thank you so much.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Thank you for watching. Subscribe below and download our NewsNation app right now on your phone and you will get fact-based, unbiased news for all Americans.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Dr. Jefferson reports that they have rescued approximately 800 animals. She explains their strategies to support government shelters, conduct search and rescue, and assist families surrendering pets. She shares heartwarming stories of pet survival and reunions but also acknowledges the significant losses. Dr. Jefferson warns about Venmo fraud and advises donating to verified charities through the Venmo app.
summary.SPEAKER_01: The interviewer asks questions about the number of animals rescued, their conditions, reunions with owners, and the scams occurring during the crisis.
summary.high_level_summary: Dr. Ellen Jefferson, President of Austin Pets Alive, discusses their efforts to rescue animals affected by the floods along the Guadalupe River and San Gabriel River complex. They have rescued about 800 animals, including those from shelters and during search and rescue operations. The organisation is also working to reunite pets with their owners and warns about emerging scams targeting donations.

video_title: Only 7% of Texans have flood insurance | NewsNation Now

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: As recovery and cleanup efforts continue in Central Texas following deadly flooding, it has become clear the rebuilding process will be costly. We can all see it, right? Data from FEMA shows that only 5 to 10% of homes in the hardest hit areas have flood insurance.  Hear that again, 5 to 10%, which means that many who lost everything probably aren't insured. With us is President of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, North Dakota Insurance Commissioner, John Godfrey. Thank you so much for being here today, John, because, I mean, when we watch it and we realize how much is lost, it's just devastating. And AccuWeather recently released preliminary numbers from the flash floods in Texas.  saying that it cost an estimated $8 to $22 billion in total damage and economic loss so far. So let's talk about what that means for the residents of Central Texas. And what do you think about that number? 5 to 10% have flood insurance.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Unfortunately, it's not uncommon. That exists across the country because the flood insurance program is a different program than your standard homeowner's policy, which is years and years and years ago was divorced from their standard policy and put under the federal government, the National Flood Insurance Program. And we've had a real challenge getting through to consumers to understand that if it rains where you're at, it can flood. And so having that flood insurance policy is absolutely critically important to protecting what is oftentimes your largest asset.  We've been in talk with Congress about the reauthorization or restructuring of FEMA and looking at how do we put some more money towards pre-disaster mitigation versus always paying for the post-disaster recovery. And so we're encouraged by some of the conversations that this administration's have on addressing some of these urgent needs. But the reality is a lot of consumers across the country just don't purchase a flood insurance policy, partially because they don't realize they need to have it. They may think, I live on a hill, it never floods where I'm at. We go by the old adage, if it rains where you're at, it can flood.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: You know what? This reminds me of when we were covering Hurricane Sandy here in New York, and this happened to a lot of people on Long Island and New Jersey. It happened all over the place, and it was it was devastating. People are still people are still trying to rebuild after that. And you know, we take a look at what Texas is dealing with. They experienced 20 weather and climate disasters in 2024, and yet when we look at the numbers, only 7% of the statewide population has this flood insurance. So why is that number so low? You mentioned how to get it, but why don't more people have it?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: Well, I think because they don't understand that it's not a part of their standard policy, right? And insurance is traditionally a state regulated institution or industry. And so oftentimes the state insurance commissioner will oversee these policies, but you've got this separate standalone policy and all that you need to have, which is a flood insurance policy, which again, we've been advocating for a long time to, you know, how do we get some more private flood insurance into the marketplace? It's really hard to compete in the private market when you've got an NFIP.  and even have those conversations with Congress about how do we reauthorize this program, make sure it doesn't go bankrupt and these type of pieces. It's really confusing for consumers anytime we're talking about insurance, but then when you need to go layer it on another layer, another protection policy that you need to have, it makes it a challenge. And so it's really, a good agent's worth its weight in gold to talk to them and ask the questions about what happens if it floods? Am I covered? And kind of walk through those different scenarios to make sure that again, your largest asset is protected.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Right. Well, we know that this is going to be a very long road for a lot of people. Thank you for weighing in on it, Commissioner John Godfrey. Thank you very much for being here today.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: We'll talk again soon.

summary.SPEAKER_00: The interviewer highlights the devastating impact of flooding in Central Texas, the low flood insurance coverage (5-10%), and the estimated $8-22 billion in damage. They draw parallels with Hurricane Sandy and Texas' frequent weather disasters, emphasizing the need for flood insurance understanding.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Commissioner Godfrey explains that flood insurance is separate from standard homeowner's policies, leading to consumer confusion. He advocates for restructuring FEMA, increasing pre-disaster mitigation, and encouraging private flood insurance market participation. Godfrey emphasizes the importance of flood insurance education and the role of insurance agents.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation discusses the low flood insurance coverage in Central Texas and across the US, highlighting the financial burden of natural disasters on uninsured residents.

video_title: 'You're Proud Of It?': Hank Johnson Relentlessly Shreds Heritage Foundation Fellow Over Project 2025

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Thank you. I thank the gentleman. I will recognize Mr. Johnson from Georgia.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. The majority's witnesses have repeatedly condemned the revolving door between what they call leftist nonprofits and the federal government, but they need to take a long, hard look in the mirror and talk about what's happening.  with MAGA billionaire corrupt corporate conservative front groups, such as the Heritage Foundation, a giant recipient of dark money. And that happens to be your employer, Mr. Gonzalez, correct?  I'd certainly take issue with the premise that we see dark money.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Yes, I'm very proud.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: And you've gotten a lot of dark money from Charles Koch, right? No, actually, we don't. Let me ask you this. Very little. Let me ask you this. Who's the biggest dark money guy out there between Charles Koch, who's worth $71.4 billion,  and George Soros, who's only worth a measly $7.2 billion. Who's the biggest dark money guy out there between those two? I don't know. Actually, I want to thank you for letting us sit down at the beginning.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You can't say that it's Charles Koch. First of all, are you aware that Charles Koch is a libertarian and we're not libertarian, right?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Let me just move on, sir.  Ahead of the 2024 presidential election, a network of right-wing dark money groups led by the Heritage Foundation launched the notorious and infamous Project 2025, a federal policy agenda for the second Trump administration that provides a blueprint for the radical and unconstitutional empowerment of the executive branch to shutter bureaus and offices  overturned regulations, and replaced thousands of public sector employees with political cronies and yes-men, all in the services of a right-wing, radical, corrupt corporate agenda. As of March of 2024, Project 2025 advisory groups have received more than $55 million from donor networks led by Leonard Leo and Charles Koch. Now, during the campaign,  which billionaire Elon Musk, by the way, purchased with about $275 million in dark money, Donald Trump swore he had nothing to do with Project 2025. But just like he lied about releasing the Epstein files, he also lied about his plan to implement Project 2025. Isn't that right, Mr. Walter?  Didn't he lie? You don't know? You won't say? Are you afraid? I'm quite awake. What about you, Mr. O'Neill? Did he lie?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: No, he said he didn't read it. Trump didn't lie when he said he was going to release the Epstein files? He said he didn't read Project 2025.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: Didn't he say he was going to release the Epstein files?  mean? Well, let me move on. Since the inauguration, Trump administration officials have worked tirelessly to implement Project 2025 and even has the author of Project 2025 as the Office of Management and Budget Director, Russell Voigt. Used to be the Vice President of Heritage Action, right, Mr. Gonzalez?  I believe he had a position. He used to be head of your operation, and now he is in the revolving door with the second Trump administration. Mr. Gonzalez, you've worked for the Heritage Foundation since 2009. Did you have any involvement with the creation?  and authorship of this infamous document, Project 2025?

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: Oh, yes, sir. I'm proud to say that I wrote an essay in it.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_02
lines.text: You're proud of it? Yes. And I worked for every version of this project, which we've had every four years at an election year.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_01
lines.text: It's called Mandate for Leadership. I'm telling you, the American people are not with you on that, Mr. Gonzalez. I'm just giving you the facts. And I'm going to tell you, in my remaining time, I'm going to sum up the testimony of you three guys, the Republican witnesses, and to sum it up,  You are anti-racial justice, you're anti-gender equity, and you're anti-environmental protection. And with that... Should we repeat our testimony? I will yield back the remainder of my time.

lines.speaker: SPEAKER_00
lines.text: There is no remainder of time. I'm sorry, Mr. Gonzales. You're going to get a chance. I think when some other people ask you questions, you'll have an ability to actually answer the question.

summary.SPEAKER_00: Recognises speakers and manages the flow of the conversation.  Acknowledges Mr Johnson from Georgia and Mr Gonzales. Indicates when time is up for speakers.
summary.SPEAKER_01: Accuses the Heritage Foundation of being a "dark money" recipient funded by billionaires like Charles Koch and George Soros. Criticises Project 2025 as a radical and unconstitutional agenda aimed at empowering the executive branch, shutting down bureaus, overturning regulations, and replacing public sector employees with political appointees. Alleges that Donald Trump lied about his association with Project 2025 and labels the Republican witnesses as anti-racial justice, anti-gender equity, and anti-environmental protection.
summary.SPEAKER_02: Defends the Heritage Foundation, stating that it is not libertarian and does not receive significant dark money from Charles Koch. Denies that Trump lied about Project 2025, clarifying that he said he didn't read it. Interrupts SPEAKER_01 and attempts to redirect the conversation.
summary.high_level_summary: The conversation is a heated exchange between a committee member (SPEAKER_01) and witnesses from conservative think tanks, particularly the Heritage Foundation. SPEAKER_01 accuses the Heritage Foundation of being a "dark money" recipient and criticises its Project 2025, a federal policy agenda for a potential second Trump administration. The witnesses defend the Foundation and Project 2025, while SPEAKER_01 alleges that the project aims to empower the executive branch, overturn regulations, and appoint political cronies.
